<h1 class="firstHeading mw-first-heading" id="firstHeading"><span class="mw-page-title-main">Bangladesh</span></h1>
<div class="vector-body" id="bodyContent">
<div class="noprint" id="siteSub">From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia</div>
<div id="contentSub"></div>
<div id="contentSub2"></div>
<div id="jump-to-nav"></div>

<a class="mw-jump-link" href="#searchInput">Jump to search</a>
<div class="mw-body-content mw-content-ltr" dir="ltr" id="mw-content-text" lang="en"><div class="mw-parser-output"><div class="shortdescription nomobile noexcerpt noprint searchaux" style="display:none">Country in South Asia</div>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1033289096">.mw-parser-output .hatnote{font-style:italic}.mw-parser-output div.hatnote{padding-left:1.6em;margin-bottom:0.5em}.mw-parser-output .hatnote i{font-style:normal}.mw-parser-output .hatnote+link+.hatnote{margin-top:-0.5em}</style><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">This article is about the country. For other uses, see <a class="mw-disambig" href="/wiki/Bangladesh_(disambiguation)" title="Bangladesh (disambiguation)">Bangladesh (disambiguation)</a>.</div>
<p>
<span style="font-size: small;"><span id="coordinates"><a href="/wiki/Geographic_coordinate_system" title="Geographic coordinate system">Coordinates</a>: <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1073938472">.mw-parser-output .geo-default,.mw-parser-output .geo-dms,.mw-parser-output .geo-dec{display:inline}.mw-parser-output .geo-nondefault,.mw-parser-output .geo-multi-punct{display:none}.mw-parser-output .longitude,.mw-parser-output .latitude{white-space:nowrap}</style><span class="plainlinks nourlexpansion"><a class="external text" href="//geohack.toolforge.org/geohack.php?pagename=Bangladesh&amp;params=24_N_90_E_type:country_region:BD"><span class="geo-default"><span class="geo-dms" title="Maps, aerial photos, and other data for this location"><span class="latitude">24°N</span> <span class="longitude">90°E</span></span></span><span class="geo-multi-punct">﻿ / ﻿</span><span class="geo-nondefault"><span class="geo-dec" title="Maps, aerial photos, and other data for this location">24°N 90°E</span><span style="display:none">﻿ / <span class="geo">24; 90</span></span></span></a></span></span></span>

<div class="side-box-text plainlist"><b>This article contains <a href="/wiki/Bengali_alphabet" title="Bengali alphabet">Bengali text</a>.</b> Without proper <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Bangla_script_display_help" title="Wikipedia:Bangla script display help">rendering support</a>, you may see <a href="/wiki/Specials_(Unicode_block)#Replacement_character" title="Specials (Unicode block)">question marks, boxes, or other symbols</a>.</div></div>
</div>
<p><b>Bangladesh</b> (<span class="rt-commentedText nowrap"><span class="IPA nopopups noexcerpt" lang="en-fonipa"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/English" title="Help:IPA/English">/<span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="/ˌ/: secondary stress follows">ˌ</span><span title="'b' in 'buy'">b</span><span title="/æ/: 'a' in 'bad'">æ</span><span title="/ŋ/: 'ng' in 'sing'">ŋ</span><span title="/ɡ/: 'g' in 'guy'">ɡ</span><span title="'l' in 'lie'">l</span><span title="/ə/: 'a' in 'about'">ə</span><span title="/ˈ/: primary stress follows">ˈ</span><span title="'d' in 'dye'">d</span><span title="/ɛ/: 'e' in 'dress'">ɛ</span><span title="/ʃ/: 'sh' in 'shy'">ʃ</span></span>,<span class="wrap"> </span><span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="/ˌ/: secondary stress follows">ˌ</span><span title="'b' in 'buy'">b</span><span title="/ɑː/: 'a' in 'father'">ɑː</span><span title="/ŋ/: 'ng' in 'sing'">ŋ</span></span>-/</a></span></span>;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-13"><a href="#cite_note-13">[13]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Bengali_language" title="Bengali language">Bengali</a>: <span lang="bn">বাংলাদেশ</span>, <small>pronounced </small><span class="IPA" lang="bn-Latn-fonipa" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/Bengali" title="Help:IPA/Bengali">[ˈbaŋlaˌdeʃ]</a></span> <span class="nowrap" style="font-size:85%">(<span class="unicode haudio"><span class="fn"><span style="white-space:nowrap;margin-right:.25em;"><a href="/wiki/File:Bn-%E0%A6%AC%E0%A6%BE%E0%A6%82%E0%A6%B2%E0%A6%BE%E0%A6%A6%E0%A7%87%E0%A6%B6.oga" title="About this sound"><img alt="" data-file-height="20" data-file-width="20" decoding="async" height="11" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/11px-Loudspeaker.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/17px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/22px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 2x" width="11"/></a></span><a class="internal" href="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/0/0a/Bn-%E0%A6%AC%E0%A6%BE%E0%A6%82%E0%A6%B2%E0%A6%BE%E0%A6%A6%E0%A7%87%E0%A6%B6.oga" title="Bn-বাংলাদেশ.oga">listen</a></span></span>)</span>), officially the <b>People's Republic of Bangladesh</b>, is a country in <a href="/wiki/South_Asia" title="South Asia">South Asia</a>. It is the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_and_dependencies_by_population" title="List of countries and dependencies by population">eighth-most populous country</a> in the world, with a population exceeding 165 million people in an area of 148,460 square kilometres (57,320 sq mi).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bdarea_7-4"><a href="#cite_note-bdarea-7">[7]</a></sup> Bangladesh is among the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_and_dependencies_by_population_density" title="List of countries and dependencies by population density">most densely populated countries</a> in the world, and shares land borders with <a href="/wiki/India" title="India">India</a> to the west, north, and east, and <a href="/wiki/Myanmar" title="Myanmar">Myanmar</a> to the southeast; to the south it has a coastline along the <a href="/wiki/Bay_of_Bengal" title="Bay of Bengal">Bay of Bengal</a>. It is narrowly separated from <a href="/wiki/Bhutan" title="Bhutan">Bhutan</a> and <a href="/wiki/Nepal" title="Nepal">Nepal</a> by the <a href="/wiki/Siliguri_Corridor" title="Siliguri Corridor">Siliguri Corridor</a>; and from <a href="/wiki/China" title="China">China</a> by the Indian state of <a href="/wiki/Sikkim" title="Sikkim">Sikkim</a> in the north. <a href="/wiki/Dhaka" title="Dhaka">Dhaka</a>, the capital and <a href="/wiki/List_of_cities_and_towns_in_Bangladesh" title="List of cities and towns in Bangladesh">largest city</a>, is the nation's political, financial and cultural center. <a href="/wiki/Chittagong" title="Chittagong">Chittagong</a>, the second-largest city, is the busiest port on the Bay of Bengal. The official language is <a href="/wiki/Bengali_language" title="Bengali language">Bengali</a>, one of the easternmost branches of the <a href="/wiki/Indo-European_languages" title="Indo-European languages">Indo-European language family</a>.
</p><p>Bangladesh forms the sovereign part of the historic and <a href="/wiki/Ethnolinguistics" title="Ethnolinguistics">ethnolinguistic</a> region of <a href="/wiki/Bengal" title="Bengal">Bengal</a>, which was divided during the <a href="/wiki/Partition_of_India" title="Partition of India">Partition of India</a> in 1947.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EyetsemitanGire2003_14-0"><a href="#cite_note-EyetsemitanGire2003-14">[14]</a></sup> The country has a <a href="/wiki/Bengali_Muslims" title="Bengali Muslims">Bengali Muslim</a> majority. Ancient Bengal was an important cultural centre in the <a href="/wiki/Indian_subcontinent" title="Indian subcontinent">Indian subcontinent</a> as the home of the states of <a href="/wiki/Vanga_Kingdom" title="Vanga Kingdom">Vanga</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pundravardhana" title="Pundravardhana">Pundra</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gangaridai" title="Gangaridai">Gangaridai</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gauda_Kingdom" title="Gauda Kingdom">Gauda</a>, <a href="/wiki/Samatata" title="Samatata">Samatata</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Harikela" title="Harikela">Harikela</a>. The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mauryan_Empire" title="Mauryan Empire">Mauryan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gupta_Empire" title="Gupta Empire">Gupta</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pala_Empire" title="Pala Empire">Pala</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sena_dynasty" title="Sena dynasty">Sena</a>, <a href="/wiki/Chandra_dynasty" title="Chandra dynasty">Chandra</a> and <a href="/wiki/Deva_dynasty" title="Deva dynasty">Deva</a> dynasties were the last pre-Islamic rulers of Bengal. The <a href="/wiki/Muslim_conquests_in_the_Indian_subcontinent" title="Muslim conquests in the Indian subcontinent">Muslim conquest of Bengal</a> began in 1204 when <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Muhammad_bin_Bakhtiyar_Khalji" title="Muhammad bin Bakhtiyar Khalji">Bakhtiar Khalji</a> overran northern Bengal and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Islamic_invasion_of_Tibet" title="Islamic invasion of Tibet">invaded Tibet</a>. Becoming part of the <a href="/wiki/Delhi_Sultanate" title="Delhi Sultanate">Delhi Sultanate</a>, three city-states emerged in the 14th century with much of eastern Bengal being ruled from <a href="/wiki/Sonargaon" title="Sonargaon">Sonargaon</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sufi" title="Sufi">Sufi</a> missionary leaders like <a href="/wiki/Sultan_Balkhi" title="Sultan Balkhi">Sultan Balkhi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Shah_Jalal" title="Shah Jalal">Shah Jalal</a> and <a href="/wiki/Shah_Makhdum_Rupos" title="Shah Makhdum Rupos">Shah Makhdum Rupos</a> helped in spreading Muslim rule. The region was unified into an independent, unitary <a href="/wiki/Bengal_Sultanate" title="Bengal Sultanate">Bengal Sultanate</a>. Under <a href="/wiki/Mughal_Empire" title="Mughal Empire">Mughal rule</a>, eastern Bengal continued to prosper as the melting pot of Muslims in the eastern subcontinent and attracted traders from around the world. The Bengali elite were among the richest people in the world due to strong trade networks like the <a href="/wiki/Muslin_trade_in_Bengal" title="Muslin trade in Bengal">muslin trade</a> which supplied textiles, such as 40% of Dutch imports from Asia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Prakash_1450,_pp._237_15-0"><a href="#cite_note-Prakash_1450,_pp._237-15">[15]</a></sup> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mughal_Bengal" title="Mughal Bengal">Mughal Bengal</a> became increasingly assertive and independent under the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nawabs_of_Bengal" title="Nawabs of Bengal">Nawabs of Bengal</a> in the 18th century. In 1757, the betrayal of <a href="/wiki/Mir_Jafar" title="Mir Jafar">Mir Jafar</a> resulted in the defeat of Nawab <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Siraj-ud-Daulah" title="Siraj-ud-Daulah">Siraj-ud-Daulah</a> to the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/British_East_India_Company" title="British East India Company">British East India Company</a> and eventual British dominance across South Asia. The <a href="/wiki/Bengal_Presidency" title="Bengal Presidency">Bengal Presidency</a> grew into the largest administrative unit in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/British_India" title="British India">British India</a>. The creation of <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Bengal_and_Assam" title="Eastern Bengal and Assam">Eastern Bengal and Assam</a> in 1905 set a precedent for the emergence of Bangladesh. In 1940, the first <a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Bengal" title="Prime Minister of Bengal">Prime Minister of Bengal</a> supported the <a href="/wiki/Lahore_Resolution" title="Lahore Resolution">Lahore Resolution</a> with the hope of creating a state in eastern South Asia. Prior to the <a href="/wiki/Partition_of_Bengal_(1947)" title="Partition of Bengal (1947)">partition of Bengal</a>, the Prime Minister of Bengal proposed a <a href="/wiki/United_Bengal" title="United Bengal">Bengali sovereign state</a>. A <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sylhet_referendum,_1947" title="Sylhet referendum, 1947">referendum</a> and the announcement of the <a href="/wiki/Radcliffe_Line" title="Radcliffe Line">Radcliffe Line</a> established the present-day territorial boundary of Bangladesh.
</p><p>In 1947, <a href="/wiki/East_Bengal" title="East Bengal">East Bengal</a> became the most populous province in the <a href="/wiki/Dominion_of_Pakistan" title="Dominion of Pakistan">Dominion of Pakistan</a>. It was renamed as <a href="/wiki/East_Pakistan" title="East Pakistan">East Pakistan</a> with Dhaka becoming the country's legislative capital. The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bengali_Language_Movement" title="Bengali Language Movement">Bengali Language Movement</a> in 1952; the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/East_Bengali_legislative_election,_1954" title="East Bengali legislative election, 1954">East Bengali legislative election, 1954</a>; the <a href="/wiki/1958_Pakistani_coup_d%27%C3%A9tat" title="1958 Pakistani coup d'état">1958 Pakistani coup d'état</a>; the <a href="/wiki/Six_point_movement" title="Six point movement">Six point movement</a> of 1966; and the <a href="/wiki/1970_Pakistani_general_election" title="1970 Pakistani general election">1970 Pakistani general election</a> resulted in the rise of <a href="/wiki/Bengali_nationalism" title="Bengali nationalism">Bengali nationalism</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pro-democracy" title="Pro-democracy">pro-democracy</a> movements in East Pakistan. The refusal of the Pakistani military junta to transfer power to the <a href="/wiki/Awami_League" title="Awami League">Awami League</a> led by <a href="/wiki/Sheikh_Mujibur_Rahman" title="Sheikh Mujibur Rahman">Sheikh Mujibur Rahman</a> led to the <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh_Liberation_War" title="Bangladesh Liberation War">Bangladesh Liberation War</a> in 1971, in which the <a href="/wiki/Mukti_Bahini" title="Mukti Bahini">Mukti Bahini</a> aided by India waged a successful <a href="/wiki/Revolution" title="Revolution">armed revolution</a>. The conflict saw the <a href="/wiki/1971_Bangladesh_genocide" title="1971 Bangladesh genocide">1971 Bangladesh genocide</a> and the massacre of pro-independence Bengali civilians, including <a href="/wiki/1971_killing_of_Bengali_intellectuals" title="1971 killing of Bengali intellectuals">intellectuals</a>. The new state of Bangladesh became the first constitutionally <a href="/wiki/Secularism_in_Bangladesh" title="Secularism in Bangladesh">secular state</a> in South Asia in 1972.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-16"><a href="#cite_note-16">[16]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Islam" title="Islam">Islam</a> was declared the state religion in 1988.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-17"><a href="#cite_note-17">[17]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-18"><a href="#cite_note-18">[18]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-19"><a href="#cite_note-19">[19]</a></sup> In 2010, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bangladesh_Supreme_Court" title="Bangladesh Supreme Court">Bangladesh Supreme Court</a> reaffirmed secular principles in the constitution.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-20"><a href="#cite_note-20">[20]</a></sup>
</p><p>A <a href="/wiki/Middle_power" title="Middle power">middle power</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Indo-Pacific" title="Indo-Pacific">Indo-Pacific</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-21"><a href="#cite_note-21">[21]</a></sup> Bangladesh is the second largest economy in South Asia. It maintains the third-largest <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh_Armed_Forces" title="Bangladesh Armed Forces">military</a> in the region and eighth-largest in the world as it is a major contributor to <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/UN_peacekeeping" title="UN peacekeeping">UN peacekeeping</a> operations. Bangladesh has the largest <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Paramilitary_force" title="Paramilitary force">Paramilitary force</a> in the world. The large <a href="/wiki/Muslims" title="Muslims">Muslim</a> population of Bangladesh makes it the <a href="/wiki/Islam_by_country" title="Islam by country">third-largest Muslim-majority country</a>. Bangladesh is a <a href="/wiki/Unitary_state" title="Unitary state">unitary</a> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Parliamentary_democracy" title="Parliamentary democracy">parliamentary</a> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Constitutional_republic" title="Constitutional republic">constitutional republic</a> based on the <a href="/wiki/Westminster_system" title="Westminster system">Westminster system</a>. <a href="/wiki/Bengalis" title="Bengalis">Bengalis</a> make up 99% of the total population of Bangladesh.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-22"><a href="#cite_note-22">[22]</a></sup> The country consists of <a href="/wiki/Divisions_of_Bangladesh" title="Divisions of Bangladesh">8 divisions</a>, <a href="/wiki/Districts_of_Bangladesh" title="Districts of Bangladesh">64 districts</a> and <a href="/wiki/Upazila" title="Upazila">495 subdistricts</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-23"><a href="#cite_note-23">[23]</a></sup> It hosts one of the largest <a href="/wiki/Rohingya_refugees_in_Bangladesh" title="Rohingya refugees in Bangladesh">refugee</a> populations in the world due to the <a href="/wiki/Rohingya_genocide" title="Rohingya genocide">Rohingya genocide</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-24"><a href="#cite_note-24">[24]</a></sup> Bangladesh faces many challenges, particularly <a href="/wiki/Effects_of_climate_change" title="Effects of climate change">effects of climate change</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-25"><a href="#cite_note-25">[25]</a></sup> Bangladesh has been a leader within the <a href="/wiki/Climate_Vulnerable_Forum" title="Climate Vulnerable Forum">Climate Vulnerable Forum</a>. It hosts the headquarters of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/BIMSTEC" title="BIMSTEC">BIMSTEC</a>. It is a founding member of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/SAARC" title="SAARC">SAARC</a>, as well as a member of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Organization_of_Islamic_Cooperation" title="Organization of Islamic Cooperation">Organization of Islamic Cooperation</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Commonwealth_of_Nations" title="Commonwealth of Nations">Commonwealth of Nations</a>.
</p>
<div aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading" class="toc" id="toc" role="navigation"><input class="toctogglecheckbox" id="toctogglecheckbox" role="button" style="display:none" type="checkbox"/><div class="toctitle" dir="ltr" lang="en"><h2 id="mw-toc-heading">Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span></div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Etymology">Etymology</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Names_of_Bengal" title="Names of Bengal">Names of Bengal</a></div>
<p>The etymology of <i>Bangladesh</i> ("Bengali Country") can be traced to the early 20th century, when Bengali patriotic songs, such as <i>Namo Namo Namo Bangladesh Momo</i> by <a href="/wiki/Kazi_Nazrul_Islam" title="Kazi Nazrul Islam">Kazi Nazrul Islam</a> and <i>Aaji Bangladesher Hridoy</i> by <a href="/wiki/Rabindranath_Tagore" title="Rabindranath Tagore">Rabindranath Tagore</a>, used the term.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-26"><a href="#cite_note-26">[26]</a></sup> The term <i>Bangladesh</i> was often written as two words, <i>Bangla Desh</i>, in the past. Starting in the 1950s, Bengali nationalists used the term in political rallies in <a href="/wiki/East_Pakistan" title="East Pakistan">East Pakistan</a>. The term <i>Bangla</i> is a major name for both the <a href="/wiki/Bengal" title="Bengal">Bengal</a> region and the <a href="/wiki/Bengali_language" title="Bengali language">Bengali language</a>. The origins of the term <i>Bangla</i> are unclear, with theories pointing to a <a href="/wiki/Bronze_Age" title="Bronze Age">Bronze Age</a> <a href="/wiki/Proto-Dravidian_language" title="Proto-Dravidian language">proto-Dravidian</a> tribe,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-27"><a href="#cite_note-27">[27]</a></sup> the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Austric" title="Austric">Austric</a> word "Bonga" (Sun god),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-auto4_28-0"><a href="#cite_note-auto4-28">[28]</a></sup> and the Iron Age <a href="/wiki/Vanga_Kingdom" title="Vanga Kingdom">Vanga Kingdom</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-auto4_28-1"><a href="#cite_note-auto4-28">[28]</a></sup> The earliest known usage of the term is the <a href="/wiki/Nesari" title="Nesari">Nesari plate</a> in 805 AD. The term <i>Vangaladesa</i> is found in 11th-century South Indian records.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-29"><a href="#cite_note-29">[29]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-auto3_30-0"><a href="#cite_note-auto3-30">[30]</a></sup> The term gained official status during the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sultanate_of_Bengal" title="Sultanate of Bengal">Sultanate of Bengal</a> in the 14th century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ahmed2004_31-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ahmed2004-31">[31]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-32"><a href="#cite_note-32">[32]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Shamsuddin_Ilyas_Shah" title="Shamsuddin Ilyas Shah">Shamsuddin Ilyas Shah</a> proclaimed himself as the first "<a href="/wiki/Shah" title="Shah">Shah</a> of Bangala" in 1342.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ahmed2004_31-1"><a href="#cite_note-Ahmed2004-31">[31]</a></sup> The word <i>Bangāl</i> became the most common name for the region during the Islamic period.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-33"><a href="#cite_note-33">[33]</a></sup> 16th-century historian <a href="/wiki/Abu%27l-Fazl_ibn_Mubarak" title="Abu'l-Fazl ibn Mubarak">Abu'l-Fazl ibn Mubarak</a> mentions in his <i><a href="/wiki/Ain-i-Akbari" title="Ain-i-Akbari">Ain-i-Akbari</a></i> that the addition of the suffix <i>"al"</i> came from the fact that the ancient rajahs of the land raised mounds of earth 10 feet high and 20 in breadth in lowlands at the foot of the hills which were called "al".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-34"><a href="#cite_note-34">[34]</a></sup> This is also mentioned in <a href="/wiki/Ghulam_Husain_Salim" title="Ghulam Husain Salim">Ghulam Husain Salim</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Riyaz-us-Salatin" title="Riyaz-us-Salatin">Riyaz-us-Salatin</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-riaj_35-0"><a href="#cite_note-riaj-35">[35]</a></sup> The Indo-Aryan suffix <i>Desh</i> is derived from the Sanskrit word <i>deśha</i>, which means "land" or "country". Hence, the name <i>Bangladesh</i> means "Land of Bengal" or "Country of Bengal".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-auto3_30-1"><a href="#cite_note-auto3-30">[30]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/History_of_Bengal" title="History of Bengal">History of Bengal</a> and <a href="/wiki/History_of_Bangladesh" title="History of Bangladesh">History of Bangladesh</a></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Ancient_Bengal">Ancient Bengal</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Asia_800ad.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1215" data-file-width="2099" decoding="async" height="127" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/19/Asia_800ad.jpg/220px-Asia_800ad.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/19/Asia_800ad.jpg/330px-Asia_800ad.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/19/Asia_800ad.jpg/440px-Asia_800ad.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Asia_800ad.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The earliest form of the <a href="/wiki/Bengali_language" title="Bengali language">Bengali language</a> developed during the <a href="/wiki/Pala_Empire" title="Pala Empire">Pala Empire</a>, shown here on a map of Asia in 800 CE.</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ruins_of_Somapura_Mahavihara,_May_2017_47.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2368" data-file-width="4160" decoding="async" height="125" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c3/Ruins_of_Somapura_Mahavihara%2C_May_2017_47.jpg/220px-Ruins_of_Somapura_Mahavihara%2C_May_2017_47.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c3/Ruins_of_Somapura_Mahavihara%2C_May_2017_47.jpg/330px-Ruins_of_Somapura_Mahavihara%2C_May_2017_47.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c3/Ruins_of_Somapura_Mahavihara%2C_May_2017_47.jpg/440px-Ruins_of_Somapura_Mahavihara%2C_May_2017_47.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Ruins_of_Somapura_Mahavihara,_May_2017_47.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Somapura_Mahavihara" title="Somapura Mahavihara">ruins of Paharpur</a> include a pyramid like structure from the Pala period.</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Stone_Age" title="Stone Age">Stone Age</a> tools found in Bangladesh indicate human habitation for over 20,000 years,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bharadwaj2003_36-0"><a href="#cite_note-Bharadwaj2003-36">[36]</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources" title="Wikipedia:Citing sources"><span title="This citation requires a reference to the specific page or range of pages in which the material appears. (October 2021)">page needed</span></a></i>]</sup> and remnants of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Copper_Age" title="Copper Age">Copper Age</a> settlements date back 4,000 years.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bharadwaj2003_36-1"><a href="#cite_note-Bharadwaj2003-36">[36]</a></sup> Ancient Bengal was settled by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Austroasiatic" title="Austroasiatic">Austroasiatics</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tibeto-Burman" title="Tibeto-Burman">Tibeto-Burmans</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Dravidian_people" title="Dravidian people">Dravidians</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rigvedic_tribes" title="Rigvedic tribes">Indo-Aryans</a> in consecutive waves of migration.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bharadwaj2003_36-2"><a href="#cite_note-Bharadwaj2003-36">[36]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-congress_37-0"><a href="#cite_note-congress-37">[37]</a></sup> Archaeological evidence confirms that by the second millennium BCE, rice-cultivating communities inhabited the region. By the 11th century people lived in systemically aligned housing, buried their dead, and manufactured copper ornaments and black and red pottery.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-google5_38-0"><a href="#cite_note-google5-38">[38]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Ganges" title="Ganges">Ganges</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Brahmaputra" title="Brahmaputra">Brahmaputra</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Meghna" title="Meghna">Meghna</a> rivers were natural arteries for communication and transportation,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-google5_38-1"><a href="#cite_note-google5-38">[38]</a></sup> and estuaries on the Bay of Bengal permitted maritime trade. The early <a href="/wiki/Iron_Age" title="Iron Age">Iron Age</a> saw the development of metal weaponry, coinage, agriculture and <a href="/wiki/Irrigation" title="Irrigation">irrigation</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-google5_38-2"><a href="#cite_note-google5-38">[38]</a></sup> Major urban settlements formed during the late Iron Age, in the mid-<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/First_millennium_BCE" title="First millennium BCE">first millennium BCE</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-39"><a href="#cite_note-39">[39]</a></sup> when the <a href="/wiki/Northern_Black_Polished_Ware" title="Northern Black Polished Ware">Northern Black Polished Ware</a> culture developed.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PierisRaven2010_40-0"><a href="#cite_note-PierisRaven2010-40">[40]</a></sup> In 1879, <a href="/wiki/Alexander_Cunningham" title="Alexander Cunningham">Alexander Cunningham</a> identified <a href="/wiki/Mahasthangarh" title="Mahasthangarh">Mahasthangarh</a> as the capital of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pundra_Kingdom" title="Pundra Kingdom">Pundra Kingdom</a> mentioned in the <i><a href="/wiki/Rigveda" title="Rigveda">Rigveda</a></i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-41"><a href="#cite_note-41">[41]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-42"><a href="#cite_note-42">[42]</a></sup> The oldest inscription in Bangladesh was found in Mahasthangarh and dates from the 3rd century BCE. It is written in the <a href="/wiki/Brahmi_script" title="Brahmi script">Brahmi script</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-43"><a href="#cite_note-43">[43]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Greco-Roman_world" title="Greco-Roman world">Greek and Roman</a> records of the ancient <a href="/wiki/Gangaridai" title="Gangaridai">Gangaridai</a> Kingdom, which (according to legend) deterred the invasion of <a href="/wiki/Alexander_the_Great" title="Alexander the Great">Alexander the Great</a>, are linked to the fort city in <a href="/wiki/Wari-Bateshwar_ruins" title="Wari-Bateshwar ruins">Wari-Bateshwar</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-44"><a href="#cite_note-44">[44]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-thedailystar1_45-0"><a href="#cite_note-thedailystar1-45">[45]</a></sup> The site is also identified with the prosperous trading centre of Souanagoura listed on <a href="/wiki/Ptolemy%27s_world_map" title="Ptolemy's world map">Ptolemy's world map</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-google1_46-0"><a href="#cite_note-google1-46">[46]</a></sup> Roman geographers noted a large seaport in southeastern Bengal, corresponding to the present-day <a href="/wiki/Chittagong_District" title="Chittagong District">Chittagong</a> region.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-47"><a href="#cite_note-47">[47]</a></sup>
</p><p>Ancient <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Buddhist" title="Buddhist">Buddhist</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hindu" title="Hindu">Hindu</a> states which ruled Bangladesh included the <a href="/wiki/Vanga_Kingdom" title="Vanga Kingdom">Vanga</a>, <a href="/wiki/Samatata" title="Samatata">Samatata</a> and Pundra kingdoms, the Mauryan and <a href="/wiki/Gupta_Empire" title="Gupta Empire">Gupta Empires</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Varman_dynasty" title="Varman dynasty">Varman dynasty</a>, <a href="/wiki/Shashanka" title="Shashanka">Shashanka</a>'s kingdom, the <a href="/wiki/Khadga_dynasty" title="Khadga dynasty">Khadga</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Candra_dynasty" title="Candra dynasty">Candra dynasties</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Pala_Empire" title="Pala Empire">Pala Empire</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Sena_dynasty" title="Sena dynasty">Sena dynasty</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Harikela" title="Harikela">Harikela</a> kingdom and the <a href="/wiki/Deva_dynasty" title="Deva dynasty">Deva dynasty</a>. These states had well-developed currencies, banking, shipping, architecture, and art, and the ancient universities of <a href="/wiki/Bikrampur" title="Bikrampur">Bikrampur</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mainamati" title="Mainamati">Mainamati</a> hosted scholars and students from other parts of Asia. <a href="/wiki/Xuanzang" title="Xuanzang">Xuanzang</a> of China was a noted scholar who resided at the <a href="/wiki/Somapura_Mahavihara" title="Somapura Mahavihara">Somapura Mahavihara</a> (the largest monastery in ancient India), and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Atisa" title="Atisa">Atisa</a> travelled from Bengal to <a href="/wiki/Tibet" title="Tibet">Tibet</a> to preach Buddhism. The earliest form of the <a href="/wiki/Bengali_language" title="Bengali language">Bengali language</a> emerged during the eighth century. Seafarers in the <a href="/wiki/Bay_of_Bengal" title="Bay of Bengal">Bay of Bengal</a> were modern Bangladesh is now located in, have also been sailing and trading with <a href="/wiki/Southeast_Asia" title="Southeast Asia">Southeast Asia</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-48"><a href="#cite_note-48">[48]</a></sup> and exported Buddhist and Hindu cultures to the region since the early Christian era.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-49"><a href="#cite_note-49">[49]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Islamic_Bengal">Islamic Bengal</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Map_of_Bengal_Sultanate.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1792" data-file-width="1717" decoding="async" height="230" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c1/Map_of_Bengal_Sultanate.png/220px-Map_of_Bengal_Sultanate.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c1/Map_of_Bengal_Sultanate.png/330px-Map_of_Bengal_Sultanate.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c1/Map_of_Bengal_Sultanate.png/440px-Map_of_Bengal_Sultanate.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Map_of_Bengal_Sultanate.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Bengal_Sultanate" title="Bengal Sultanate">Bengal Sultanate</a> and its vassals.</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Darashbari_Mosque_-012_Photo_by_Porag.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2803" data-file-width="4200" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f9/Darashbari_Mosque_-012_Photo_by_Porag.jpg/220px-Darashbari_Mosque_-012_Photo_by_Porag.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f9/Darashbari_Mosque_-012_Photo_by_Porag.jpg/330px-Darashbari_Mosque_-012_Photo_by_Porag.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f9/Darashbari_Mosque_-012_Photo_by_Porag.jpg/440px-Darashbari_Mosque_-012_Photo_by_Porag.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Darashbari_Mosque_-012_Photo_by_Porag.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Mihrab" title="Mihrab">Mihrabs</a> and arches in the ruins of <a href="/wiki/Darasbari_Mosque" title="Darasbari Mosque">Darasbari Mosque</a>, an Islamic learning center during the Bengal Sultanate. Its roof collapsed after an <a href="/wiki/1897_Assam_earthquake" title="1897 Assam earthquake">1897 earthquake</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-50"><a href="#cite_note-50">[50]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Sixty_Dome_Mosque-01.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2736" data-file-width="3648" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e3/Sixty_Dome_Mosque-01.jpg/220px-Sixty_Dome_Mosque-01.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e3/Sixty_Dome_Mosque-01.jpg/330px-Sixty_Dome_Mosque-01.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e3/Sixty_Dome_Mosque-01.jpg/440px-Sixty_Dome_Mosque-01.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Sixty_Dome_Mosque-01.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Sixty_Dome_Mosque" title="Sixty Dome Mosque">Sixty Dome Mosque</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Mosque_City_of_Bagerhat" title="Mosque City of Bagerhat">Mosque City of Bagerhat</a> is the largest sultanate-era mosque in Bangladesh.</div></div></div>
<p>The early history of Islam in Bengal is divided into two phases. The first phase is the period of maritime trade with Arabia and Persia between the 8th and 12th centuries. The second phase covers centuries of Muslim dynastic rule after the Islamic conquest of Bengal. The writings of <a href="/wiki/Muhammad_al-Idrisi" title="Muhammad al-Idrisi">Al-Idrisi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ibn_Hawqal" title="Ibn Hawqal">Ibn Hawqal</a>, <a href="/wiki/Al-Masudi" title="Al-Masudi">Al-Masudi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ibn_Khordadbeh" title="Ibn Khordadbeh">Ibn Khordadbeh</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sulaiman_al-Tajir" title="Sulaiman al-Tajir">Sulaiman</a> record the maritime links between Arabia, Persia and Bengal.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-auto5_51-0"><a href="#cite_note-auto5-51">[51]</a></sup> Muslim trade with Bengal flourished after the fall of the <a href="/wiki/Sasanian_Empire" title="Sasanian Empire">Sasanian Empire</a> and the Arab takeover of Persian trade routes. Much of this trade occurred with southeastern Bengal in areas east of the <a href="/wiki/Meghna_River" title="Meghna River">Meghna River</a>. There is speculation regarding the presence of a Muslim community in Bangladesh as early as 690 CE; this is based on the discovery of one of South Asia's oldest mosques in northern Bangladesh.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-52"><a href="#cite_note-52">[52]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-53"><a href="#cite_note-53">[53]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-auto5_51-1"><a href="#cite_note-auto5-51">[51]</a></sup> Bengal was possibly used as a transit route to <a href="/wiki/China" title="China">China</a> by the earliest Muslims. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Abbasid" title="Abbasid">Abbasid</a> coins have been discovered in the archaeological ruins of <a href="/wiki/Somapura_Mahavihara" title="Somapura Mahavihara">Paharpur</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mainamati" title="Mainamati">Mainamati</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-54"><a href="#cite_note-54">[54]</a></sup> A collection of Sasanian, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Umayyad" title="Umayyad">Umayyad</a> and Abbasid coins are preserved in the <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh_National_Museum" title="Bangladesh National Museum">Bangladesh National Museum</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-55"><a href="#cite_note-55">[55]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Muslim conquest of Bengal began with the 1204 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ghurid_Empire" title="Ghurid Empire">Ghurid</a> expeditions led by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Muhammad_bin_Bakhtiyar_Khalji" title="Muhammad bin Bakhtiyar Khalji">Muhammad bin Bakhtiyar Khalji</a>, who overran the Sena capital in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gauda_(city)" title="Gauda (city)">Gauda</a> and led the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Islamic_invasion_of_Tibet" title="Islamic invasion of Tibet">first Muslim army into Tibet</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-google5_38-3"><a href="#cite_note-google5-38">[38]</a></sup> The conquest of Bengal was inscribed in gold coins of the <a href="/wiki/Delhi_Sultanate" title="Delhi Sultanate">Delhi Sultanate</a>. Bengal was ruled by the Sultans of Delhi for a century under the <a href="/wiki/Mamluk_dynasty_(Delhi)" title="Mamluk dynasty (Delhi)">Mamluk</a>, Balban, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tughluq_dynasty" title="Tughluq dynasty">Tughluq dynasties</a>. In the 14th century, three city-states emerged in Bengal, including <a href="/wiki/Sonargaon" title="Sonargaon">Sonargaon</a> led by <a href="/wiki/Fakhruddin_Mubarak_Shah" title="Fakhruddin Mubarak Shah">Fakhruddin Mubarak Shah</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Satgaon" title="Satgaon">Satgaon</a> led by <a href="/wiki/Shamsuddin_Ilyas_Shah" title="Shamsuddin Ilyas Shah">Shamsuddin Ilyas Shah</a> and <a href="/wiki/Gau%E1%B8%8Da_(city)" title="Gauḍa (city)">Lakhnauti</a> led by <a href="/wiki/Alauddin_Ali_Shah" title="Alauddin Ali Shah">Alauddin Ali Shah</a>. These city-states were led by former governors who declared independence from Delhi. The Moroccan traveler <a href="/wiki/Ibn_Battuta" title="Ibn Battuta">Ibn Battuta</a> visited eastern Bengal during the reign of Fakhruddin Mubarak Shah. Ibn Battuta also visited the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sufi" title="Sufi">Sufi</a> leader <a href="/wiki/Shah_Jalal" title="Shah Jalal">Shah Jalal</a> in <a href="/wiki/Sylhet" title="Sylhet">Sylhet</a>. Sufis played an important role in spreading Islam in Bengal through both peaceful conversion and militarily overthrowing pre-Islamic rulers. In 1352, Shamsuddin Ilyas Shah united the three city-states into a single, unitary and independent <a href="/wiki/Bengal_Sultanate" title="Bengal Sultanate">Bengal Sultanate</a>. The new Sultan of Bengal led the first Muslim army into <a href="/wiki/Nepal" title="Nepal">Nepal</a> and forced the Sultan of Delhi to <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bengal_Sultanate-Delhi_Sultanate_War" title="Bengal Sultanate-Delhi Sultanate War">retreat</a> during an invasion. The army of Ilyas Shah reached as far as <a href="/wiki/Varanasi" title="Varanasi">Varanasi</a> in the northwest, <a href="/wiki/Kathmandu" title="Kathmandu">Kathmandu</a> in the north, <a href="/wiki/Kamarupa" title="Kamarupa">Kamarupa</a> in the east and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Orissa" title="Orissa">Orissa</a> in the south. Ilyas Shah raided many of these areas and returned to Bengal with treasures. During the reign of <a href="/wiki/Sikandar_Shah" title="Sikandar Shah">Sikandar Shah</a>, Delhi recognized Bengal's independence. The Bengal Sultanate established a network of mint towns which acted as a provincial capitals where the <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_taka" title="History of the taka">Sultan's currency</a> was minted.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-56"><a href="#cite_note-56">[56]</a></sup> Bengal became the eastern frontier of the Islamic world, which stretched from <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Muslim_Spain" title="Muslim Spain">Muslim Spain</a> in the west to Bengal in the east. The Bengali language crystallized as an official court language during the Bengal Sultanate, with prominent writers like Nur Qutb Alam, <a href="/wiki/Usman_Serajuddin" title="Usman Serajuddin">Usman Serajuddin</a>, <a href="/wiki/Alaul_Haq" title="Alaul Haq">Alaul Haq</a>, <a href="/wiki/Alaol" title="Alaol">Alaol</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Shah_Muhammad_Sagir" title="Shah Muhammad Sagir">Shah Muhammad Sagir</a>, <a href="/wiki/Abdul_Hakim_(poet)" title="Abdul Hakim (poet)">Abdul Hakim</a> and <a href="/wiki/Syed_Sultan" title="Syed Sultan">Syed Sultan</a>; and the emergence of <i><a href="/wiki/Dobhashi" title="Dobhashi">Dobhashi</a></i> to write Muslim epics in Bengali literature.
</p><p>The Bengal Sultanate was a melting pot of Muslim political, mercantile and military elites. Muslims from other parts of the world migrated to Bengal for military, bureaucratic and household services.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-auto1_57-0"><a href="#cite_note-auto1-57">[57]</a></sup> Immigrants included Persians who were lawyers, teachers, clerics, and scholars;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-58"><a href="#cite_note-58">[58]</a></sup> Turks from upper India who were originally recruited in <a href="/wiki/Central_Asia" title="Central Asia">Central Asia</a>; and Abyssinians who came via East Africa and arrived in the Bengali port of Chittagong.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-auto1_57-1"><a href="#cite_note-auto1-57">[57]</a></sup> A highly commercialized and monetized economy evolved.
</p><p>The two most prominent dynasties of the Bengal Sultanate were the <a href="/wiki/Ilyas_Shahi_dynasty" title="Ilyas Shahi dynasty">Ilyas Shahi</a> and <a href="/wiki/Hussain_Shahi_dynasty" title="Hussain Shahi dynasty">Hussain Shahi</a> dynasties. The reign of Sultan <a href="/wiki/Ghiyasuddin_Azam_Shah" title="Ghiyasuddin Azam Shah">Ghiyasuddin Azam Shah</a> saw the opening of diplomatic relations with <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ming_China" title="Ming China">Ming China</a>. Ghiyasuddin was also a friend of the Persian poet <a href="/wiki/Hafez" title="Hafez">Hafez</a>. The reign of the Sultan <a href="/wiki/Jalaluddin_Muhammad_Shah" title="Jalaluddin Muhammad Shah">Jalaluddin Muhammad Shah</a> saw the development of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bengali_architecture" title="Bengali architecture">Bengali architecture</a>. During the early 15th century, the <a href="/wiki/Restoration_of_Min_Saw_Mon" title="Restoration of Min Saw Mon">Restoration of Min Saw Mon</a> in <a href="/wiki/Arakan" title="Arakan">Arakan</a> was aided by the army of the Bengal Sultanate. As a result, Arakan became a tributary state of Bengal. Even though Arakan later became independent, Bengali Muslim influence in Arakan persisted for 300 years due to the settlement of Bengali bureaucrats, poets, military personnel, farmers, artisans and sailors. The kings of Arakan fashioned themselves after Bengali Sultans and adopted Muslim titles.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Chowdhury2004_59-0"><a href="#cite_note-Chowdhury2004-59">[59]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ChutintharanonChutintharānonBaker2002_60-0"><a href="#cite_note-ChutintharanonChutintharānonBaker2002-60">[60]</a></sup> During the reign of Sultan <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Alauddin_Hussain_Shah" title="Alauddin Hussain Shah">Alauddin Hussain Shah</a>, the Bengal Sultanate dispatched a naval <a href="/wiki/Flotilla" title="Flotilla">flotilla</a> and an army of 24,000 soldiers led by <a href="/wiki/Shah_Ismail_Ghazi" title="Shah Ismail Ghazi">Shah Ismail Ghazi</a> to conquer <a href="/wiki/Kamata_Kingdom" title="Kamata Kingdom">Assam</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-r1_61-0"><a href="#cite_note-r1-61">[61]</a></sup> Bengali forces penetrated deep into the <a href="/wiki/Brahmaputra_Valley" title="Brahmaputra Valley">Brahmaputra Valley</a>. Hussain Shah's forces also conquered Jajnagar in Orissa.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-62"><a href="#cite_note-62">[62]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-63"><a href="#cite_note-63">[63]</a></sup> In <a href="/wiki/Tripura" title="Tripura">Tripura</a>, Bengal helped <a href="/wiki/Ratna_Manikya_I" title="Ratna Manikya I">Ratna Manikya I</a> to assume the throne.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Eaton1996p64_64-0"><a href="#cite_note-Eaton1996p64-64">[64]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-65"><a href="#cite_note-65">[65]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-66"><a href="#cite_note-66">[66]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Jaunpur_Sultanate" title="Jaunpur Sultanate">Jaunpur Sultanate</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pratapgarh_Kingdom" title="Pratapgarh Kingdom">Pratapgarh Kingdom</a> and the island of <a href="/wiki/Chandradwip" title="Chandradwip">Chandradwip</a> also came under Bengali control.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Hasan2007p16-17_67-0"><a href="#cite_note-Hasan2007p16-17-67">[67]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-68"><a href="#cite_note-68">[68]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-69"><a href="#cite_note-69">[69]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Hasan1987_70-0"><a href="#cite_note-Hasan1987-70">[70]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-71"><a href="#cite_note-71">[71]</a></sup> By 1500, Gaur became the fifth-most populous city in the world with a population of 200,000.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-72"><a href="#cite_note-72">[72]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-73"><a href="#cite_note-73">[73]</a></sup> The river port of <a href="/wiki/Sonargaon" title="Sonargaon">Sonargaon</a> was used as a base by the Sultans of Bengal during campaigns against Assam, Tripura and Arakan. The Sultans launched many naval raids from Sonargaon.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-dhakatribune.com_74-0"><a href="#cite_note-dhakatribune.com-74">[74]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Jo%C3%A3o_de_Barros" title="João de Barros">João de Barros</a> described the sea port of Chittagong as "the most famous and wealthy city of the Kingdom of Bengal".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-75"><a href="#cite_note-75">[75]</a></sup> Maritime trade linked Bengal with <a href="/wiki/China" title="China">China</a>, <a href="/wiki/Malacca_Sultanate" title="Malacca Sultanate">Malacca</a>, <a href="/wiki/Aceh_Sultanate" title="Aceh Sultanate">Sumatra</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bruneian_Empire" title="Bruneian Empire">Brunei</a>, <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_India" title="Portuguese India">Portuguese India</a>, <a href="/wiki/East_Africa" title="East Africa">East Africa</a>, Arabia, Persia, Mesopotamia, <a href="/wiki/Yemen" title="Yemen">Yemen</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Maldives" title="Maldives">Maldives</a>. Bengali ships were among the biggest vessels plying the <a href="/wiki/Bay_of_Bengal" title="Bay of Bengal">Bay of Bengal</a>, <a href="/wiki/Indian_Ocean" title="Indian Ocean">Indian Ocean</a> and <a href="/wiki/Pacific_Ocean" title="Pacific Ocean">Pacific Ocean</a>. A royal vessel from Bengal accommodated three embassies from Bengal, Brunei and Sumatra while en route to China and was the only vessel capable of transporting three embassies.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-auto2_76-0"><a href="#cite_note-auto2-76">[76]</a></sup> Many wealthy Bengali shipowners and merchants lived in Malacca. The Sultans permitted the opening of the <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_settlement_in_Chittagong" title="Portuguese settlement in Chittagong">Portuguese settlement in Chittagong</a>. The disintegration of the Bengal Sultanate began with the intervention of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Suri_Empire" title="Suri Empire">Suri Empire</a>. <a href="/wiki/Babur" title="Babur">Babur</a> began invading Bengal after creating the Mughal Empire. The Bengal Sultanate collapsed with the overthrow of the <a href="/wiki/Karrani_dynasty" title="Karrani dynasty">Karrani dynasty</a> during the reign of Akbar. However, the <a href="/wiki/Bhati_(region)" title="Bhati (region)">Bhati</a> region of eastern Bengal continued to be ruled by aristocrats of the former Bengal Sultanate led by <a href="/wiki/Isa_Khan" title="Isa Khan">Isa Khan</a>. They formed an independent federation called the <a href="/wiki/Baro-Bhuyan" title="Baro-Bhuyan">Twelve Bhuiyans</a>, with their capital in Sonargaon. They defeated the Mughals in several naval battles. The Bhuiyans ultimately succumbed to the Mughals after <a href="/wiki/Musa_Khan_of_Bengal" title="Musa Khan of Bengal">Musa Khan</a> was defeated.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Bibi_Mariam.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="740" data-file-width="1024" decoding="async" height="159" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7f/Bibi_Mariam.jpg/220px-Bibi_Mariam.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7f/Bibi_Mariam.jpg/330px-Bibi_Mariam.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7f/Bibi_Mariam.jpg/440px-Bibi_Mariam.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Bibi_Mariam.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Bibi_Mariam_Cannon" title="Bibi Mariam Cannon">Bibi Mariam Cannon</a> (Lady Mary Cannon) was used by the <a href="/wiki/Mughal_Empire" title="Mughal Empire">Mughals</a> to defend their bases.</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Lalbagh_fort.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2597" data-file-width="3854" decoding="async" height="148" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d2/Lalbagh_fort.jpg/220px-Lalbagh_fort.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d2/Lalbagh_fort.jpg/330px-Lalbagh_fort.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d2/Lalbagh_fort.jpg/440px-Lalbagh_fort.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Lalbagh_fort.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Lalbagh_Fort" title="Lalbagh Fort">Lalbagh Fort</a> was the residence of the Mughal viceroy <a href="/wiki/Shaista_Khan" title="Shaista Khan">Shaista Khan</a>.</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Asiatic_Society_Heritage_Museum.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3559" data-file-width="5450" decoding="async" height="144" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/da/Asiatic_Society_Heritage_Museum.jpg/220px-Asiatic_Society_Heritage_Museum.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/da/Asiatic_Society_Heritage_Museum.jpg/330px-Asiatic_Society_Heritage_Museum.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/da/Asiatic_Society_Heritage_Museum.jpg/440px-Asiatic_Society_Heritage_Museum.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Asiatic_Society_Heritage_Museum.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Nimtali_arch" title="Nimtali arch">Nimtali arch</a> was the entrance to the palace of the <a href="/wiki/Naib_Nazim_of_Dhaka" title="Naib Nazim of Dhaka">Naib Nazim of Dhaka</a> who governed Dhaka, Chittagong and Comilla under the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nawabs_of_Bengal" title="Nawabs of Bengal">Nawabs of Bengal</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Mughal_Empire" title="Mughal Empire">Mughal Empire</a> controlled Bengal by the 17th century. During the reign of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Emperor_Akbar" title="Emperor Akbar">Emperor Akbar</a>, the Bengali agrarian calendar was reformed to facilitate tax collection. The Mughals established Dhaka as a fort city and commercial metropolis, and it was the capital of <a href="/wiki/Bengal_Subah" title="Bengal Subah">Bengal Subah</a> for 75 years.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-77"><a href="#cite_note-77">[77]</a></sup> In 1666, the Mughals expelled the <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Mrauk_U" title="Kingdom of Mrauk U">Arakanese</a> from Chittagong. Mughal Bengal attracted foreign traders for its <a href="/wiki/Muslin" title="Muslin">muslin</a> and silk goods, and the <a href="/wiki/Armenians_in_Bangladesh" title="Armenians in Bangladesh">Armenians</a> were a notable merchant community. A <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_settlement_in_Chittagong" title="Portuguese settlement in Chittagong">Portuguese settlement in Chittagong</a> flourished in the southeast, and a <a href="/wiki/Dutch_settlement_in_Rajshahi" title="Dutch settlement in Rajshahi">Dutch settlement in Rajshahi</a> existed in the north. Bengal accounted for 40% of overall <a href="/wiki/Dutch_East_India_Company" title="Dutch East India Company">Dutch</a> imports from Asia; including more than 50% of textiles and around 80% of silks.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Prakash_78-0"><a href="#cite_note-Prakash-78">[78]</a></sup> The Bengal Subah, described as the <i>Paradise of the Nations</i>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-paradise_79-0"><a href="#cite_note-paradise-79">[79]</a></sup> was the empire's wealthiest province, and a major global exporter,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Prakash_78-1"><a href="#cite_note-Prakash-78">[78]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-richards95_80-0"><a href="#cite_note-richards95-80">[80]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-riello_81-0"><a href="#cite_note-riello-81">[81]</a></sup> a notable centre of worldwide industries such as <a href="/wiki/Muslin_trade_in_Bengal" title="Muslin trade in Bengal">muslin</a>, cotton textiles, silk,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-google5_38-4"><a href="#cite_note-google5-38">[38]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Shipbuilding_in_Bangladesh" title="Shipbuilding in Bangladesh">shipbuilding</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ray174_82-0"><a href="#cite_note-ray174-82">[82]</a></sup> Its citizens also enjoyed one of the world's most superior <a href="/wiki/Standard_of_living" title="Standard of living">living standards</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-harrison_83-0"><a href="#cite_note-harrison-83">[83]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-auto_84-0"><a href="#cite_note-auto-84">[84]</a></sup>
</p><p>During the 18th century, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nawabs_of_Bengal" title="Nawabs of Bengal">Nawabs of Bengal</a> became the region's <i>de facto</i> rulers. The ruler's title is popularly known as the <i>Nawab of Bengal, Bihar, and Orissa</i>, given that the Bengali Nawab's realm encompassed much of the eastern subcontinent. The Nawabs forged alliances with European colonial companies, making the region relatively prosperous early in the century. Bengal accounted for 50% of the gross domestic product of the empire. The Bengali economy relied on <a href="/wiki/Textile_manufacturing" title="Textile manufacturing">textile manufacturing</a>, shipbuilding, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Saltpetre" title="Saltpetre">saltpetre</a> production, craftsmanship, and agricultural produce. Bengal was a major hub for international trade – silk and cotton textiles from Bengal were worn in Europe, Japan, Indonesia, and Central Asia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-85"><a href="#cite_note-85">[85]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-google5_38-5"><a href="#cite_note-google5-38">[38]</a></sup> Annual Bengali shipbuilding output was 223,250 tons, compared to an output of 23,061 tons in the nineteen colonies of North America. Bengali shipbuilding proved to be more advanced than European shipbuilding before the Industrial Revolution. The <a href="/wiki/Flush_deck" title="Flush deck">flush deck</a> of Bengali rice ships was later replicated in European shipbuilding to replace the stepped deck design for ship <a href="/wiki/Hull_(watercraft)" title="Hull (watercraft)">hulls</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-auto_84-1"><a href="#cite_note-auto-84">[84]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-star_86-0"><a href="#cite_note-star-86">[86]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-books.google.com_87-0"><a href="#cite_note-books.google.com-87">[87]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Prakash_1450,_pp._237_15-1"><a href="#cite_note-Prakash_1450,_pp._237-15">[15]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-88"><a href="#cite_note-88">[88]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-89"><a href="#cite_note-89">[89]</a></sup>
</p><p>Eastern Bengal was a thriving <a href="/wiki/Melting_pot" title="Melting pot">melting pot</a> with strong trade and cultural networks. It was a relatively prosperous part of the subcontinent and the center of the Muslim population in the eastern subcontinent.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-star_86-1"><a href="#cite_note-star-86">[86]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-90"><a href="#cite_note-90">[90]</a></sup> The Muslims of eastern Bengal included people of diverse origins from different parts of the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-91"><a href="#cite_note-91">[91]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bengali_Muslim" title="Bengali Muslim">Bengali Muslim</a> population was a product of conversion and religious evolution,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-google5_38-6"><a href="#cite_note-google5-38">[38]</a></sup> and their pre-Islamic beliefs included elements of Buddhism and Hinduism. The construction of mosques, Islamic academies (madrasas) and Sufi monasteries (<a href="/wiki/Khanqah" title="Khanqah">khanqahs</a>) facilitated conversion, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Islamic_cosmology" title="Islamic cosmology">Islamic cosmology</a> played a significant role in developing Bengali Muslim society. Scholars have theorised that Bengalis were attracted to Islam by its egalitarian social order, which contrasted with the Hindu caste system.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Roy1999_92-0"><a href="#cite_note-Roy1999-92">[92]</a></sup> By the 15th century, Muslim poets were widely writing in the Bengali language. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Syncretic" title="Syncretic">Syncretic</a> cults, such as the <a href="/wiki/Baul" title="Baul">Baul</a> movement, emerged on the fringes of Bengali Muslim society. The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Persianate" title="Persianate">Persianate</a> culture was significant in Bengal, where cities like <a href="/wiki/Sonargaon" title="Sonargaon">Sonargaon</a> became the easternmost centres of Persian influence.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-93"><a href="#cite_note-93">[93]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-94"><a href="#cite_note-94">[94]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1756, nawab <a href="/wiki/Siraj_ud-Daulah" title="Siraj ud-Daulah">Siraj ud-Daulah</a> sought to rein in the rising power of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/British_East_India_Company" title="British East India Company">British East India Company</a> by revoking their free trade rights and demanding the dismantling of their fortification in Calcutta. A military conflict ensued which culminated in the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Plassey" title="Battle of Plassey">Battle of Plassey</a> on 22 June 1757.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-95"><a href="#cite_note-95">[95]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Robert_Clive" title="Robert Clive">Robert Clive</a> exploited rivalries within the nawab's family, bribing <a href="/wiki/Mir_Jafar" title="Mir Jafar">Mir Jafar</a>, the nawab's uncle and commander in chief, to ensure Siraj-ud-Daula's defeat.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-96"><a href="#cite_note-96">[96]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Avari2013p137_97-0"><a href="#cite_note-Avari2013p137-97">[97]</a></sup> Clive rewarded Mir Jafar by making him nawab in place of Siraj-ud-Daula, but henceforth the position was a figurehead appointed and controlled by the company.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-98"><a href="#cite_note-98">[98]</a></sup> After Plassey, the Mughal emperor ruled Bengal in name only.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Lewis2011p48_99-0"><a href="#cite_note-Lewis2011p48-99">[99]</a></sup> Effective power rested with the company. Historians often describe the battle as "the beginning of British colonial rule in South Asia".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-100"><a href="#cite_note-100">[100]</a></sup> Historian Willem van Schendel describes it as "The beginning of empire" for Britain.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-vanSchendel2009p56_101-0"><a href="#cite_note-vanSchendel2009p56-101">[101]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Company replaced Mir Jafar with his son-in-law, Mir Kasim, in 1760. Mir Kasim challenged British control by allying with Mughal emperor <a href="/wiki/Shah_Alam_II" title="Shah Alam II">Shah Alam II</a> and the Nawab of Awadh, Shuja ud-Daulah, but the company decisively defeated the three at the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Buxar" title="Battle of Buxar">Battle of Buxar</a> on 23 October 1764.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Avari2013p137_97-1"><a href="#cite_note-Avari2013p137-97">[97]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Lewis2011p48_99-1"><a href="#cite_note-Lewis2011p48-99">[99]</a></sup> The resulting treaty made the Mughal emperor a puppet of the British and gave the company the right to collect taxes (<i><a href="/wiki/Dewan" title="Dewan">diwani</a></i>) in Bengal, Bihar, and Orissa, giving them de facto control of the region.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Lewis2011p48_99-2"><a href="#cite_note-Lewis2011p48-99">[99]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-vanSchendel2009p56_101-1"><a href="#cite_note-vanSchendel2009p56-101">[101]</a></sup> The Company used Bengal's tax revenue to conquer the rest of India.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-vanSchendel2009p56_101-2"><a href="#cite_note-vanSchendel2009p56-101">[101]</a></sup> By 1857, the Company controlled over 60% of the subcontinent directly, and exercised indirect rule over the remainder.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-102"><a href="#cite_note-102">[102]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Colonial_period">Colonial period</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Bengal_Presidency" title="Bengal Presidency">Bengal Presidency</a> and <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Bengal_and_Assam" title="Eastern Bengal and Assam">Eastern Bengal and Assam</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Jesuits_at_Akbar%27s_court.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="4123" data-file-width="2275" decoding="async" height="399" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/Jesuits_at_Akbar%27s_court.jpg/220px-Jesuits_at_Akbar%27s_court.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/Jesuits_at_Akbar%27s_court.jpg/330px-Jesuits_at_Akbar%27s_court.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/Jesuits_at_Akbar%27s_court.jpg/440px-Jesuits_at_Akbar%27s_court.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Jesuits_at_Akbar%27s_court.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Portuguese envoys (top left) at the imperial court of emperor <a href="/wiki/Akbar" title="Akbar">Akbar</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_settlement_in_Chittagong" title="Portuguese settlement in Chittagong">Portuguese settlement in Chittagong</a> flourished until the Mughals expelled the Portuguese in 1666.</div></div></div>
<p>Two decades after <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Vasco_Da_Gama" title="Vasco Da Gama">Vasco Da Gama</a>'s landing in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Calicut" title="Calicut">Calicut</a>, the Bengal Sultanate permitted the <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_Empire" title="Portuguese Empire">Portuguese</a> settlement in Chittagong to be established in 1528. It became the first European colonial enclave in Bengal. The Bengal Sultanate lost control of Chittagong in 1531 after Arakan declared independence and the established Kingdom of Mrauk U.
</p><p>Portuguese ships from Goa and <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_Malacca" title="Portuguese Malacca">Malacca</a> began frequenting the port city in the 16th century. The <i><a href="/wiki/Cartaz" title="Cartaz">cartaz</a></i> system was introduced and required all ships in the area to purchase naval trading licenses from the Portuguese settlement. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Slave_trade" title="Slave trade">Slave trade</a> and piracy flourished. The nearby island of <a href="/wiki/Sandwip" title="Sandwip">Sandwip</a> was conquered in 1602. In 1615, the <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_Navy" title="Portuguese Navy">Portuguese Navy</a> defeated a joint <a href="/wiki/Dutch_East_India_Company" title="Dutch East India Company">Dutch East India Company</a> and Arakanese fleet near the coast of Chittagong.
</p><p>The Bengal Sultan after 1534 allowed the Portuguese to create several settlements at Chitagoong, Satgaon,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-103"><a href="#cite_note-103">[103]</a></sup> Hughli, Bandel, and Dhaka. In 1535, the Portuguese allied with the Bengal sultan and held the Teliagarhi pass 280 kilometres (170 mi) from <a href="/wiki/Patna" title="Patna">Patna</a> helping to avoid the invasion by the Mughals. By then several of the products came from Patna and the Portuguese send in traders, establishing a factory there since 1580.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-104"><a href="#cite_note-104">[104]</a></sup>
</p><p>By the time the Portuguese assured military help against Sher Shah, the Mughals already had started to conquer the Sultanate of Ghiyasuddin Mahmud.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-105"><a href="#cite_note-105">[105]</a></sup>
</p><p>Bengal was the wealthiest region in the Indian subcontinent, and its <a href="/wiki/Proto-industrialization" title="Proto-industrialization">proto-industrial</a> economy showed signs of driving an <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Industrial_revolution" title="Industrial revolution">Industrial revolution</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-voss_106-0"><a href="#cite_note-voss-106">[106]</a></sup>
</p><p>The region has been described as the "Paradise of Nations",<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-107"><a href="#cite_note-107">[107]</a></sup> and its inhabitants's <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Standards_of_living" title="Standards of living">living standards</a> and <a href="/wiki/Real_wages" title="Real wages">real wages</a> were among the highest in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-108"><a href="#cite_note-108">[108]</a></sup> It alone accounted for 40% of <a href="/wiki/Dutch_East_India_Company" title="Dutch East India Company">Dutch imports</a> outside the <a href="/wiki/Europe" title="Europe">European</a> continent.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Prakash_78-2"><a href="#cite_note-Prakash-78">[78]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-star_86-2"><a href="#cite_note-star-86">[86]</a></sup> The eastern part of Bengal was globally prominent in industries such as <a href="/wiki/Textile_manufacturing" title="Textile manufacturing">textile manufacturing</a> and <a href="/wiki/Shipbuilding" title="Shipbuilding">shipbuilding</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ray_109-0"><a href="#cite_note-ray-109">[109]</a></sup> and it was a major exporter of <a href="/wiki/Silk" title="Silk">silk</a> and <a href="/wiki/Cotton" title="Cotton">cotton</a> <a href="/wiki/Textile" title="Textile">textiles</a>, <a href="/wiki/Steel" title="Steel">steel</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Saltpeter" title="Saltpeter">saltpeter</a>, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Agricultural" title="Agricultural">agricultural</a> and industrial produce in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-star_86-3"><a href="#cite_note-star-86">[86]</a></sup>
In 1666, the Mughal government of Bengal led by viceroy <a href="/wiki/Shaista_Khan" title="Shaista Khan">Shaista Khan</a> moved to retake Chittagong from Portuguese and Arakanese control. The <a href="/wiki/Anglo-Mughal_War" title="Anglo-Mughal War">Anglo-Mughal War</a> was witnessed in 1686.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-110"><a href="#cite_note-110">[110]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-111"><a href="#cite_note-111">[111]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:302px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Clive.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1870" data-file-width="2400" decoding="async" height="234" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4f/Clive.jpg/300px-Clive.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4f/Clive.jpg/450px-Clive.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4f/Clive.jpg/600px-Clive.jpg 2x" width="300"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Clive.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Lord_Clive" title="Lord Clive">Lord Clive</a> meeting with <a href="/wiki/Mir_Jafar" title="Mir Jafar">Mir Jafar</a> after the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Plassey" title="Battle of Plassey">Battle of Plassey</a>, which led to the overthrow of the last independent <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nawab_of_Bengal" title="Nawab of Bengal">Nawab of Bengal</a></div></div></div>
<p>After the 1757 <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Plassey" title="Battle of Plassey">Battle of Plassey</a>, Bengal was the first region of the Indian subcontinent conquered by the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/British_East_India_Company" title="British East India Company">British East India Company</a>. The company formed the <a href="/wiki/Bengal_Presidency" title="Bengal Presidency">Presidency of Fort William</a>, which administered the region until 1858. A notable aspect of <a href="/wiki/Company_rule_in_India" title="Company rule in India">Company rule</a> was the <a href="/wiki/Permanent_Settlement" title="Permanent Settlement">Permanent Settlement</a>, which established the feudal <a href="/wiki/Zamindar" title="Zamindar">zamindari</a> system; in addition, Company policies led to the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Deindustrialisation" title="Deindustrialisation">deindustrialisation</a> of Bengal's textile industry.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-112"><a href="#cite_note-112">[112]</a></sup> The capital amassed by the East India Company in Bengal was invested in the emerging <a href="/wiki/Industrial_Revolution" title="Industrial Revolution">Industrial Revolution</a> in <a href="/wiki/United_Kingdom_of_Great_Britain_and_Ireland" title="United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland">Great Britain</a>, in industries such as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Textile_manufacture_during_the_Industrial_Revolution" title="Textile manufacture during the Industrial Revolution">textile manufacturing</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-113"><a href="#cite_note-113">[113]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-sengupta_114-0"><a href="#cite_note-sengupta-114">[114]</a></sup> Economic mismanagement, alongside drought and a smallpox epidemic, directly led to the <a href="/wiki/Great_Bengal_famine_of_1770" title="Great Bengal famine of 1770">Great Bengal famine of 1770</a>, which is estimated to have caused the deaths of between 1 million and 10 million people.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Roy2019_115-0"><a href="#cite_note-Roy2019-115">[115]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-116"><a href="#cite_note-116">[116]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-117"><a href="#cite_note-117">[117]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Jonsson2013p167_118-0"><a href="#cite_note-Jonsson2013p167-118">[118]</a></sup> Several rebellions broke out during the early 19th century (including one led by <a href="/wiki/Titumir" title="Titumir">Titumir</a>), as Company rule had displaced the Muslim ruling class from power. A conservative Islamic cleric, <a href="/wiki/Haji_Shariatullah" title="Haji Shariatullah">Haji Shariatullah</a>, sought to overthrow the British by propagating Islamic revivalism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-119"><a href="#cite_note-119">[119]</a></sup> Several towns in Bangladesh participated in the <a href="/wiki/Indian_Rebellion_of_1857" title="Indian Rebellion of 1857">Indian Rebellion of 1857</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-120"><a href="#cite_note-120">[120]</a></sup> and pledged allegiance to the last Mughal emperor, <a href="/wiki/Bahadur_Shah_Zafar" title="Bahadur Shah Zafar">Bahadur Shah Zafar</a>, who was later exiled to neighbouring Burma.
</p><p>The challenge posed to company rule by the failed Indian Mutiny led to the creation of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/British_Indian_Empire" title="British Indian Empire">British Indian Empire</a> as a <a href="/wiki/Crown_colony" title="Crown colony">crown colony</a>. The British established several schools, colleges, and a university in Bangladesh. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Syed_Ahmed_Khan" title="Syed Ahmed Khan">Syed Ahmed Khan</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ram_Mohan_Roy" title="Ram Mohan Roy">Ram Mohan Roy</a> promoted modern and <a href="/wiki/Liberal_education" title="Liberal education">liberal education</a> in the subcontinent, inspiring the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Aligarh_movement" title="Aligarh movement">Aligarh movement</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-121"><a href="#cite_note-121">[121]</a></sup> and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bengal_Renaissance" title="Bengal Renaissance">Bengal Renaissance</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-122"><a href="#cite_note-122">[122]</a></sup> During the late 19th century, novelists, social reformers and feminists emerged from Muslim Bengali society. <a href="/wiki/Electricity" title="Electricity">Electricity</a> and municipal water systems were introduced in the 1890s; <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Movie_theatre" title="Movie theatre">cinemas</a> opened in many towns during the early 20th century. East Bengal's <a href="/wiki/Plantation_economy" title="Plantation economy">plantation economy</a> was important to the British Empire, particularly its <a href="/wiki/Jute" title="Jute">jute</a> and <a href="/wiki/Tea_production_in_Bangladesh" title="Tea production in Bangladesh">tea</a>. The British established <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Free_port" title="Free port">tax-free river ports</a>, such as the <a href="/wiki/Port_of_Narayanganj" title="Port of Narayanganj">Port of Narayanganj</a>, and large seaports like the <a href="/wiki/Port_of_Chittagong" title="Port of Chittagong">Port of Chittagong</a>.
</p><p>Bengal had the highest gross domestic product in British India.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-daily-sun.com_123-0"><a href="#cite_note-daily-sun.com-123">[123]</a></sup> Bengal was one of the first regions in Asia to have a railway. The first railway in what is now Bangladesh began operating in 1862.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-124"><a href="#cite_note-124">[124]</a></sup> In comparison, <a href="/wiki/Japan" title="Japan">Japan</a> saw its first railway in 1872. The main railway companies in the region were the <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Bengal_Railway" title="Eastern Bengal Railway">Eastern Bengal Railway</a> and <a href="/wiki/Assam_Bengal_Railway" title="Assam Bengal Railway">Assam Bengal Railway</a>. Railways competed with waterborne transport to become one of the main mediums of transport.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-125"><a href="#cite_note-125">[125]</a></sup>
</p><p>Supported by the Muslim aristocracy, the British government created the province of <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Bengal_and_Assam" title="Eastern Bengal and Assam">Eastern Bengal and Assam</a> in 1905; the new province received increased investment in education, transport, and industry.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-126"><a href="#cite_note-126">[126]</a></sup> However, the <a href="/wiki/Partition_of_Bengal_(1905)" title="Partition of Bengal (1905)">first partition of Bengal</a> created an uproar in <a href="/wiki/Kolkata" title="Kolkata">Calcutta</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Indian_National_Congress" title="Indian National Congress">Indian National Congress</a>. In response to growing Hindu nationalism, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/All_India_Muslim_League" title="All India Muslim League">All India Muslim League</a> was formed in Dhaka during the 1906 All India Muhammadan Educational Conference. The British government reorganised the provinces in 1912, reuniting East and West Bengal and making <a href="/wiki/Assam_Province" title="Assam Province">Assam</a> a second province.
</p><p>The Raj was slow to allow self-rule in the colonial subcontinent. It established the <a href="/wiki/Bengal_Legislative_Council" title="Bengal Legislative Council">Bengal Legislative Council</a> in 1862, and the council's native Bengali representation increased during the early 20th century. The <a href="/wiki/Bengal_Provincial_Muslim_League" title="Bengal Provincial Muslim League">Bengal Provincial Muslim League</a> was formed in 1913 to advocate <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Civil_rights" title="Civil rights">civil rights</a> for Bengali Muslims within a constitutional framework. During the 1920s, the league was divided into factions supporting the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Khilafat_movement" title="Khilafat movement">Khilafat movement</a> and favouring co-operation with the British to achieve self-rule.
