Segments of the Bengali elite supported <a href="/wiki/Mustafa_Kemal_Atat%C3%BCrk" title="Mustafa Kemal Atatürk">Mustafa Kemal Atatürk</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Secularism_in_Turkey" title="Secularism in Turkey">secularist</a> forces.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-127"><a href="#cite_note-127">[127]</a></sup> In 1929, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Praja_Party" title="Praja Party">All Bengal Tenants Association</a> was formed in the Bengal Legislative Council to counter the influence of the Hindu landed gentry, and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Indian_Independence_Movement" title="Indian Independence Movement">Indian Independence</a> and <a href="/wiki/Pakistan_Movement" title="Pakistan Movement">Pakistan Movements</a> strengthened during the early 20th century. After the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Morley-Minto_Reforms" title="Morley-Minto Reforms">Morley-Minto Reforms</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Government_of_India_Act_1919" title="Government of India Act 1919">diarchy</a> era in the <a href="/wiki/Legislatures_of_British_India" title="Legislatures of British India">legislatures of British India</a>, the British government promised <a href="/wiki/Government_of_India_Act_1935" title="Government of India Act 1935">limited provincial autonomy</a> in 1935. The <a href="/wiki/Bengal_Legislative_Assembly" title="Bengal Legislative Assembly">Bengal Legislative Assembly</a>, British India's largest legislature, was established in 1937.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:342px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:All_India_Muslim_league_conference_1906_attendees_in_Dhaka.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="257" data-file-width="800" decoding="async" height="109" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/74/All_India_Muslim_league_conference_1906_attendees_in_Dhaka.jpg/340px-All_India_Muslim_league_conference_1906_attendees_in_Dhaka.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/74/All_India_Muslim_league_conference_1906_attendees_in_Dhaka.jpg/510px-All_India_Muslim_league_conference_1906_attendees_in_Dhaka.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/74/All_India_Muslim_league_conference_1906_attendees_in_Dhaka.jpg/680px-All_India_Muslim_league_conference_1906_attendees_in_Dhaka.jpg 2x" width="340"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:All_India_Muslim_league_conference_1906_attendees_in_Dhaka.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Founding conference of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/All_India_Muslim_League" title="All India Muslim League">All India Muslim League</a> in Dhaka, 1906</div></div></div>
<p>Although it won most seats in 1937, the Bengal Congress boycotted the legislature. <a href="/wiki/A._K._Fazlul_Huq" title="A. K. Fazlul Huq">A. K. Fazlul Huq</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Krishak_Sramik_Party" title="Krishak Sramik Party">Krishak Praja Party</a> was elected as the first <a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Bengal" title="Prime Minister of Bengal">Prime Minister of Bengal</a>. In 1940 Huq supported the <a href="/wiki/Lahore_Resolution" title="Lahore Resolution">Lahore Resolution</a>, which envisaged independent states in the subcontinent's northwestern and eastern Muslim-majority regions. The first Huq ministry, a coalition with the Bengal Provincial Muslim League, lasted until 1941; it was followed by a Huq coalition with the <a href="/wiki/Hindu_Mahasabha" title="Hindu Mahasabha">Hindu Mahasabha</a> which lasted until 1943. Huq was succeeded by <a href="/wiki/Khawaja_Nazimuddin" title="Khawaja Nazimuddin">Khawaja Nazimuddin</a>, who grappled with the effects of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Burma_Campaign" title="Burma Campaign">Burma Campaign</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Bengal_famine_of_1943" title="Bengal famine of 1943">Bengal famine of 1943</a>, which killed up to 3 million people,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-128"><a href="#cite_note-128">[128]</a></sup> and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Quit_India" title="Quit India">Quit India</a> movement. In 1946, the Bengal Provincial Muslim League won the provincial election, taking 113 of the 250-seat assembly (the largest Muslim League mandate in British India). <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/H._S._Suhrawardy" title="H. S. Suhrawardy">H. S. Suhrawardy</a>, who made a final futile effort for a <a href="/wiki/United_Bengal" title="United Bengal">United Bengal</a> in 1946, was the last premier of Bengal.
</p>
<h3><span id="Partition_of_Bengal_.281947.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Partition_of_Bengal_(1947)">Partition of Bengal (1947)</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Partition_of_Bengal_(1947)" title="Partition of Bengal (1947)">Partition of Bengal (1947)</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><audio class="thumbimage" controls="" data-durationhint="248" data-mwprovider="wikimediacommons" data-mwtitle="Suhrawardy_interview_on_Partition_of_India.oga" id="mwe_player_1" preload="none" style="width:220px;" width="220"><source data-bandwidth="93792" data-height="0" data-shorttitle="Ogg Vorbis" data-title="Ogg Vorbis" data-transcodekey="ogg" data-width="0" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/b/b9/Suhrawardy_interview_on_Partition_of_India.oga/Suhrawardy_interview_on_Partition_of_India.oga.ogg" type='audio/ogg; codecs="vorbis"'/><source data-bandwidth="194744" data-height="0" data-shorttitle="MP3" data-title="MP3" data-transcodekey="mp3" data-width="0" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/b/b9/Suhrawardy_interview_on_Partition_of_India.oga/Suhrawardy_interview_on_Partition_of_India.oga.mp3" type="audio/mpeg"/><source data-bandwidth="1236641" data-height="0" data-shorttitle="Ogg source" data-title="Original Ogg file (1.24 Mbps)" data-width="0" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/b/b9/Suhrawardy_interview_on_Partition_of_India.oga" type='audio/ogg; codecs="flac"'/></audio> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Suhrawardy_interview_on_Partition_of_India.oga" title="Enlarge"></a></div>British Bengal's last premier <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/H._S._Suhrawardy" title="H. S. Suhrawardy">H. S. Suhrawardy</a> speaking about partition</div></div></div>
<p>On 3 June 1947, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mountbatten_Plan" title="Mountbatten Plan">Mountbatten Plan</a> outlined the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Partition_of_British_India" title="Partition of British India">partition of British India</a>. On 20 June, the Bengal Legislative Assembly met to decide on the partition of Bengal. At the preliminary joint meeting, it was decided (120 votes to 90) that if the province remained united, it should join the <a href="/wiki/Constituent_Assembly_of_Pakistan" title="Constituent Assembly of Pakistan">Constituent Assembly of Pakistan</a>. At a separate meeting of legislators from <a href="/wiki/West_Bengal" title="West Bengal">West Bengal</a>, it was decided (58 votes to 21) that the province should be partitioned and West Bengal should join the <a href="/wiki/Constituent_Assembly_of_India" title="Constituent Assembly of India">Constituent Assembly of India</a>. At another meeting of legislators from <a href="/wiki/East_Bengal" title="East Bengal">East Bengal</a>, it was decided (106 votes to 35) that the province should not be partitioned and (107 votes to 34) that East Bengal should join the Constituent Assembly of <a href="/wiki/Pakistan" title="Pakistan">Pakistan</a> if Bengal was partitioned.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Mukherjee1987_129-0"><a href="#cite_note-Mukherjee1987-129">[129]</a></sup> On 6 July, the <a href="/wiki/Sylhet_Division" title="Sylhet Division">Sylhet region</a> of Assam voted in a <a href="/wiki/1947_Sylhet_referendum" title="1947 Sylhet referendum">referendum to join East Bengal</a>.
<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cyril_Radcliffe" title="Cyril Radcliffe">Cyril Radcliffe</a> was tasked with drawing the borders of Pakistan and India, and the <a href="/wiki/Radcliffe_Line" title="Radcliffe Line">Radcliffe Line</a> established the borders of present-day Bangladesh. The Radcliffe Line awarded two-thirds of Bengal as the eastern wing of Pakistan, although the medieval and early modern Bengali capitals of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gauda_(city)" title="Gauda (city)">Gaur</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pandua,_Malda" title="Pandua, Malda">Pandua</a> and <a href="/wiki/Murshidabad" title="Murshidabad">Murshidabad</a> fell on the Indian side close to the border with Pakistan.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Union_with_Pakistan">Union with Pakistan</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/East_Bengal" title="East Bengal">East Bengal</a> and <a href="/wiki/East_Pakistan" title="East Pakistan">East Pakistan</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Dominion_of_Pakistan_%26_Indian_Controlled_Kashmir_(orthographic_projection).svg"><img alt="Map of the world, with Pakistan in 1947 highlighted" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="541" data-file-width="541" decoding="async" height="220" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/52/Dominion_of_Pakistan_%26_Indian_Controlled_Kashmir_%28orthographic_projection%29.svg/220px-Dominion_of_Pakistan_%26_Indian_Controlled_Kashmir_%28orthographic_projection%29.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/52/Dominion_of_Pakistan_%26_Indian_Controlled_Kashmir_%28orthographic_projection%29.svg/330px-Dominion_of_Pakistan_%26_Indian_Controlled_Kashmir_%28orthographic_projection%29.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/52/Dominion_of_Pakistan_%26_Indian_Controlled_Kashmir_%28orthographic_projection%29.svg/440px-Dominion_of_Pakistan_%26_Indian_Controlled_Kashmir_%28orthographic_projection%29.svg.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Dominion_of_Pakistan_%26_Indian_Controlled_Kashmir_(orthographic_projection).svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Dominion_of_Pakistan" title="Dominion of Pakistan">Dominion of Pakistan</a> in 1947, with <a href="/wiki/East_Bengal" title="East Bengal">East Bengal</a> its eastern part</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:21_Feb_1953_Dhaka_University_female_students_procession.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1056" data-file-width="1374" decoding="async" height="169" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/91/21_Feb_1953_Dhaka_University_female_students_procession.png/220px-21_Feb_1953_Dhaka_University_female_students_procession.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/91/21_Feb_1953_Dhaka_University_female_students_procession.png/330px-21_Feb_1953_Dhaka_University_female_students_procession.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/91/21_Feb_1953_Dhaka_University_female_students_procession.png/440px-21_Feb_1953_Dhaka_University_female_students_procession.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:21_Feb_1953_Dhaka_University_female_students_procession.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Women students of Dhaka University marching in defiance of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Section_144" title="Section 144">Section 144</a> prohibition on assembly during the Bengali Language Movement in early 1953</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Mujib_in_Harvard.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="728" data-file-width="1254" decoding="async" height="128" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Mujib_in_Harvard.jpg/220px-Mujib_in_Harvard.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Mujib_in_Harvard.jpg/330px-Mujib_in_Harvard.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Mujib_in_Harvard.jpg/440px-Mujib_in_Harvard.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Mujib_in_Harvard.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Sheikh_Mujibur_Rahman" title="Sheikh Mujibur Rahman">Sheikh Mujibur Rahman</a> (left) and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Munier_Chowdhury" title="Munier Chowdhury">Munier Chowdhury</a> (centre) visiting Matiul Islam (right), an East Bengali student at Harvard during the late 1950s</div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Dominion_of_Pakistan" title="Dominion of Pakistan">Dominion of Pakistan</a> was created on 14 August 1947. East Bengal, with Dhaka as its capital, was the most populous province of the 1947 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/State_of_Pakistan" title="State of Pakistan">Pakistani federation</a> (led by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Governor_General_of_Pakistan" title="Governor General of Pakistan">Governor General</a> <a href="/wiki/Muhammad_Ali_Jinnah" title="Muhammad Ali Jinnah">Muhammad Ali Jinnah</a>, who promised freedom of religion and secular democracy in the new state).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ispahani2017_130-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ispahani2017-130">[130]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Saikia2011_131-0"><a href="#cite_note-Saikia2011-131">[131]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Khawaja_Nazimuddin" title="Khawaja Nazimuddin">Khawaja Nazimuddin</a> was East Bengal's first <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chief_Minister_of_East_Bengal" title="Chief Minister of East Bengal">chief minister</a> with <a href="/wiki/Frederick_Chalmers_Bourne" title="Frederick Chalmers Bourne">Frederick Chalmers Bourne</a> its governor. The <a href="/wiki/All_Pakistan_Awami_Muslim_League" title="All Pakistan Awami Muslim League">All Pakistan Awami Muslim League</a> was formed in 1949. In 1950, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/East_Bengal_Legislative_Assembly" title="East Bengal Legislative Assembly">East Bengal Legislative Assembly</a> enacted <a href="/wiki/Land_reform" title="Land reform">land reform</a>, abolishing the Permanent Settlement and the <a href="/wiki/Zamindar" title="Zamindar">zamindari</a> system.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-132"><a href="#cite_note-132">[132]</a></sup> The 1952 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bengali_Language_Movement" title="Bengali Language Movement">Bengali Language Movement</a> was the first sign of friction between the country's geographically separated wings. The Awami Muslim League was renamed the more-secular <a href="/wiki/Awami_League" title="Awami League">Awami League</a> in 1953.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-LewisSagar1992_133-0"><a href="#cite_note-LewisSagar1992-133">[133]</a></sup> The first constituent assembly was dissolved in 1954; this was challenged by its East Bengali speaker, <a href="/wiki/Maulvi_Tamizuddin_Khan" title="Maulvi Tamizuddin Khan">Maulvi Tamizuddin Khan</a>. The <a href="/wiki/United_Front_(East_Pakistan)" title="United Front (East Pakistan)">United Front</a> coalition swept aside the Muslim League in a landslide victory in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/1954_East_Bengali_legislative_election" title="1954 East Bengali legislative election">1954 East Bengali legislative election</a>. The following year, East Bengal was renamed East Pakistan as part of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/One_Unit" title="One Unit">One Unit</a> program, and the province became a vital part of the <a href="/wiki/Southeast_Asia_Treaty_Organization" title="Southeast Asia Treaty Organization">Southeast Asia Treaty Organization</a>.
</p><p>Pakistan adopted a new constitution in 1956. Three Bengalis were its Prime Minister until 1957: Nazimuddin, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mohammad_Ali_of_Bogra" title="Mohammad Ali of Bogra">Mohammad Ali of Bogra</a> and Suhrawardy. None of the three completed their terms, and resigned from office. The <a href="/wiki/Pakistan_Army" title="Pakistan Army">Pakistan Army</a> imposed <a href="/wiki/1958_Pakistani_coup_d%27%C3%A9tat" title="1958 Pakistani coup d'état">military rule in 1958</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Ayub_Khan_(general)" title="Ayub Khan (general)">Ayub Khan</a> was the country's strongman for 11 years. Political repression increased after the coup. Khan introduced a new constitution in 1962, replacing Pakistan's parliamentary system with a presidential and gubernatorial system (based on <a href="/wiki/Electoral_college" title="Electoral college">electoral college</a> selection) known as Basic Democracy. In 1962 Dhaka became the seat of the <a href="/wiki/National_Assembly_of_Pakistan" title="National Assembly of Pakistan">National Assembly of Pakistan</a>, a move seen as appeasing increased Bengali nationalism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-134"><a href="#cite_note-134">[134]</a></sup> The Pakistani government built the controversial <a href="/wiki/Kaptai_Dam" title="Kaptai Dam">Kaptai Dam</a>, displacing the <a href="/wiki/Chakma_people" title="Chakma people">Chakma people</a> from their indigenous homeland in the <a href="/wiki/Chittagong_Hill_Tracts" title="Chittagong Hill Tracts">Chittagong Hill Tracts</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-135"><a href="#cite_note-135">[135]</a></sup> During the <a href="/wiki/1965_Pakistani_presidential_election" title="1965 Pakistani presidential election">1965 presidential election</a>, <a href="/wiki/Fatima_Jinnah" title="Fatima Jinnah">Fatima Jinnah</a> lost to Ayub Khan despite support from the Combined Opposition alliance (which included the Awami League).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ahmed2004p157_136-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ahmed2004p157-136">[136]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Indo-Pakistani_War_of_1965" title="Indo-Pakistani War of 1965">Indo-Pakistani War of 1965</a> blocked cross-border transport links with neighbouring India in what is described as a second partition.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-137"><a href="#cite_note-137">[137]</a></sup> In 1966, Awami League leader <a href="/wiki/Sheikh_Mujibur_Rahman" title="Sheikh Mujibur Rahman">Sheikh Mujibur Rahman</a> announced a <a href="/wiki/Six_point_movement" title="Six point movement">six-point movement</a> for a federal parliamentary democracy.
</p><p>According to senior <a href="/wiki/World_Bank" title="World Bank">World Bank</a> officials, the Pakistani government practised extensive <a href="/wiki/Economic_discrimination" title="Economic discrimination">economic discrimination</a> against East Pakistan: greater government spending on West Pakistan, financial transfers from East to West Pakistan, the use of East Pakistan's foreign-exchange surpluses to finance West Pakistani imports, and refusal by the central government to release funds allocated to East Pakistan because the previous spending had been under budget;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-google.co.nz_138-0"><a href="#cite_note-google.co.nz-138">[138]</a></sup> though East Pakistan generated 70 percent of Pakistan's export revenue with its jute and tea.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-139"><a href="#cite_note-139">[139]</a></sup> Sheikh Mujibur Rahman was arrested for treason in the <a href="/wiki/Agartala_Conspiracy_Case" title="Agartala Conspiracy Case">Agartala Conspiracy Case</a> and was released during the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/1969_uprising_in_East_Pakistan" title="1969 uprising in East Pakistan">1969 uprising in East Pakistan</a> which resulted in Ayub Khan's resignation. General <a href="/wiki/Yahya_Khan" title="Yahya Khan">Yahya Khan</a> assumed power, reintroducing martial law.
</p><p>Ethnic and linguistic discrimination was common in Pakistan's civil and military services, in which Bengalis were under-represented. Fifteen percent of Pakistani central-government offices were occupied by East Pakistanis, who formed 10 percent of the military.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-140"><a href="#cite_note-140">[140]</a></sup> Cultural discrimination also prevailed, making East Pakistan forge a distinct political identity.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-141"><a href="#cite_note-141">[141]</a></sup> Authorities banned Bengali literature and music in state media, including the works of Nobel laureate Rabindranath Tagore.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-142"><a href="#cite_note-142">[142]</a></sup> A <a href="/wiki/1970_Bhola_cyclone" title="1970 Bhola cyclone">cyclone</a> devastated the coast of East Pakistan in 1970, killing an estimated 500,000 people,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-143"><a href="#cite_note-143">[143]</a></sup> and the central government was criticised for its poor response.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-countrystudies.us1_144-0"><a href="#cite_note-countrystudies.us1-144">[144]</a></sup> After the December 1970 elections, calls for the independence of East Bengal became louder; the Bengali-nationalist Awami League won 167 of 169 East Pakistani seats in the National Assembly. The League claimed the right to form a government and develop a new constitution but was strongly opposed by the Pakistani military and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pakistan_Peoples_Party" title="Pakistan Peoples Party">Pakistan Peoples Party</a> (led by <a href="/wiki/Zulfikar_Ali_Bhutto" title="Zulfikar Ali Bhutto">Zulfikar Ali Bhutto</a>).
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="War_of_Independence">War of Independence</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh_Liberation_War" title="Bangladesh Liberation War">Bangladesh Liberation War</a></div>
<p>The Bengali population was angered when Prime Minister-elect <a href="/wiki/Sheikh_Mujibur_Rahman" title="Sheikh Mujibur Rahman">Sheikh Mujibur Rahman</a> was prevented from taking the office.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-145"><a href="#cite_note-145">[145]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Non-cooperation_movement_(1971)" title="Non-cooperation movement (1971)">Civil disobedience</a> erupted across East Pakistan,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-146"><a href="#cite_note-146">[146]</a></sup> with calls for independence. Mujib addressed a <a href="/wiki/7_March_Speech_of_Bangabandhu" title="7 March Speech of Bangabandhu">pro-independence rally</a> of nearly 2 million people in Dacca (as Dhaka used to be spelled in English) on 7 March 1971, where he said, "This time the struggle is for our freedom. This time the struggle is for our independence."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-147"><a href="#cite_note-147">[147]</a></sup> The flag of Bangladesh was raised for the first time on 23 March, Pakistan's Republic Day.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-148"><a href="#cite_note-148">[148]</a></sup> Later, on 25 March late evening, the Pakistani military junta led by <a href="/wiki/Yahya_Khan" title="Yahya Khan">Yahya Khan</a> launched a sustained military assault on East Pakistan under the code name of <a href="/wiki/Operation_Searchlight" title="Operation Searchlight">Operation Searchlight</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-149"><a href="#cite_note-149">[149]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-150"><a href="#cite_note-150">[150]</a></sup> The Pakistan Army arrested Sheikh Mujibur Rahman and flew him to Karachi.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-151"><a href="#cite_note-151">[151]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-152"><a href="#cite_note-152">[152]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-153"><a href="#cite_note-153">[153]</a></sup> However, before his arrest Mujib proclaimed the <a href="/wiki/Proclamation_of_Bangladeshi_Independence" title="Proclamation of Bangladeshi Independence">Independence of Bangladesh</a> at midnight on 26 March which led the <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh_Liberation_War" title="Bangladesh Liberation War">Bangladesh Liberation War</a> to break out within hours.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-154"><a href="#cite_note-154">[154]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-155"><a href="#cite_note-155">[155]</a></sup> The Pakistan Army and its local supporters continued to massacre Bengalis, in particular <a href="/wiki/1971_Dhaka_University_massacre" title="1971 Dhaka University massacre">students</a>, <a href="/wiki/1971_killing_of_Bengali_intellectuals" title="1971 killing of Bengali intellectuals">intellectuals</a>, political figures, and Hindus in the <a href="/wiki/1971_Bangladesh_genocide" title="1971 Bangladesh genocide">1971 Bangladesh genocide</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Mukti_Bahini" title="Mukti Bahini">Mukti Bahini</a>, a guerrilla resistance force, also violated human rights during the conflict.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-156"><a href="#cite_note-156">[156]</a></sup> During the war, an estimated 0.3 to 3.0 million people were killed and several million people took shelter in neighbouring India.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-157"><a href="#cite_note-157">[157]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:302px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Central_Rotunda_with_Light-infused_Water_Pillar_-_Museum_of_Independence_-_Suhrawardy_Udyan_-_Dhaka_2015-05-31_2177-2181.tif"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="5971" data-file-width="13650" decoding="async" height="131" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/Central_Rotunda_with_Light-infused_Water_Pillar_-_Museum_of_Independence_-_Suhrawardy_Udyan_-_Dhaka_2015-05-31_2177-2181.tif/lossy-page1-300px-Central_Rotunda_with_Light-infused_Water_Pillar_-_Museum_of_Independence_-_Suhrawardy_Udyan_-_Dhaka_2015-05-31_2177-2181.tif.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/Central_Rotunda_with_Light-infused_Water_Pillar_-_Museum_of_Independence_-_Suhrawardy_Udyan_-_Dhaka_2015-05-31_2177-2181.tif/lossy-page1-450px-Central_Rotunda_with_Light-infused_Water_Pillar_-_Museum_of_Independence_-_Suhrawardy_Udyan_-_Dhaka_2015-05-31_2177-2181.tif.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/Central_Rotunda_with_Light-infused_Water_Pillar_-_Museum_of_Independence_-_Suhrawardy_Udyan_-_Dhaka_2015-05-31_2177-2181.tif/lossy-page1-600px-Central_Rotunda_with_Light-infused_Water_Pillar_-_Museum_of_Independence_-_Suhrawardy_Udyan_-_Dhaka_2015-05-31_2177-2181.tif.jpg 2x" width="300"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Central_Rotunda_with_Light-infused_Water_Pillar_-_Museum_of_Independence_-_Suhrawardy_Udyan_-_Dhaka_2015-05-31_2177-2181.tif" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Museum_of_Independence,_Dhaka" title="Museum of Independence, Dhaka">Museum of Independence, Dhaka</a></div></div></div>
<p>Global public opinion turned against Pakistan as news of the atrocities spread;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Benvenisti2012_158-0"><a href="#cite_note-Benvenisti2012-158">[158]</a></sup> the Bangladesh movement was supported by prominent political and cultural figures in the West, including <a href="/wiki/Ted_Kennedy" title="Ted Kennedy">Ted Kennedy</a>, <a href="/wiki/George_Harrison" title="George Harrison">George Harrison</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bob_Dylan" title="Bob Dylan">Bob Dylan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Joan_Baez" title="Joan Baez">Joan Baez</a>, <a href="/wiki/Victoria_Ocampo" title="Victoria Ocampo">Victoria Ocampo</a> and <a href="/wiki/Andr%C3%A9_Malraux" title="André Malraux">André Malraux</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-159"><a href="#cite_note-159">[159]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-160"><a href="#cite_note-160">[160]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-161"><a href="#cite_note-161">[161]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/The_Concert_for_Bangladesh" title="The Concert for Bangladesh">The Concert for Bangladesh</a> was held at <a href="/wiki/Madison_Square_Garden" title="Madison Square Garden">Madison Square Garden</a> in New York City to raise funds for Bangladeshi refugees. The first major benefit concert in history, it was organised by Harrison and Indian Bengali sitarist <a href="/wiki/Ravi_Shankar" title="Ravi Shankar">Ravi Shankar</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-162"><a href="#cite_note-162">[162]</a></sup>
</p><p>During the Bangladesh Liberation War, Bengali nationalists declared independence and formed the Mukti Bahini (the Bangladeshi National Liberation Army). The <a href="/wiki/Provisional_Government_of_Bangladesh" title="Provisional Government of Bangladesh">Provisional Government of Bangladesh</a> was established on 17 April 1971, converting the 469 elected members of the Pakistani national assembly and East Pakistani provincial assembly into the <a href="/wiki/Constituent_Assembly_of_Bangladesh" title="Constituent Assembly of Bangladesh">Constituent Assembly of Bangladesh</a>. The provisional government issued a <a href="/wiki/Proclamation_of_Bangladeshi_Independence" title="Proclamation of Bangladeshi Independence">proclamation</a> that became the country's interim constitution and declared "equality, human dignity, and social justice" as its fundamental principles. Due to Mujib's detention, <a href="/wiki/Syed_Nazrul_Islam" title="Syed Nazrul Islam">Syed Nazrul Islam</a> took over the role of Acting President, while <a href="/wiki/Tajuddin_Ahmad" title="Tajuddin Ahmad">Tajuddin Ahmad</a> was named Bangladesh's first Prime Minister. The Mukti Bahini and other Bengali guerrilla forces formed the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bangladesh_Forces" title="Bangladesh Forces">Bangladesh Forces</a>, which became the military wing of the provisional government. Led by General <a href="/wiki/M._A._G._Osmani" title="M. A. G. Osmani">M. A. G. Osmani</a> and eleven <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_sectors_in_Bangladesh_Liberation_War" title="List of sectors in Bangladesh Liberation War">sector commanders</a>, the forces held the countryside during the war. They conducted wide-ranging guerrilla operations against Pakistani forces. As a result, almost the entire country except for the capital Dacca was liberated by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bangladesh_Forces" title="Bangladesh Forces">Bangladesh Forces</a> by late November.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (December 2021)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup>
</p><p>This led the Pakistan Army to attack neighbouring India's western front on 2 December 1971. India retaliated in both the western and eastern fronts. With a joint ground advance by Bangladeshi and Indian forces, coupled with air strikes by both India and the small Bangladeshi air contingent, the capital Dacca was liberated from Pakistani occupation in mid-December. During the last phase of the war, both the Soviet Union and the United States dispatched naval forces to the Bay of Bengal in a Cold War standoff. The nine month long war ended with the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Surrender_of_Pakistan" title="Surrender of Pakistan">surrender of Pakistani armed forces</a> to the Bangladesh-India Allied Forces on 16 December 1971.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-laporte_163-0"><a href="#cite_note-laporte-163">[163]</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability" title="Wikipedia:Verifiability"><span title="The material near this tag failed verification of its source citation(s). (December 2021)">failed verification</span></a></i>]</sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Rummel-8-2_164-0"><a href="#cite_note-Rummel-8-2-164">[164]</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability" title="Wikipedia:Verifiability"><span title="The material near this tag failed verification of its source citation(s). (December 2021)">failed verification</span></a></i>]</sup> Under international pressure, Pakistan released Rahman from imprisonment on 8 January 1972 and he was flown by the British Royal Air Force to a million-strong homecoming in Dacca.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-165"><a href="#cite_note-165">[165]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-166"><a href="#cite_note-166">[166]</a></sup> Remaining Indian troops were withdrawn by 12 March 1972, three months after the war ended.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-167"><a href="#cite_note-167">[167]</a></sup>
</p><p>The cause of Bangladeshi self-determination was recognised around the world. By August 1972, the new state was recognised by 86 countries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Benvenisti2012_158-1"><a href="#cite_note-Benvenisti2012-158">[158]</a></sup> Pakistan recognised Bangladesh in 1974 after pressure from most of the Muslim countries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-168"><a href="#cite_note-168">[168]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Modern_Bangladesh">Modern Bangladesh</span></h3>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="First_parliamentary_era">First parliamentary era</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Sheikh_Mujibur_Rahman_casting_ballot_1970_election.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2116" data-file-width="2972" decoding="async" height="157" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/Sheikh_Mujibur_Rahman_casting_ballot_1970_election.jpg/220px-Sheikh_Mujibur_Rahman_casting_ballot_1970_election.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/Sheikh_Mujibur_Rahman_casting_ballot_1970_election.jpg/330px-Sheikh_Mujibur_Rahman_casting_ballot_1970_election.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/Sheikh_Mujibur_Rahman_casting_ballot_1970_election.jpg/440px-Sheikh_Mujibur_Rahman_casting_ballot_1970_election.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Sheikh_Mujibur_Rahman_casting_ballot_1970_election.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Sheikh Mujib casting his <a href="/wiki/Ballot" title="Ballot">ballot</a> during a general election. He was given the popular title of <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bangabandhu" title="Bangabandhu">Bangabandhu</a></i> (Friend of Bengal) and is regarded as Bangladesh's founding leader.</div></div></div>
<p>The constituent assembly adopted the constitution of Bangladesh on 4 November 1972, establishing a secular, multiparty parliamentary democracy. The new constitution included references to <a href="/wiki/Socialism" title="Socialism">socialism</a>, and Prime Minister Sheikh Mujibur Rahman <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nationalised" title="Nationalised">nationalised</a> major industries in 1972.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-169"><a href="#cite_note-169">[169]</a></sup> A major reconstruction and rehabilitation program was launched. The Awami League won the country's first general election in 1973, securing a large majority in the "<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jatiyo_Sangshad" title="Jatiyo Sangshad">Jatiyo Sangshad</a>", the national parliament. Bangladesh joined the <a href="/wiki/Commonwealth_of_Nations" title="Commonwealth of Nations">Commonwealth of Nations</a>, the UN, the <a href="/wiki/Organisation_of_Islamic_Cooperation" title="Organisation of Islamic Cooperation">OIC</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Non-Aligned_Movement" title="Non-Aligned Movement">Non-Aligned Movement</a>, and Rahman strengthened ties with India. Amid growing agitation by the opposition <a href="/wiki/National_Awami_Party" title="National Awami Party">National Awami Party</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jashod" title="Jashod">Jashod</a>, he became increasingly authoritarian. Rahman amended the constitution, giving himself more emergency powers (including the suspension of fundamental rights). The <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh_famine_of_1974" title="Bangladesh famine of 1974">Bangladesh famine of 1974</a> also worsened the political situation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Lewis2011_170-0"><a href="#cite_note-Lewis2011-170">[170]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span id="Presidential_era_.281975.E2.80.931991.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Presidential_era_(1975–1991)">Presidential era (1975–1991)</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Military_coups_in_Bangladesh" title="Military coups in Bangladesh">Military coups in Bangladesh</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Statiefoto_Koninklijke_Familie_en_President_Ziaur_Rakm_(Bangladesj)_en_echtgenot,_Bestanddeelnr_253-8087.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2427" data-file-width="3635" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a5/Statiefoto_Koninklijke_Familie_en_President_Ziaur_Rakm_%28Bangladesj%29_en_echtgenot%2C_Bestanddeelnr_253-8087.jpg/220px-Statiefoto_Koninklijke_Familie_en_President_Ziaur_Rakm_%28Bangladesj%29_en_echtgenot%2C_Bestanddeelnr_253-8087.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a5/Statiefoto_Koninklijke_Familie_en_President_Ziaur_Rakm_%28Bangladesj%29_en_echtgenot%2C_Bestanddeelnr_253-8087.jpg/330px-Statiefoto_Koninklijke_Familie_en_President_Ziaur_Rakm_%28Bangladesj%29_en_echtgenot%2C_Bestanddeelnr_253-8087.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a5/Statiefoto_Koninklijke_Familie_en_President_Ziaur_Rakm_%28Bangladesj%29_en_echtgenot%2C_Bestanddeelnr_253-8087.jpg/440px-Statiefoto_Koninklijke_Familie_en_President_Ziaur_Rakm_%28Bangladesj%29_en_echtgenot%2C_Bestanddeelnr_253-8087.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Statiefoto_Koninklijke_Familie_en_President_Ziaur_Rakm_(Bangladesj)_en_echtgenot,_Bestanddeelnr_253-8087.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Ziaur_Rahman" title="Ziaur Rahman">Ziaur Rahman</a> with members of the Dutch royal family in 1978</div></div></div>
<p>In January 1975, Sheikh Mujibur Rahman introduced <a href="/wiki/One-party_state" title="One-party state">one-party socialist rule</a> under <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh_Krishak_Sramik_Awami_League" title="Bangladesh Krishak Sramik Awami League">BAKSAL</a>. Rahman banned all newspapers except four state-owned publications and amended the constitution to increase his power. He was <a href="/wiki/Assassination_of_Sheikh_Mujibur_Rahman" title="Assassination of Sheikh Mujibur Rahman">assassinated</a> during a coup on 15 August 1975. <a href="/wiki/Martial_law" title="Martial law">Martial law</a> was declared, and the presidency passed to the <a href="/wiki/Usurper" title="Usurper">usurper</a> <a href="/wiki/Khondaker_Mostaq_Ahmad" title="Khondaker Mostaq Ahmad">Khondaker Mostaq Ahmad</a> for four months. Ahmad is widely regarded as a traitor by Bangladeshis.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-171"><a href="#cite_note-171">[171]</a></sup> Tajuddin Ahmad, the nation's first prime minister, and four other independence leaders were assassinated on 4 November 1975. Chief Justice <a href="/wiki/Abu_Sadat_Mohammad_Sayem" title="Abu Sadat Mohammad Sayem">Abu Sadat Mohammad Sayem</a> was installed as president by the military on 6 November 1975. Bangladesh was governed by a <a href="/wiki/Military_junta" title="Military junta">military junta</a> led by the <a href="/wiki/Chief_Martial_Law_Administrator" title="Chief Martial Law Administrator">Chief Martial Law Administrator</a> for three years. In 1977, the army chief <a href="/wiki/Ziaur_Rahman" title="Ziaur Rahman">Ziaur Rahman</a> became president. Rahman reinstated <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Multiparty" title="Multiparty">multiparty</a> politics, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Privatised" title="Privatised">privatised</a> industries and newspapers, established <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh_Export_Processing_Zone_Authority" title="Bangladesh Export Processing Zone Authority">BEPZA</a> and held the country's second general election in 1979. A <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Semi-presidential" title="Semi-presidential">semi-presidential</a> system evolved, with the <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh_Nationalist_Party" title="Bangladesh Nationalist Party">Bangladesh Nationalist Party</a> (BNP) governing until 1982. Rahman was assassinated in 1981 and was succeeded by Vice-president <a href="/wiki/Abdus_Sattar_(president)" title="Abdus Sattar (president)">Abdus Sattar</a>. Sattar received 65.5 per cent of the vote in the <a href="/wiki/1981_Bangladeshi_presidential_election" title="1981 Bangladeshi presidential election">1981 presidential election</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Khasru_172-0"><a href="#cite_note-Khasru-172">[172]</a></sup>
</p><p>After a year in office, Sattar was overthrown in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/1982_Bangladesh_coup_d%27%C3%A9tat" title="1982 Bangladesh coup d'état">1982 Bangladesh coup d'état</a>. Chief Justice <a href="/wiki/A._F._M._Ahsanuddin_Chowdhury" title="A. F. M. Ahsanuddin Chowdhury">A. F. M. Ahsanuddin Chowdhury</a> was installed as president, but army chief <a href="/wiki/Hussain_Muhammad_Ershad" title="Hussain Muhammad Ershad">Hussain Muhammad Ershad</a> became the country's <i>de facto</i> leader and assumed the presidency in 1983. Ershad lifted martial law in 1986. He governed with four successive prime ministers (<a href="/wiki/Ataur_Rahman_Khan" title="Ataur Rahman Khan">Ataur Rahman Khan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mizanur_Rahman_Chowdhury" title="Mizanur Rahman Chowdhury">Mizanur Rahman Chowdhury</a>, <a href="/wiki/Moudud_Ahmed" title="Moudud Ahmed">Moudud Ahmed</a> and <a href="/wiki/Kazi_Zafar_Ahmed" title="Kazi Zafar Ahmed">Kazi Zafar Ahmed</a>) and a parliament dominated by his <a href="/wiki/Jatiya_Party_(Ershad)" title="Jatiya Party (Ershad)">Jatiyo Party</a>. General elections were held in 1986 and 1988, although the opposition BNP and Awami League boycotted the latter. Ershad pursued administrative decentralisation, dividing the country into 64 districts, and pushed Parliament to make Islam the state religion in 1988.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-173"><a href="#cite_note-173">[173]</a></sup> A <a href="/wiki/1990_Mass_Uprising_in_Bangladesh" title="1990 Mass Uprising in Bangladesh">1990 mass uprising</a> forced him to resign, and Chief Justice <a href="/wiki/Shahabuddin_Ahmed" title="Shahabuddin Ahmed">Shahabuddin Ahmed</a> led the country's first caretaker government as part of the transition to parliamentary rule.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Khasru_172-1"><a href="#cite_note-Khasru-172">[172]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span id="Parliamentary_era_.281991.E2.80.93present.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Parliamentary_era_(1991–present)">Parliamentary era (1991–present)</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Muhammad_Yunus_in_Oslo_Norway_at_the_Nobel_Awards_by_Don_Ramey_Logan.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2012" data-file-width="3038" decoding="async" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/47/Muhammad_Yunus_in_Oslo_Norway_at_the_Nobel_Awards_by_Don_Ramey_Logan.jpg/220px-Muhammad_Yunus_in_Oslo_Norway_at_the_Nobel_Awards_by_Don_Ramey_Logan.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/47/Muhammad_Yunus_in_Oslo_Norway_at_the_Nobel_Awards_by_Don_Ramey_Logan.jpg/330px-Muhammad_Yunus_in_Oslo_Norway_at_the_Nobel_Awards_by_Don_Ramey_Logan.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/47/Muhammad_Yunus_in_Oslo_Norway_at_the_Nobel_Awards_by_Don_Ramey_Logan.jpg/440px-Muhammad_Yunus_in_Oslo_Norway_at_the_Nobel_Awards_by_Don_Ramey_Logan.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Muhammad_Yunus_in_Oslo_Norway_at_the_Nobel_Awards_by_Don_Ramey_Logan.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Muhammad_Yunus" title="Muhammad Yunus">Muhammad Yunus</a> (center) celebrating the <a href="/wiki/Nobel_Peace_Prize" title="Nobel Peace Prize">Nobel Peace Prize</a> in 2006 with his family in Oslo, Norway</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Rohingya_refugees_entering_Bangladesh_after_being_driven_out_of_Myanmar,_2017.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1080" data-file-width="1920" decoding="async" height="124" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b9/Rohingya_refugees_entering_Bangladesh_after_being_driven_out_of_Myanmar%2C_2017.JPG/220px-Rohingya_refugees_entering_Bangladesh_after_being_driven_out_of_Myanmar%2C_2017.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b9/Rohingya_refugees_entering_Bangladesh_after_being_driven_out_of_Myanmar%2C_2017.JPG/330px-Rohingya_refugees_entering_Bangladesh_after_being_driven_out_of_Myanmar%2C_2017.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b9/Rohingya_refugees_entering_Bangladesh_after_being_driven_out_of_Myanmar%2C_2017.JPG/440px-Rohingya_refugees_entering_Bangladesh_after_being_driven_out_of_Myanmar%2C_2017.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Rohingya_refugees_entering_Bangladesh_after_being_driven_out_of_Myanmar,_2017.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Rohingya_people" title="Rohingya people">Rohingya</a> refugees entering Bangladesh from Myanmar</div></div></div>
<p>After the 1991 general election, the twelfth amendment to the constitution restored the parliamentary republic and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Begum_Khaleda_Zia" title="Begum Khaleda Zia">Begum Khaleda Zia</a> became Bangladesh's first female prime minister. Zia, a former first lady, led a BNP government from 1990 to 1996. In 1991, her finance minister, <a href="/wiki/Saifur_Rahman_(Bangladeshi_politician)" title="Saifur Rahman (Bangladeshi politician)">Saifur Rahman</a>, began a major program to liberalise the Bangladeshi economy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Lewis2011_170-1"><a href="#cite_note-Lewis2011-170">[170]</a></sup>
</p><p>In February 1996, <a href="/wiki/February_1996_Bangladeshi_general_election" title="February 1996 Bangladeshi general election">a general election</a> was held, which was boycotted by all opposition parties giving a 300 (of 300) seat victory for BNP. This election was deemed illegitimate, so a system of a <a href="/wiki/Caretaker_government_of_Bangladesh" title="Caretaker government of Bangladesh">caretaker government</a> was introduced to oversee the transfer of power and a new election was held in June 1996, overseen by Justice <a href="/wiki/Muhammad_Habibur_Rahman" title="Muhammad Habibur Rahman">Muhammad Habibur Rahman</a>, the first <a href="/wiki/Chief_Adviser_of_Bangladesh" title="Chief Adviser of Bangladesh">Chief Adviser of Bangladesh</a>. The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bangladesh_Awami_League" title="Bangladesh Awami League">Awami League</a> won the <a href="/wiki/June_1996_Bangladeshi_general_election" title="June 1996 Bangladeshi general election">seventh general election</a>, marking its leader <a href="/wiki/Sheikh_Hasina" title="Sheikh Hasina">Sheikh Hasina's</a> first term as Prime Minister. Hasina's first term was highlighted by the <a href="/wiki/Chittagong_Hill_Tracts_Peace_Accord" title="Chittagong Hill Tracts Peace Accord">Chittagong Hill Tracts Peace Accord</a> and a <a href="/wiki/Ganges" title="Ganges">Ganges</a> water-sharing treaty with India. The second caretaker government, led by Chief Adviser Justice <a href="/wiki/Latifur_Rahman" title="Latifur Rahman">Latifur Rahman</a>, oversaw the <a href="/wiki/2001_Bangladeshi_general_election" title="2001 Bangladeshi general election">2001 Bangladeshi general election</a> which returned Begum Zia and the BNP to power.
</p><p>The second Zia administration saw improved economic growth, but political turmoil gripped the country between 2004 and 2006. A radical Islamist militant group, the <a href="/wiki/Jamaat-ul-Mujahideen_Bangladesh" title="Jamaat-ul-Mujahideen Bangladesh">JMB</a>, carried out a series of terror attacks. The evidence of staging these attacks by these extremist groups have been found in the investigation. Hundreds of suspected members were detained in numerous security operations in 2006, including the two chiefs of the JMB, <a href="/wiki/Shaykh_Abdur_Rahman" title="Shaykh Abdur Rahman">Shaykh Abdur Rahman</a> and <a href="/wiki/Bangla_Bhai" title="Bangla Bhai">Bangla Bhai</a>, who was executed with other top leaders in March 2007, bringing the militant group to an end.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-174"><a href="#cite_note-174">[174]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2006, at the end of the term of the BNP administration, there was widespread political unrest related to the handover of power to a caretaker government.  As such, the Bangladeshi military urged President <a href="/wiki/Iajuddin_Ahmed" title="Iajuddin Ahmed">Iajuddin Ahmed</a> to impose a <a href="/wiki/State_of_emergency" title="State of emergency">state of emergency</a> and a caretaker government, led by technocrat <a href="/wiki/Fakhruddin_Ahmed" title="Fakhruddin Ahmed">Fakhruddin Ahmed</a>, was installed.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Lewis2011_170-2"><a href="#cite_note-Lewis2011-170">[170]</a></sup> Emergency rule lasted for two years, during which time investigations into members of both Awami League and BNP were conducted, including their leaders <a href="/wiki/Sheikh_Hasina" title="Sheikh Hasina">Sheikh Hasina</a> and <a href="/wiki/Khaleda_Zia" title="Khaleda Zia">Khaleda Zia</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-175"><a href="#cite_note-175">[175]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-176"><a href="#cite_note-176">[176]</a></sup> In 2008, the <a href="/wiki/2008_Bangladeshi_general_election" title="2008 Bangladeshi general election">ninth general election</a> saw a return to power for Sheikh Hasina and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bangladesh_Awami_League" title="Bangladesh Awami League">Awami League</a> led <a href="/wiki/Grand_Alliance_(Bangladesh)" title="Grand Alliance (Bangladesh)">Grand Alliance</a> in a landslide victory. In 2010, the <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_Bangladesh" title="Supreme Court of Bangladesh">Supreme Court</a> ruled martial law illegal and affirmed <a href="/wiki/Secularism" title="Secularism">secular</a> principles in the constitution. The following year, the Awami League abolished the caretaker government system.
</p><p>Citing the lack of caretaker government, the <a href="/wiki/2014_Bangladeshi_general_election" title="2014 Bangladeshi general election">2014 general election</a> was boycotted by the BNP and other opposition parties, giving the Awami League a decisive victory. The election was controversial with reports of violence and an alleged crackdown on the opposition in the run-up to the election, and 153 seats (of 300) went uncontested in the election. Despite the controversy, Hasina went on to form a government that saw her return for a third term as Prime Minister. Due to strong domestic demand, Bangladesh emerged as one of the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_real_GDP_growth_rate" title="List of countries by real GDP growth rate">fastest-growing economies in the world</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-177"><a href="#cite_note-177">[177]</a></sup> However, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Human_rights_abuses" title="Human rights abuses">human rights abuses</a> increased under the Hasina administration, particularly <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Forced_disappearance_in_Bangladesh" title="Forced disappearance in Bangladesh">enforced disappearances</a>. Between 2016 and 2017, an estimated 1 million <a href="/wiki/Rohingya_refugees_in_Bangladesh" title="Rohingya refugees in Bangladesh">Rohingya refugees</a> took shelter in <a href="/wiki/Cox%27s_Bazar_District" title="Cox's Bazar District">southeastern Bangladesh</a> amid a military crackdown in neighbouring <a href="/wiki/Rakhine_State" title="Rakhine State">Rakhine State</a>, <a href="/wiki/Myanmar" title="Myanmar">Myanmar</a>.
</p><p>In 2018, the country saw major movements for <a href="/wiki/2018_Bangladesh_quota_reform_movement" title="2018 Bangladesh quota reform movement">government quota reforms</a> and <a href="/wiki/2018_Bangladesh_road-safety_protests" title="2018 Bangladesh road-safety protests">road-safety</a>. The <a href="/wiki/2018_Bangladeshi_general_election" title="2018 Bangladeshi general election">2018 Bangladeshi general election</a> was marred by allegations of widespread <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Vote_rigging" title="Vote rigging">vote rigging</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-178"><a href="#cite_note-178">[178]</a></sup> The Awami League won 259 out of 300 seats and the main opposition alliance <a href="/wiki/Jatiya_Oikya_Front" title="Jatiya Oikya Front">Jatiya Oikya Front</a> secured only 8 seats, with Sheikh Hasina becoming the longest-serving prime minister in Bangladeshi history.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-179"><a href="#cite_note-179">[179]</a></sup> Pro-democracy leader Dr. <a href="/wiki/Kamal_Hossain" title="Kamal Hossain">Kamal Hossain</a> called for an annulment of the election result and for a new election to be held in a free and fair manner.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-180"><a href="#cite_note-180">[180]</a></sup> The election was also observed by <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a> observers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-181"><a href="#cite_note-181">[181]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Geography">Geography</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Geography_of_Bangladesh" title="Geography of Bangladesh">Geography of Bangladesh</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Map_of_Bangladesh-en.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2074" data-file-width="1678" decoding="async" height="272" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/aa/Map_of_Bangladesh-en.svg/220px-Map_of_Bangladesh-en.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/aa/Map_of_Bangladesh-en.svg/330px-Map_of_Bangladesh-en.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/aa/Map_of_Bangladesh-en.svg/440px-Map_of_Bangladesh-en.svg.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Map_of_Bangladesh-en.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Physical map of Bangladesh</div></div></div>
<p>Bangladesh is a small, lush country in <a href="/wiki/South_Asia" title="South Asia">South Asia</a>, located on the <a href="/wiki/Bay_of_Bengal" title="Bay of Bengal">Bay of Bengal</a>. It is surrounded almost entirely by neighbouring <a href="/wiki/India" title="India">India</a>—and shares a small border with <a href="/wiki/Myanmar" title="Myanmar">Myanmar</a> to its southeast, though it lies very close to <a href="/wiki/Nepal" title="Nepal">Nepal</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bhutan" title="Bhutan">Bhutan</a>, and <a href="/wiki/China" title="China">China</a>. The country is divided into three regions. Most of the country is dominated by the fertile <a href="/wiki/Ganges_Delta" title="Ganges Delta">Ganges Delta</a>, the largest river delta in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-182"><a href="#cite_note-182">[182]</a></sup> The northwest and central parts of the country are formed by the <a href="/wiki/Madhupur_tract" title="Madhupur tract">Madhupur</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Barind_Tract" title="Barind Tract">Barind</a> plateaus. The northeast and southeast are home to <a href="/wiki/Evergreen" title="Evergreen">evergreen</a> hill ranges.
</p><p>The Ganges delta is formed by the confluence of the Ganges (local name <a href="/wiki/Padma_River" title="Padma River">Padma</a> or <i>Pôdda</i>), <a href="/wiki/Brahmaputra_River" title="Brahmaputra River">Brahmaputra</a> (<a href="/wiki/Jamuna_River_(Bangladesh)" title="Jamuna River (Bangladesh)">Jamuna</a> or <i>Jomuna</i>), and <a href="/wiki/Meghna_River" title="Meghna River">Meghna</a> rivers and their respective tributaries. The Ganges unites with the Jamuna (main channel of the Brahmaputra) and later joins the Meghna, finally flowing into the Bay of Bengal. Bangladesh is called the "Land of Rivers";<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-183"><a href="#cite_note-183">[183]</a></sup> as it is home to over 57 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Trans-boundary_river" title="Trans-boundary river">trans-boundary rivers</a>. However, this resolves water issues politically complicated, in most cases, as the country is a lower <a href="/wiki/Riparian_zone" title="Riparian zone">riparian</a> state to India.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-184"><a href="#cite_note-184">[184]</a></sup>
</p><p>Bangladesh is predominantly rich fertile flat land. Most of it is less than 12 m (39 ft) above sea level, and it is estimated that about 10% of its land would be flooded if the sea level were to rise by 1 m (3.3 ft).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ali_185-0"><a href="#cite_note-ali-185">[185]</a></sup> 17% of the country is covered by forests and 12% is covered by hill systems. The country's <a href="/wiki/Haor" title="Haor">haor</a> wetlands are of significance to global environmental science. The <a href="/wiki/List_of_mountains_of_Bangladesh" title="List of mountains of Bangladesh">highest point in Bangladesh</a> is the <a href="/wiki/Saka_Haphong" title="Saka Haphong">Saka Haphong</a>, located near the border with Myanmar, with an elevation of 1,064 m (3,491 ft).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CIA_186-0"><a href="#cite_note-CIA-186">[186]</a></sup> Previously, either <a href="/wiki/Keokradong" title="Keokradong">Keokradong</a> or <a href="/wiki/Tazing_Dong" title="Tazing Dong">Tazing Dong</a> were considered the highest.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Administrative_geography">Administrative geography</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Administrative_geography_of_Bangladesh" title="Administrative geography of Bangladesh">Administrative geography of Bangladesh</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Divisions_of_Bangladesh" title="Divisions of Bangladesh">Divisions of Bangladesh</a>, <a href="/wiki/Districts_of_Bangladesh" title="Districts of Bangladesh">Districts of Bangladesh</a>, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Upazilas_of_Bangladesh" title="Upazilas of Bangladesh">Upazilas of Bangladesh</a></div>

href="/wiki/Sylhet_Division" shape="poly" title="Sylhet Division"/><area alt="Chittagong Division" coords="212,167,214,184,205,194,203,210,210,230,216,247,219,246,218,235,223,235,228,253,238,253,243,244,242,231,251,223,255,218,253,203,260,208,268,203,274,208,280,235,281,254,285,265,296,309,294,310,296,329,294,344,299,369,294,372,289,365,286,364,278,357,274,365,270,369,270,379,278,403,277,405,262,379,256,360,251,354,248,355,247,337,247,326,247,316,239,292,228,293,222,300,204,308,179,311,185,287,175,262,164,247,163,226,171,216,171,203,179,194,188,189,194,180,194,171,212,168" decoding="async" height="416" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ea/Bangladesh_divisions_english.svg/300px-Bangladesh_divisions_english.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ea/Bangladesh_divisions_english.svg/450px-Bangladesh_divisions_english.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ea/Bangladesh_divisions_english.svg/600px-Bangladesh_divisions_english.svg.png 2x" usemap="#ImageMap_7e2ae818281c9310" width="300"/><div style="margin-left: 280px; margin-top: -415px; text-align: left;"><a href="/wiki/File:Bangladesh_divisions_english.svg" title="About this image"><img alt="About this image" src="/w/extensions/ImageMap/resources/desc-20.png?15600" style="border: none;"/></a></div></div></div>
<p>Bangladesh is divided into eight administrative divisions,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-187"><a href="#cite_note-187">[187]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CIA_186-1"><a href="#cite_note-CIA-186">[186]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-188"><a href="#cite_note-188">[188]</a></sup> each named after their respective divisional headquarters: <a href="/wiki/Barisal_Division" title="Barisal Division">Barisal</a> (officially <i>Barishal</i><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-namechange_189-0"><a href="#cite_note-namechange-189">[189]</a></sup>), <a href="/wiki/Chittagong_Division" title="Chittagong Division">Chittagong</a> (officially <i>Chattogram</i><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-namechange_189-1"><a href="#cite_note-namechange-189">[189]</a></sup>), <a href="/wiki/Dhaka_Division" title="Dhaka Division">Dhaka</a>, <a href="/wiki/Khulna_Division" title="Khulna Division">Khulna</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mymensingh_Division" title="Mymensingh Division">Mymensingh</a>, Rajshahi, Rangpur, and Sylhet.
</p><p>Divisions are subdivided into districts (<i>zila</i>). There are 64 districts in Bangladesh, each further subdivided into <i>upazila</i> (subdistricts) or <i>thana</i>. The area within each police station, except for those in metropolitan areas, is divided into several <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Union_Councils_of_Bangladesh" title="Union Councils of Bangladesh">unions</a></i>, with each union consisting of multiple villages. In the metropolitan areas, police stations are divided into wards, further divided into <i>mahallas</i>.
</p><p>There are no elected officials at the divisional or district levels, and the administration is composed only of government officials. Direct elections are held in each union (or ward) for a chairperson and a number of members. In 1997, a parliamentary act was passed to reserve three seats (out of 12) in every union for female candidates.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-190"><a href="#cite_note-190">[190]</a></sup>
</p>

<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Climate">Climate</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Geography_of_Bangladesh#Climate" title="Geography of Bangladesh">Geography of Bangladesh § Climate</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Climate_change_in_Bangladesh" title="Climate change in Bangladesh">Climate change in Bangladesh</a></div>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">.mw-parser-output .tmulti .multiimageinner{display:flex;flex-direction:column}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow{display:flex;flex-direction:row;clear:left;flex-wrap:wrap;width:100%;box-sizing:border-box}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle{margin:1px;float:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .theader{clear:both;font-weight:bold;text-align:center;align-self:center;background-color:transparent;width:100%}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbcaption{background-color:transparent}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-left{text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-right{text-align:right}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-center{text-align:center}@media all and (max-width:720px){.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbinner{width:100%!important;box-sizing:border-box;max-width:none!important;align-items:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow{justify-content:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle{float:none!important;max-width:100%!important;box-sizing:border-box;text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle .thumbcaption{text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow>.thumbcaption{text-align:center}}</style><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:392px;max-width:392px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:192px;max-width:192px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:130px;overflow:hidden"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Koppen-Geiger_Map_BGD_present.svg"><img alt="" data-file-height="850" data-file-width="1240" decoding="async" height="130" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/af/Koppen-Geiger_Map_BGD_present.svg/190px-Koppen-Geiger_Map_BGD_present.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/af/Koppen-Geiger_Map_BGD_present.svg/285px-Koppen-Geiger_Map_BGD_present.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/af/Koppen-Geiger_Map_BGD_present.svg/380px-Koppen-Geiger_Map_BGD_present.svg.png 2x" width="190"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification" title="Köppen climate classification">Köppen-Geiger climate classification</a> map for Bangladesh<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-193"><a href="#cite_note-193">[193]</a></sup></div></div><div class="tsingle" style="width:196px;max-width:196px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:130px;overflow:hidden"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Flooding_after_1991_cyclone.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="1890" data-file-width="2810" decoding="async" height="130" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/90/Flooding_after_1991_cyclone.jpg/194px-Flooding_after_1991_cyclone.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/90/Flooding_after_1991_cyclone.jpg/291px-Flooding_after_1991_cyclone.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/90/Flooding_after_1991_cyclone.jpg/388px-Flooding_after_1991_cyclone.jpg 2x" width="194"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption">Flooding after the <a href="/wiki/1991_Bangladesh_cyclone" title="1991 Bangladesh cyclone">1991 Bangladesh cyclone</a>, which killed around 140,000 people</div></div></div></div></div>
<p>Straddling the <a href="/wiki/Tropic_of_Cancer" title="Tropic of Cancer">Tropic of Cancer</a>, Bangladesh's climate is tropical, with a mild winter from October to March and a hot, humid summer from March to June. The country has never recorded an air temperature below 0 °C (32 °F), with a record low of 1.1 °C (34.0 °F) in the northwest city of <a href="/wiki/Dinajpur" title="Dinajpur">Dinajpur</a> on 3 February 1905.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-194"><a href="#cite_note-194">[194]</a></sup> A warm and humid <a href="/wiki/Monsoon" title="Monsoon">monsoon</a> season lasts from June to October and supplies most of the country's rainfall. Natural calamities, such as <a href="/wiki/Floods_in_Bangladesh" title="Floods in Bangladesh">floods</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tropical_cyclone" title="Tropical cyclone">tropical cyclones</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tornado" title="Tornado">tornadoes</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Tidal_bore" title="Tidal bore">tidal bores</a> occur almost every year,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NatDis_195-0"><a href="#cite_note-NatDis-195">[195]</a></sup> combined with the effects of <a href="/wiki/Deforestation" title="Deforestation">deforestation</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Soils_retrogression_and_degradation" title="Soils retrogression and degradation">soil degradation</a> and <a href="/wiki/Erosion" title="Erosion">erosion</a>. The <a href="/wiki/List_of_Bangladesh_tropical_cyclones" title="List of Bangladesh tropical cyclones">cyclones</a> of 1970 and 1991 were particularly devastating, the <a href="/wiki/1991_Bangladesh_cyclone" title="1991 Bangladesh cyclone">latter</a> killing approximately 140,000 people.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-196"><a href="#cite_note-196">[196]</a></sup>
</p><p>In September 1998, Bangladesh saw the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/1998_Bangladesh_floods" title="1998 Bangladesh floods">most severe flooding</a> in modern history, after which two-thirds of the country went underwater, along with a death toll of 1,000.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EWG_197-0"><a href="#cite_note-EWG-197">[197]</a></sup> As a result of various international and national level initiatives in disaster risk reduction, human toll and economic damage from floods and cyclones have come down over the years.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-198"><a href="#cite_note-198">[198]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/2007_South_Asian_floods" title="2007 South Asian floods">2007 South Asian floods</a> ravaged areas across the country, leaving five million people displaced, had a death toll around 500.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-199"><a href="#cite_note-199">[199]</a></sup>
</p><p>Bangladesh is recognised to be one of the countries most <a href="/wiki/Climate_change_vulnerability" title="Climate change vulnerability">vulnerable to climate change</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-200"><a href="#cite_note-200">[200]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-201"><a href="#cite_note-201">[201]</a></sup> Over the course of a century, 508 cyclones have affected the Bay of Bengal region, 17 percent of which are believed to have caused landfall in Bangladesh.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-202"><a href="#cite_note-202">[202]</a></sup> Natural hazards that come from increased rainfall, rising sea levels, and tropical cyclones are expected to increase as the climate changes, each seriously affecting agriculture, water and food security, human health, and shelter.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-203"><a href="#cite_note-203">[203]</a></sup> It is estimated that by 2050, a 3 feet rise in sea levels will inundate some 20 percent of the land and displace more than 30 million people.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-204"><a href="#cite_note-204">[204]</a></sup> To address the <a href="/wiki/Sea_level_rise" title="Sea level rise">sea level rise</a> threat in Bangladesh, the Bangladesh Delta Plan 2100 has been launched.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:2_205-0"><a href="#cite_note-:2-205">[205]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-206"><a href="#cite_note-206">[206]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Biodiversity">Biodiversity</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Wildlife_of_Bangladesh" title="Wildlife of Bangladesh">Wildlife of Bangladesh</a> and <a href="/wiki/Fauna_of_Bangladesh" title="Fauna of Bangladesh">Fauna of Bangladesh</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Bengal_Tiger_gets_down_in_a_shallow_canal_in_Sundarban.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1067" data-file-width="1600" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d4/Bengal_Tiger_gets_down_in_a_shallow_canal_in_Sundarban.jpg/220px-Bengal_Tiger_gets_down_in_a_shallow_canal_in_Sundarban.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d4/Bengal_Tiger_gets_down_in_a_shallow_canal_in_Sundarban.jpg/330px-Bengal_Tiger_gets_down_in_a_shallow_canal_in_Sundarban.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d4/Bengal_Tiger_gets_down_in_a_shallow_canal_in_Sundarban.jpg/440px-Bengal_Tiger_gets_down_in_a_shallow_canal_in_Sundarban.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Bengal_Tiger_gets_down_in_a_shallow_canal_in_Sundarban.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A <a href="/wiki/Bengal_tiger" title="Bengal tiger">Bengal tiger</a>, the national animal, in the Sundarbans</div></div></div>
<p>Bangladesh is located in the <a href="/wiki/Indomalayan_realm" title="Indomalayan realm">Indomalayan realm</a>, and lies within four terrestrial ecoregions: <a href="/wiki/Lower_Gangetic_Plains_moist_deciduous_forests" title="Lower Gangetic Plains moist deciduous forests">Lower Gangetic Plains moist deciduous forests</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mizoram%E2%80%93Manipur%E2%80%93Kachin_rain_forests" title="Mizoram–Manipur–Kachin rain forests">Mizoram–Manipur–Kachin rain forests</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sundarbans_freshwater_swamp_forests" title="Sundarbans freshwater swamp forests">Sundarbans freshwater swamp forests</a>, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sundarbans_mangroves" title="Sundarbans mangroves">Sundarbans mangroves</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-DinersteinOlson2017_207-0"><a href="#cite_note-DinersteinOlson2017-207">[207]</a></sup> Its ecology includes a long sea coastline, numerous <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_rivers_in_Bangladesh" title="List of rivers in Bangladesh">rivers and tributaries</a>, lakes, <a href="/wiki/Wetland" title="Wetland">wetlands</a>, evergreen forests, semi evergreen forests, hill forests, moist <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Deciduous_forest" title="Deciduous forest">deciduous forests</a>, freshwater swamp forests and flat land with tall grass. The Bangladesh Plain is famous for its fertile <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Alluvial" title="Alluvial">alluvial</a> soil which supports extensive cultivation. The country is dominated by lush vegetation, with villages often buried in groves of <a href="/wiki/Mango" title="Mango">mango</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jackfruit" title="Jackfruit">jackfruit</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bamboo" title="Bamboo">bamboo</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Betel_nut" title="Betel nut">betel nut</a>, <a href="/wiki/Coconut" title="Coconut">coconut</a> and <a href="/wiki/Date_palm" title="Date palm">date palm</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-global.britannica.com_208-0"><a href="#cite_note-global.britannica.com-208">[208]</a></sup> The country has up to 6000 species of plant life, including 5000 flowering plants.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-209"><a href="#cite_note-209">[209]</a></sup> Water bodies and wetland systems provide a habitat for many aquatic plants. <a href="/wiki/Nymphaeaceae" title="Nymphaeaceae">Water lilies</a> and <a href="/wiki/Nelumbo_nucifera" title="Nelumbo nucifera">lotuses</a> grow vividly during the monsoon season. The country has <a href="/wiki/List_of_protected_areas_of_Bangladesh" title="List of protected areas of Bangladesh">50 wildlife sanctuaries</a>.
</p><p>Bangladesh is home to much of the <a href="/wiki/Sundarbans" title="Sundarbans">Sundarbans</a>, the world's largest <a href="/wiki/Mangrove_forest" title="Mangrove forest">mangrove forest</a>, covering an area of 6,000 km<sup>2</sup> in the southwest littoral region. It is divided into three protected sanctuaries–the <a href="/wiki/Sundarbans_South_Wildlife_Sanctuary" title="Sundarbans South Wildlife Sanctuary">South</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sundarbans_East_Wildlife_Sanctuary" title="Sundarbans East Wildlife Sanctuary">East</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sundarbans_West_Wildlife_Sanctuary" title="Sundarbans West Wildlife Sanctuary">West</a> zones. The forest is a UNESCO World Heritage Site. The northeastern Sylhet region is home to haor wetlands, a unique ecosystem. It also includes <a href="/wiki/Tropical_and_subtropical_coniferous_forests" title="Tropical and subtropical coniferous forests">tropical and subtropical coniferous forests</a>, a <a href="/wiki/Freshwater_swamp_forest" title="Freshwater swamp forest">freshwater swamp forest</a>, and mixed deciduous forests. The southeastern <a href="/wiki/Chittagong_Division" title="Chittagong Division">Chittagong region</a> covers evergreen and semi-evergreen hilly jungles. Central Bangladesh includes the plainland Sal forest running along with the districts of Gazipur, <a href="/wiki/Tangail" title="Tangail">Tangail</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mymensingh" title="Mymensingh">Mymensingh</a>. <a href="/wiki/St._Martin%27s_Island" title="St. Martin's Island">St. Martin's Island</a> is the only <a href="/wiki/Coral_reef" title="Coral reef">coral reef</a> in the country.
</p><p>Bangladesh has an abundance of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Wildlife_in_Bangladesh" title="Wildlife in Bangladesh">wildlife</a> in its forests, marshes, woodlands and hills.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-global.britannica.com_208-1"><a href="#cite_note-global.britannica.com-208">[208]</a></sup> The vast majority of animals dwell within a habitat of 150,000 km<sup>2</sup> .<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-210"><a href="#cite_note-210">[210]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Bengal_tiger" title="Bengal tiger">Bengal tiger</a>, <a href="/wiki/Clouded_leopard" title="Clouded leopard">clouded leopard</a>, <a href="/wiki/Saltwater_crocodile" title="Saltwater crocodile">saltwater crocodile</a>, <a href="/wiki/Black_panther" title="Black panther">black panther</a> and <a href="/wiki/Fishing_cat" title="Fishing cat">fishing cat</a> are among the chief predators in the Sundarbans.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-211"><a href="#cite_note-211">[211]</a></sup> Northern and eastern Bangladesh is home to the <a href="/wiki/Asian_elephant" title="Asian elephant">Asian elephant</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hoolock_gibbon" title="Hoolock gibbon">hoolock gibbon</a>, <a href="/wiki/Asian_black_bear" title="Asian black bear">Asian black bear</a> and <a href="/wiki/Oriental_pied_hornbill" title="Oriental pied hornbill">oriental pied hornbill</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bearprojectbd.weebly.com_212-0"><a href="#cite_note-bearprojectbd.weebly.com-212">[212]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Chital" title="Chital">Chital</a> deer are widely seen in southwestern woodlands. Other animals include the <a href="/wiki/Black_giant_squirrel" title="Black giant squirrel">black giant squirrel</a>, <a href="/wiki/Capped_langur" title="Capped langur">capped langur</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bengal_fox" title="Bengal fox">Bengal fox</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sambar_deer" title="Sambar deer">sambar deer</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jungle_cat" title="Jungle cat">jungle cat</a>, <a href="/wiki/King_cobra" title="King cobra">king cobra</a>, <a href="/wiki/Wild_boar" title="Wild boar">wild boar</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mongoose" title="Mongoose">mongooses</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pangolin" title="Pangolin">pangolins</a>, <a href="/wiki/Python_(genus)" title="Python (genus)">pythons</a> and <a href="/wiki/Asian_water_monitor" title="Asian water monitor">water monitors</a>. Bangladesh has one of the largest populations of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Irrawaddy_dolphins" title="Irrawaddy dolphins">Irrawaddy dolphins</a> and <a href="/wiki/South_Asian_river_dolphin" title="South Asian river dolphin">Ganges dolphins</a>. A 2009 census found 6,000 Irrawaddy dolphins inhabiting the littoral rivers of Bangladesh.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-213"><a href="#cite_note-213">[213]</a></sup> The country has numerous species of <a href="/wiki/Amphibian" title="Amphibian">amphibians</a> (53), reptiles (139), <a href="/wiki/Marine_reptile" title="Marine reptile">marine reptiles</a> (19) and <a href="/wiki/Marine_mammal" title="Marine mammal">marine mammals</a> (5). It also has <a href="/wiki/List_of_birds_of_Bangladesh" title="List of birds of Bangladesh">628 species of birds</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-214"><a href="#cite_note-214">[214]</a></sup>
