</p><p>Several animals became extinct in Bangladesh during the last century, including the one-horned and two-horned <a href="/wiki/Rhinoceros" title="Rhinoceros">rhinoceros</a> and common <a href="/wiki/Peafowl" title="Peafowl">peafowl</a>. The human population is concentrated in urban areas, limiting deforestation to a certain extent. Rapid urban growth has threatened natural habitats. Although many areas are protected under law, some Bangladeshi wildlife is threatened by this growth. The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bangladesh_Environment_Conservation_Act" title="Bangladesh Environment Conservation Act">Bangladesh Environment Conservation Act</a> was enacted in 1995. The government has designated several regions as <a href="/wiki/Ecologically_Critical_Area" title="Ecologically Critical Area">Ecologically Critical Areas</a>, including wetlands, forests, and rivers. The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sundarbans_tiger_project" title="Sundarbans tiger project">Sundarbans tiger project</a> and the Bangladesh Bear Project are among the key initiatives to strengthen conservation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bearprojectbd.weebly.com_212-1"><a href="#cite_note-bearprojectbd.weebly.com-212">[212]</a></sup> It ratified the Rio <a href="/wiki/Convention_on_Biological_Diversity" title="Convention on Biological Diversity">Convention on Biological Diversity</a> on 3 May 1994.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cbd.int_215-0"><a href="#cite_note-cbd.int-215">[215]</a></sup> As of 2014<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Bangladesh&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, the country was set to revise its <a href="/wiki/Biodiversity_action_plan" title="Biodiversity action plan">National Biodiversity Strategy and Action Plan</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cbd.int_215-1"><a href="#cite_note-cbd.int-215">[215]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Politics_and_government">Politics and government</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Politics_of_Bangladesh" title="Politics of Bangladesh">Politics of Bangladesh</a> and <a href="/wiki/Government_of_Bangladesh" title="Government of Bangladesh">Government of Bangladesh</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Bangabhaban.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="472" data-file-width="800" decoding="async" height="130" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4b/Bangabhaban.jpg/220px-Bangabhaban.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4b/Bangabhaban.jpg/330px-Bangabhaban.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4b/Bangabhaban.jpg/440px-Bangabhaban.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Bangabhaban.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Bangabhaban" title="Bangabhaban">Bangabhaban</a>, the official residence of the <a href="/wiki/President_of_Bangladesh" title="President of Bangladesh">President of Bangladesh</a>, was built in 1905 during the <a href="/wiki/British_Raj" title="British Raj">British Raj</a> for use by the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Viceroy_of_India" title="Viceroy of India">Viceroy of India</a> and the <a href="/wiki/List_of_governors_of_Bengal_Presidency" title="List of governors of Bengal Presidency">Governor of Bengal</a>.</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:National_Assembly_of_Bangladesh_(%E0%A6%9C%E0%A6%BE%E0%A6%A4%E0%A7%80%E0%A6%AF%E0%A6%BC_%E0%A6%B8%E0%A6%82%E0%A6%B8%E0%A6%A6_%E0%A6%AD%E0%A6%AC%E0%A6%A8).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2713" data-file-width="4928" decoding="async" height="121" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4e/National_Assembly_of_Bangladesh_%28%E0%A6%9C%E0%A6%BE%E0%A6%A4%E0%A7%80%E0%A6%AF%E0%A6%BC_%E0%A6%B8%E0%A6%82%E0%A6%B8%E0%A6%A6_%E0%A6%AD%E0%A6%AC%E0%A6%A8%29.jpg/220px-National_Assembly_of_Bangladesh_%28%E0%A6%9C%E0%A6%BE%E0%A6%A4%E0%A7%80%E0%A6%AF%E0%A6%BC_%E0%A6%B8%E0%A6%82%E0%A6%B8%E0%A6%A6_%E0%A6%AD%E0%A6%AC%E0%A6%A8%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4e/National_Assembly_of_Bangladesh_%28%E0%A6%9C%E0%A6%BE%E0%A6%A4%E0%A7%80%E0%A6%AF%E0%A6%BC_%E0%A6%B8%E0%A6%82%E0%A6%B8%E0%A6%A6_%E0%A6%AD%E0%A6%AC%E0%A6%A8%29.jpg/330px-National_Assembly_of_Bangladesh_%28%E0%A6%9C%E0%A6%BE%E0%A6%A4%E0%A7%80%E0%A6%AF%E0%A6%BC_%E0%A6%B8%E0%A6%82%E0%A6%B8%E0%A6%A6_%E0%A6%AD%E0%A6%AC%E0%A6%A8%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4e/National_Assembly_of_Bangladesh_%28%E0%A6%9C%E0%A6%BE%E0%A6%A4%E0%A7%80%E0%A6%AF%E0%A6%BC_%E0%A6%B8%E0%A6%82%E0%A6%B8%E0%A6%A6_%E0%A6%AD%E0%A6%AC%E0%A6%A8%29.jpg/440px-National_Assembly_of_Bangladesh_%28%E0%A6%9C%E0%A6%BE%E0%A6%A4%E0%A7%80%E0%A6%AF%E0%A6%BC_%E0%A6%B8%E0%A6%82%E0%A6%B8%E0%A6%A6_%E0%A6%AD%E0%A6%AC%E0%A6%A8%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:National_Assembly_of_Bangladesh_(%E0%A6%9C%E0%A6%BE%E0%A6%A4%E0%A7%80%E0%A6%AF%E0%A6%BC_%E0%A6%B8%E0%A6%82%E0%A6%B8%E0%A6%A6_%E0%A6%AD%E0%A6%AC%E0%A6%A8).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Jatiya_Sangsad_Bhaban" title="Jatiya Sangsad Bhaban">National Parliament</a> of Bangladesh</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Bangladesh_Supreme_Court.jpg"><img alt="Long, white, domed building" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="767" data-file-width="1023" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/45/Bangladesh_Supreme_Court.jpg/220px-Bangladesh_Supreme_Court.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/45/Bangladesh_Supreme_Court.jpg/330px-Bangladesh_Supreme_Court.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/45/Bangladesh_Supreme_Court.jpg/440px-Bangladesh_Supreme_Court.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Bangladesh_Supreme_Court.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_Bangladesh" title="Supreme Court of Bangladesh">The Supreme Court of Bangladesh</a></div></div></div>
<p>Bangladesh is a <i><a href="/wiki/De_jure" title="De jure">de jure</a></i> <a href="/wiki/Representative_democracy" title="Representative democracy">representative democracy</a> under its <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Bangladesh" title="Constitution of Bangladesh">constitution</a>, with a <a href="/wiki/Westminster_system" title="Westminster system">Westminster</a>-style <a href="/wiki/Unitary_authority" title="Unitary authority">unitary</a> <a href="/wiki/Parliamentary_republic" title="Parliamentary republic">parliamentary republic</a> that has <a href="/wiki/Universal_suffrage" title="Universal suffrage">universal suffrage</a>. The head of government is the Prime Minister, who is invited to form a government every five years. The President invites the leader of the largest party in parliament to become Prime Minister of the world's fifth-largest democracy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-216"><a href="#cite_note-216">[216]</a></sup> Bangladesh experienced a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Two_party_system" title="Two party system">two party system</a> between 1990 and 2014, when the <a href="/wiki/Awami_League" title="Awami League">Awami League</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh_Nationalist_Party" title="Bangladesh Nationalist Party">Bangladesh Nationalist Party</a> (BNP) alternated in power. During this period, elections were managed by a neutral <a href="/wiki/Caretaker_government_of_Bangladesh" title="Caretaker government of Bangladesh">caretaker government</a>. But the caretaker government was abolished by the Awami League government in 2011.
</p><p>One of the key aspects of Bangladeshi politics is the "spirit of the liberation war", which refers to the ideals of the liberation movement during the <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh_Liberation_War" title="Bangladesh Liberation War">Bangladesh Liberation War</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-217"><a href="#cite_note-217">[217]</a></sup> The Proclamation of Independence enunciated the values of "equality, human dignity and social justice". In 1972, the constitution included a <a href="/wiki/Bill_of_rights" title="Bill of rights">bill of rights</a> and declared "nationalism, socialism, democracy and <a href="/wiki/Secularity" title="Secularity">secularity</a>" as the principles of government policy. Socialism was later de-emphasised and neglected by successive governments. Bangladesh has a market-based economy. To many Bangladeshis, especially in the younger generation, the spirit of the liberation war is a vision for a society based on civil liberties, human rights, the rule of law and good governance.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-218"><a href="#cite_note-218">[218]</a></sup>
</p>
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Legislature" title="Legislature">Legislative</a>: The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jatiya_Sangshad" title="Jatiya Sangshad">Jatiya Sangshad</a> (National Parliament) is the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Unicameral" title="Unicameral">unicameral</a> parliament. It has 350 <a href="/wiki/Member_of_parliament" title="Member of parliament">Members of Parliament</a> (MPs), including 300 MPs elected on the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/First_past_the_post" title="First past the post">first past the post</a> system and 50 MPs appointed to reserved seats for <a href="/wiki/Women%27s_empowerment" title="Women's empowerment">women's empowerment</a>. <a href="/wiki/Article_70_of_the_Constitution_of_Bangladesh" title="Article 70 of the Constitution of Bangladesh">Article 70 of the Constitution of Bangladesh</a> forbids MPs from voting against their party. However, several laws proposed independently by MPs have been transformed into legislation, including the anti-torture law.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-219"><a href="#cite_note-219">[219]</a></sup> The parliament is presided over by the <a href="/wiki/Speaker_of_the_Jatiya_Sangsad" title="Speaker of the Jatiya Sangsad">Speaker of the Jatiya Sangsad</a>, who is second in line to the president as per the constitution. There is also a Deputy Speaker. When a president is incapable of performing duties (i.e. due to illness), the Speaker steps in as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Acting_President" title="Acting President">Acting President</a> and the Deputy Speaker becomes Acting Speaker. A recurring proposal suggests that the Deputy Speaker should be an opposition member.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-220"><a href="#cite_note-220">[220]</a></sup></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Executive_(government)" title="Executive (government)">Executive</a>: The <a href="/wiki/Government_of_Bangladesh" title="Government of Bangladesh">Government of Bangladesh</a> is overseen by a <a href="/wiki/Cabinet_of_Bangladesh" title="Cabinet of Bangladesh">cabinet</a> headed by the <a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Bangladesh" title="Prime Minister of Bangladesh">Prime Minister of Bangladesh</a>. The tenure of a parliamentary government is five years. The <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh_Civil_Service" title="Bangladesh Civil Service">Bangladesh Civil Service</a> assists the cabinet in running the government. Recruitment for the civil service is based on a public examination. In theory, the civil service should be a meritocracy. But a disputed quota system coupled with politicisation and preference for seniority have allegedly affected the civil service's meritocracy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-221"><a href="#cite_note-221">[221]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/President_of_Bangladesh" title="President of Bangladesh">President of Bangladesh</a> is the ceremonial head of state<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-222"><a href="#cite_note-222">[222]</a></sup> whose powers include signing bills passed by parliament into law. The President is elected by the parliament and has a five-year term. Under the constitution, the president acts on the prime minister's advice. The President is the Supreme Commander of the Bangladesh Armed Forces and the chancellor of all universities.</li>
<li><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Laws_in_Bangladesh" title="Laws in Bangladesh">Judiciary</a>: The <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_Bangladesh" title="Supreme Court of Bangladesh">Supreme Court of Bangladesh</a> is the highest court of the land, followed by the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/High_Court_Division" title="High Court Division">High Court</a> and Appellate Divisions. The head of the judiciary is the <a href="/wiki/Chief_Justice_of_Bangladesh" title="Chief Justice of Bangladesh">Chief Justice of Bangladesh</a>, who sits on the Supreme Court. The courts have wide latitude in <a href="/wiki/Judicial_review_in_Bangladesh" title="Judicial review in Bangladesh">judicial review</a>, and judicial <a href="/wiki/Precedent" title="Precedent">precedent</a> is supported by Article 111 of the constitution. The <a href="/wiki/Judiciary_of_Bangladesh" title="Judiciary of Bangladesh">judiciary</a> includes district and metropolitan courts divided into civil and criminal courts. Due to a shortage of judges, the judiciary has a large backlog. The <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh_Judicial_Service_Commission" title="Bangladesh Judicial Service Commission">Bangladesh Judicial Service Commission</a> is responsible for judicial appointments, salaries, and discipline.</li></ul>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Military">Military</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh_Armed_Forces" title="Bangladesh Armed Forces">Bangladesh Armed Forces</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Bangladesh_Army_FM90_Crotale_SAM._(38169460305).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1906" data-file-width="2909" decoding="async" height="144" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6a/Bangladesh_Army_FM90_Crotale_SAM._%2838169460305%29.jpg/220px-Bangladesh_Army_FM90_Crotale_SAM._%2838169460305%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6a/Bangladesh_Army_FM90_Crotale_SAM._%2838169460305%29.jpg/330px-Bangladesh_Army_FM90_Crotale_SAM._%2838169460305%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6a/Bangladesh_Army_FM90_Crotale_SAM._%2838169460305%29.jpg/440px-Bangladesh_Army_FM90_Crotale_SAM._%2838169460305%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Bangladesh_Army_FM90_Crotale_SAM._(38169460305).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Bangladesh's <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/FM-90" title="FM-90">FM-90</a> air defense missile system, modelled on the <a href="/wiki/Crotale_(missile)" title="Crotale (missile)">Crotale</a>.</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:262px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:BangladeshMilitaryUN_PeacekeepingForce.jpg"><img alt="World map, indicating where the Bangladeshi UN peacekeeping force is stationed" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="738" data-file-width="1178" decoding="async" height="163" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a6/BangladeshMilitaryUN_PeacekeepingForce.jpg/260px-BangladeshMilitaryUN_PeacekeepingForce.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a6/BangladeshMilitaryUN_PeacekeepingForce.jpg/390px-BangladeshMilitaryUN_PeacekeepingForce.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a6/BangladeshMilitaryUN_PeacekeepingForce.jpg/520px-BangladeshMilitaryUN_PeacekeepingForce.jpg 2x" width="260"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:BangladeshMilitaryUN_PeacekeepingForce.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Map of <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh_UN_Peacekeeping_Force" title="Bangladesh UN Peacekeeping Force">Bangladesh UN Peacekeeping Force</a> deployments.</div></div></div>
<p>The Bangladesh Armed Forces have inherited the institutional framework of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/British_military" title="British military">British military</a> and the <a href="/wiki/British_Indian_Army" title="British Indian Army">British Indian Army</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-223"><a href="#cite_note-223">[223]</a></sup> It was formed in 1971 from the military regiments of East Pakistan. In 2022, the active personnel strength of the <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh_Army" title="Bangladesh Army">Bangladesh Army</a> was around 250,000,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IISS_224-0"><a href="#cite_note-IISS-224">[224]</a></sup> excluding the Air Force and the Navy (24,000).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-225"><a href="#cite_note-225">[225]</a></sup> In addition to traditional defence roles, the military has supported civil authorities in disaster relief and provided internal security during periods of political unrest. For many years, Bangladesh has been the world's largest contributor to <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_peacekeeping" title="United Nations peacekeeping">UN peacekeeping forces</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Military_budget_of_Bangladesh" title="Military budget of Bangladesh">military budget of Bangladesh</a> accounts for 1.3% of GDP, amounting to US$4.3 billion in 2021.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-226"><a href="#cite_note-226">[226]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-227"><a href="#cite_note-227">[227]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh_Navy" title="Bangladesh Navy">Bangladesh Navy</a>, one of the largest in the Bay of Bengal, includes a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_active_ships_of_the_Bangladesh_Navy" title="List of active ships of the Bangladesh Navy">fleet</a> of frigates, submarines, corvettes and other vessels. The <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh_Air_Force" title="Bangladesh Air Force">Bangladesh Air Force</a> has a <a href="/wiki/List_of_active_Bangladesh_military_aircraft" title="List of active Bangladesh military aircraft">small fleet</a> of multi-role combat aircraft, including the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/MiG-29" title="MiG-29">MiG-29</a> and <a href="/wiki/Chengdu_J-7" title="Chengdu J-7">Chengdu-F7</a>. Most of Bangladesh's military equipment comes from China.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-228"><a href="#cite_note-228">[228]</a></sup>  In recent years, Bangladesh and India have increased joint military exercises, high level visits of military leaders, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Counter-terrorism" title="Counter-terrorism">counter-terrorism</a> cooperation and intelligence sharing. Bangladesh is vital to ensuring stability and security in <a href="/wiki/Northeast_India" title="Northeast India">northeast India</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-229"><a href="#cite_note-229">[229]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-230"><a href="#cite_note-230">[230]</a></sup>
</p><p>Bangladesh's strategic importance in the eastern subcontinent hinges on its proximity to China, its frontier with Burma, the separation of mainland and northeast India, and its maritime territory in the Bay of Bengal.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-231"><a href="#cite_note-231">[231]</a></sup> In 2002, Bangladesh and China signed a Defense Cooperation Agreement (DCA) which the governments of both countries said will "institutionalize the existing accords in defence sector and also to rationalize the existing piecemeal agreements to enhance cooperation in training, maintenance and in some areas of production".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-232"><a href="#cite_note-232">[232]</a></sup> The United States has pursued negotiations with Bangladesh on a <a href="/wiki/Status_of_forces_agreement" title="Status of forces agreement">Status of Forces Agreement</a>, an <a href="/wiki/Acquisition_and_Cross-Servicing_Agreement" title="Acquisition and Cross-Servicing Agreement">Acquisition and Cross-Servicing Agreement</a> and a General Security of Military Information Agreement.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-233"><a href="#cite_note-233">[233]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-234"><a href="#cite_note-234">[234]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-235"><a href="#cite_note-235">[235]</a></sup> In 2019, Bangladesh ratified the UN <a href="/wiki/Treaty_on_the_Prohibition_of_Nuclear_Weapons" title="Treaty on the Prohibition of Nuclear Weapons">Treaty on the Prohibition of Nuclear Weapons</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-236"><a href="#cite_note-236">[236]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Foreign_relations">Foreign relations</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Foreign_relations_of_Bangladesh" title="Foreign relations of Bangladesh">Foreign relations of Bangladesh</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Special_Presidential_Envoy_for_Climate_John_Kerry_Visits_Bangladesh_(51104953309).png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1280" data-file-width="1263" decoding="async" height="223" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7e/Special_Presidential_Envoy_for_Climate_John_Kerry_Visits_Bangladesh_%2851104953309%29.png/220px-Special_Presidential_Envoy_for_Climate_John_Kerry_Visits_Bangladesh_%2851104953309%29.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7e/Special_Presidential_Envoy_for_Climate_John_Kerry_Visits_Bangladesh_%2851104953309%29.png/330px-Special_Presidential_Envoy_for_Climate_John_Kerry_Visits_Bangladesh_%2851104953309%29.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7e/Special_Presidential_Envoy_for_Climate_John_Kerry_Visits_Bangladesh_%2851104953309%29.png/440px-Special_Presidential_Envoy_for_Climate_John_Kerry_Visits_Bangladesh_%2851104953309%29.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Special_Presidential_Envoy_for_Climate_John_Kerry_Visits_Bangladesh_(51104953309).png" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/U.S._Special_Presidential_Envoy_for_Climate" title="U.S. Special Presidential Envoy for Climate">U.S. Special Presidential Envoy for Climate</a> <a href="/wiki/John_Kerry" title="John Kerry">John Kerry</a> meeting Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina at her residence in Dhaka in April 2021</div></div></div>
<p>Bangladesh is considered a <a href="/wiki/Middle_power" title="Middle power">middle power</a> in <a href="/wiki/Global_politics" title="Global politics">global politics</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-237"><a href="#cite_note-237">[237]</a></sup> It plays an important role in the geopolitical affairs of the <a href="/wiki/Indo-Pacific" title="Indo-Pacific">Indo-Pacific</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-238"><a href="#cite_note-238">[238]</a></sup> due to its strategic location between South and Southeast Asia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-239"><a href="#cite_note-239">[239]</a></sup> Bangladesh joined the <a href="/wiki/Commonwealth_of_Nations" title="Commonwealth of Nations">Commonwealth of Nations</a> in 1972 and the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations" title="United Nations">United Nations</a> in 1974.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-240"><a href="#cite_note-240">[240]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-241"><a href="#cite_note-241">[241]</a></sup> It relies on <a href="/wiki/Multilateralism" title="Multilateralism">multilateral</a> diplomacy on issues like climate change, nuclear nonproliferation, trade policy and non-traditional security issues.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-242"><a href="#cite_note-242">[242]</a></sup> At the <a href="/wiki/World_Trade_Organization" title="World Trade Organization">WTO</a>, Bangladesh has used the dispute resolution mechanism to settle trade disputes with India and other countries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-243"><a href="#cite_note-243">[243]</a></sup> Bangladesh pioneered the creation of <a href="/wiki/South_Asian_Association_for_Regional_Cooperation" title="South Asian Association for Regional Cooperation">SAARC</a>, which has been the preeminent forum for regional diplomacy among the countries of the <a href="/wiki/Indian_subcontinent" title="Indian subcontinent">Indian subcontinent</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-244"><a href="#cite_note-244">[244]</a></sup> It joined the <a href="/wiki/Organisation_of_Islamic_Cooperation" title="Organisation of Islamic Cooperation">OIC</a>, an <a href="/wiki/Intergovernmental_organization" title="Intergovernmental organization">intergovernmental organization</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Muslim_world" title="Muslim world">Muslim world</a> in 1974,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-245"><a href="#cite_note-245">[245]</a></sup> and is a founding member of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Developing_8_Countries" title="Developing 8 Countries">Developing 8 Countries</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-246"><a href="#cite_note-246">[246]</a></sup> In recent years, Bangladesh has focused on promoting regional trade and transport links with support from the <a href="/wiki/World_Bank" title="World Bank">World Bank</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-247"><a href="#cite_note-247">[247]</a></sup> Dhaka hosts the headquarters of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/BIMSTEC" title="BIMSTEC">BIMSTEC</a>, an organization that brings together <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Countries_dependent_on_the_Bay_of_Bengal" title="Countries dependent on the Bay of Bengal">countries dependent on the Bay of Bengal</a>.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Bangladesh%E2%80%93Myanmar_relations" title="Bangladesh–Myanmar relations">Relations</a> with neighboring <a href="/wiki/Myanmar" title="Myanmar">Myanmar</a> have been severely strained since 2016–2017, after over 700,000 <a href="/wiki/Rohingya_refugees_in_Bangladesh" title="Rohingya refugees in Bangladesh">Rohingya refugees</a> illegally entered Bangladesh fleeing persecution, <a href="/wiki/Ethnic_cleansing" title="Ethnic cleansing">ethnic cleansing</a>, <a href="/wiki/Genocide" title="Genocide">genocide</a>, and other atrocities in their native state.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-RohingyaHRW_248-0"><a href="#cite_note-RohingyaHRW-248">[248]</a></sup> The parliament, government, and civil society of Bangladesh have been at the forefront of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/International_reaction_to_the_2016%E2%80%9317_Rohingya_exodus" title="International reaction to the 2016–17 Rohingya exodus">international criticism</a> against Myanmar for military operations against the Rohingya, and have demanded their <a href="/wiki/Right_of_return" title="Right of return">right of return</a> to <a href="/wiki/Arakan" title="Arakan">Arakan</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-249"><a href="#cite_note-249">[249]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-250"><a href="#cite_note-250">[250]</a></sup>
</p><p>Bangladesh shares an important <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh%E2%80%93India_relations" title="Bangladesh–India relations">bilateral and economic relationship</a> with its largest neighbor <a href="/wiki/India" title="India">India</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-251"><a href="#cite_note-251">[251]</a></sup> which is often strained by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Water_politics_in_India" title="Water politics in India">water politics</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Ganges_water_dispute" title="Ganges water dispute">Ganges</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Teesta_River#Water_sharing_challenge" title="Teesta River">Teesta</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-252"><a href="#cite_note-252">[252]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-253"><a href="#cite_note-253">[253]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Deaths_along_the_Bangladesh%E2%80%93India_border" title="Deaths along the Bangladesh–India border">border killings of Bangladeshi civilians</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-254"><a href="#cite_note-254">[254]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-255"><a href="#cite_note-255">[255]</a></sup> Post-independent Bangladesh has continued to have a problematic relationship with Pakistan, mainly due to its denial of the <a href="/wiki/1971_Bangladesh_genocide" title="1971 Bangladesh genocide">1971 Bangladesh genocide</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-256"><a href="#cite_note-256">[256]</a></sup> It maintains a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bangladesh-China_relations" title="Bangladesh-China relations">warm relationship</a> with <a href="/wiki/China" title="China">China</a>, which is its largest trading partner, and the largest arms supplier.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-257"><a href="#cite_note-257">[257]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Japan" title="Japan">Japan</a> is Bangladesh's largest economic aid provider, and the two maintain a <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh%E2%80%93Japan_relations" title="Bangladesh–Japan relations">strategic and economic partnership</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-258"><a href="#cite_note-258">[258]</a></sup> Political relations with Middle Eastern countries are robust.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-259"><a href="#cite_note-259">[259]</a></sup> Bangladesh receives 59% of its remittances from the Middle East,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-260"><a href="#cite_note-260">[260]</a></sup> despite poor working conditions affecting over 4 million <a href="/wiki/Bangladeshis_in_the_Middle_East" title="Bangladeshis in the Middle East">Bangladeshi workers</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-261"><a href="#cite_note-261">[261]</a></sup> Bangladesh plays a major role in <a href="/wiki/Climate_change" title="Climate change">global climate</a> diplomacy as a leader of the <a href="/wiki/Climate_Vulnerable_Forum" title="Climate Vulnerable Forum">Climate Vulnerable Forum</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-262"><a href="#cite_note-262">[262]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Civil_society">Civil society</span></h3>
<p>Since the colonial period, Bangladesh has had a prominent <a href="/wiki/Civil_society" title="Civil society">civil society</a>. There are various special interest groups, including <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Non-governmental_organisations" title="Non-governmental organisations">non-governmental organisations</a>, human rights organisations, professional associations, <a href="/wiki/Chamber_of_commerce" title="Chamber of commerce">chambers of commerce</a>, employers' associations and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Trade_unions" title="Trade unions">trade unions</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-263"><a href="#cite_note-263">[263]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/National_Human_Rights_Commission_of_Bangladesh" title="National Human Rights Commission of Bangladesh">National Human Rights Commission of Bangladesh</a> was set up in 2007. Notable human rights organisations and initiatives include the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Centre_for_Law_and_Mediation_(Bangladesh)" title="Centre for Law and Mediation (Bangladesh)">Centre for Law and Mediation</a>, <a href="/wiki/Odhikar" title="Odhikar">Odhikar</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Alliance_for_Bangladesh_Worker_Safety" title="Alliance for Bangladesh Worker Safety">Alliance for Bangladesh Worker Safety</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh_Environmental_Lawyers_Association" title="Bangladesh Environmental Lawyers Association">Bangladesh Environmental Lawyers Association</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh_Hindu_Buddhist_Christian_Unity_Council" title="Bangladesh Hindu Buddhist Christian Unity Council">Bangladesh Hindu Buddhist Christian Unity Council</a> and the <a href="/wiki/War_Crimes_Fact_Finding_Committee" title="War Crimes Fact Finding Committee">War Crimes Fact Finding Committee</a>. The world's largest international NGO <a href="/wiki/BRAC_(organisation)" title="BRAC (organisation)">BRAC</a> is based in Bangladesh. There have been concerns regarding the shrinking space for independent civil society in recent years,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-264"><a href="#cite_note-264">[264]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-265"><a href="#cite_note-265">[265]</a></sup> with commentators labelling the civil society movement dead under the authoritarianism of the Awami League.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-266"><a href="#cite_note-266">[266]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Human_rights">Human rights</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Human_rights_in_Bangladesh" title="Human rights in Bangladesh">Human rights in Bangladesh</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:R.A.B.jpg"><img alt="Armed men in black uniforms on a street" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="458" data-file-width="306" decoding="async" height="254" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a9/R.A.B.jpg/170px-R.A.B.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a9/R.A.B.jpg/255px-R.A.B.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/a/a9/R.A.B.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:R.A.B.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Rapid_Action_Battalion" title="Rapid Action Battalion">Rapid Action Battalion</a> has been sanctioned by the United States for human rights abuses</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Torture" title="Torture">Torture</a> is banned by Article 35 (5) of the <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Bangladesh" title="Constitution of Bangladesh">Constitution of Bangladesh</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-267"><a href="#cite_note-267">[267]</a></sup> Despite this constitutional ban, torture is rampantly used by Bangladesh's security forces. Bangladesh joined the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Convention_against_Torture" title="Convention against Torture">Convention against Torture</a> in 1998; but it enacted its first anti-torture law, the <a href="/wiki/Torture_and_Custodial_Death_(Prevention)_Act" title="Torture and Custodial Death (Prevention) Act">Torture and Custodial Death (Prevention) Act</a>, in 2013. The first conviction under this law was announced in 2020.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-268"><a href="#cite_note-268">[268]</a></sup> Amnesty International <a href="/wiki/Prisoner_of_conscience" title="Prisoner of conscience">Prisoners of Conscience</a> from Bangladesh have included <a href="/wiki/Saber_Hossain_Chowdhury" title="Saber Hossain Chowdhury">Saber Hossain Chowdhury</a> and <a href="/wiki/Shahidul_Alam" title="Shahidul Alam">Shahidul Alam</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-269"><a href="#cite_note-269">[269]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-270"><a href="#cite_note-270">[270]</a></sup> The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Digital_Security_Act" title="Digital Security Act">Digital Security Act</a> of 2018 has greatly reduced <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Freedom_of_expression" title="Freedom of expression">freedom of expression</a> in Bangladesh, particularly on the internet. The Digital Security Act has been used to target critics of the government and bureaucracy. Newspaper editorials have been demanding the repeal of the Digital Security Act.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-271"><a href="#cite_note-271">[271]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-272"><a href="#cite_note-272">[272]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-273"><a href="#cite_note-273">[273]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-274"><a href="#cite_note-274">[274]</a></sup>
</p><p>On <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/International_Human_Rights_Day" title="International Human Rights Day">International Human Rights Day</a> in December 2021, the United States <a href="/wiki/United_States_Department_of_the_Treasury" title="United States Department of the Treasury">Department of Treasury</a> announced <a href="/wiki/Economic_sanctions" title="Economic sanctions">sanctions</a> on commanders of the <a href="/wiki/Rapid_Action_Battalion" title="Rapid Action Battalion">Rapid Action Battalion</a> for extrajudicial killings, torture and other human rights abuses.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-275"><a href="#cite_note-275">[275]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Freedom_House" title="Freedom House">Freedom House</a> has criticised the ruling party for human rights abuses, crackdown on opposition, mass media, and civil society through politicized enforcement.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-276"><a href="#cite_note-276">[276]</a></sup> Bangladesh is ranked "partly free" in <a href="/wiki/Freedom_House" title="Freedom House">Freedom House</a>'s <i><a href="/wiki/Freedom_in_the_World" title="Freedom in the World">Freedom in the World</a></i> report,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-277"><a href="#cite_note-277">[277]</a></sup> but its <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Press_freedom" title="Press freedom">press freedom</a> has deteriorated from "free" to "not free" in recent years due to increasing pressure from the authoritarian government.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-278"><a href="#cite_note-278">[278]</a></sup> According to the British <a href="/wiki/Economist_Intelligence_Unit" title="Economist Intelligence Unit">Economist Intelligence Unit</a>, the country has a <a href="/wiki/Hybrid_regime" title="Hybrid regime">hybrid regime</a>: the third of four rankings in its <a href="/wiki/Democracy_Index" title="Democracy Index">Democracy Index</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-279"><a href="#cite_note-279">[279]</a></sup> Bangladesh was ranked 96th among 163 countries in the 2022 <a href="/wiki/Global_Peace_Index" title="Global Peace Index">Global Peace Index</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-280"><a href="#cite_note-280">[280]</a></sup> According to National Human Rights Commission, 70% of alleged human-rights violations are committed by law-enforcement agencies.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-281"><a href="#cite_note-281">[281]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/LGBT_rights_in_Bangladesh" title="LGBT rights in Bangladesh">LGBT rights</a> are heavily suppressed by both government and society,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-282"><a href="#cite_note-282">[282]</a></sup> as <a href="/wiki/Homosexuality" title="Homosexuality">homosexuality</a> is outlawed by section 377 of the criminal code (a legacy of the colonial period), and is punishable by a maximum of life imprisonment.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-283"><a href="#cite_note-283">[283]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-284"><a href="#cite_note-284">[284]</a></sup> However, Bangladesh recognises the <a href="/wiki/Third_gender" title="Third gender">third gender</a> and accords limited rights for <a href="/wiki/Transgender" title="Transgender">transgender</a> people.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-285"><a href="#cite_note-285">[285]</a></sup> According to the 2016 Global Slavery Index, an estimated 1,531,300 people are enslaved in Bangladesh, or roughly 1% of the population.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-286"><a href="#cite_note-286">[286]</a></sup> A number of slaves in Bangladesh are forced to work in the fish and shrimp industries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-287"><a href="#cite_note-287">[287]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-288"><a href="#cite_note-288">[288]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-289"><a href="#cite_note-289">[289]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Corruption">Corruption</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Corruption_in_Bangladesh" title="Corruption in Bangladesh">Corruption in Bangladesh</a></div>
<p>Like for many developing countries, institutional corruption is a serious concern for Bangladesh. Bangladesh was ranked 146th among 180 countries on <a href="/wiki/Transparency_International" title="Transparency International">Transparency International</a>'s 2018 <a href="/wiki/Corruption_Perceptions_Index" title="Corruption Perceptions Index">Corruption Perceptions Index</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-290"><a href="#cite_note-290">[290]</a></sup> According to survey conducted by the Bangladesh chapter of TI, in 2015, bribes made up 3.7 percent of the national budget.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:3_291-0"><a href="#cite_note-:3-291">[291]</a></sup> Land administration was the sector with the most bribery in 2015,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:3_291-1"><a href="#cite_note-:3-291">[291]</a></sup> followed by education,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-292"><a href="#cite_note-292">[292]</a></sup> police<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-293"><a href="#cite_note-293">[293]</a></sup>
and water supply.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-294"><a href="#cite_note-294">[294]</a></sup> The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Anti_Corruption_Commission_Bangladesh" title="Anti Corruption Commission Bangladesh">Anti Corruption Commission</a> was formed in 2004, and it was active during the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/2006%E2%80%9308_Bangladeshi_political_crisis" title="2006–08 Bangladeshi political crisis">2006–08 Bangladeshi political crisis</a>, indicting many leading politicians, bureaucrats and businessmen for <a href="/wiki/Graft_(politics)" title="Graft (politics)">graft</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-295"><a href="#cite_note-295">[295]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-296"><a href="#cite_note-296">[296]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-297"><a href="#cite_note-297">[297]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Economy">Economy</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Bangladesh" title="Economy of Bangladesh">Economy of Bangladesh</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:%E0%A6%89%E0%A6%A6%E0%A7%8D%E0%A6%AC%E0%A7%8B%E0%A6%A7%E0%A6%A8%E0%A7%87%E0%A6%B0_%E0%A6%86%E0%A6%97%E0%A7%87%E0%A6%B0_%E0%A6%A6%E0%A6%BF%E0%A6%A8%E0%A7%87_%E0%A6%AA%E0%A6%A6%E0%A7%8D%E0%A6%AE%E0%A6%BE_%E0%A6%B8%E0%A7%87%E0%A6%A4%E0%A7%81.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3114" data-file-width="5467" decoding="async" height="125" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ee/%E0%A6%89%E0%A6%A6%E0%A7%8D%E0%A6%AC%E0%A7%8B%E0%A6%A7%E0%A6%A8%E0%A7%87%E0%A6%B0_%E0%A6%86%E0%A6%97%E0%A7%87%E0%A6%B0_%E0%A6%A6%E0%A6%BF%E0%A6%A8%E0%A7%87_%E0%A6%AA%E0%A6%A6%E0%A7%8D%E0%A6%AE%E0%A6%BE_%E0%A6%B8%E0%A7%87%E0%A6%A4%E0%A7%81.jpg/220px-%E0%A6%89%E0%A6%A6%E0%A7%8D%E0%A6%AC%E0%A7%8B%E0%A6%A7%E0%A6%A8%E0%A7%87%E0%A6%B0_%E0%A6%86%E0%A6%97%E0%A7%87%E0%A6%B0_%E0%A6%A6%E0%A6%BF%E0%A6%A8%E0%A7%87_%E0%A6%AA%E0%A6%A6%E0%A7%8D%E0%A6%AE%E0%A6%BE_%E0%A6%B8%E0%A7%87%E0%A6%A4%E0%A7%81.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ee/%E0%A6%89%E0%A6%A6%E0%A7%8D%E0%A6%AC%E0%A7%8B%E0%A6%A7%E0%A6%A8%E0%A7%87%E0%A6%B0_%E0%A6%86%E0%A6%97%E0%A7%87%E0%A6%B0_%E0%A6%A6%E0%A6%BF%E0%A6%A8%E0%A7%87_%E0%A6%AA%E0%A6%A6%E0%A7%8D%E0%A6%AE%E0%A6%BE_%E0%A6%B8%E0%A7%87%E0%A6%A4%E0%A7%81.jpg/330px-%E0%A6%89%E0%A6%A6%E0%A7%8D%E0%A6%AC%E0%A7%8B%E0%A6%A7%E0%A6%A8%E0%A7%87%E0%A6%B0_%E0%A6%86%E0%A6%97%E0%A7%87%E0%A6%B0_%E0%A6%A6%E0%A6%BF%E0%A6%A8%E0%A7%87_%E0%A6%AA%E0%A6%A6%E0%A7%8D%E0%A6%AE%E0%A6%BE_%E0%A6%B8%E0%A7%87%E0%A6%A4%E0%A7%81.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ee/%E0%A6%89%E0%A6%A6%E0%A7%8D%E0%A6%AC%E0%A7%8B%E0%A6%A7%E0%A6%A8%E0%A7%87%E0%A6%B0_%E0%A6%86%E0%A6%97%E0%A7%87%E0%A6%B0_%E0%A6%A6%E0%A6%BF%E0%A6%A8%E0%A7%87_%E0%A6%AA%E0%A6%A6%E0%A7%8D%E0%A6%AE%E0%A6%BE_%E0%A6%B8%E0%A7%87%E0%A6%A4%E0%A7%81.jpg/440px-%E0%A6%89%E0%A6%A6%E0%A7%8D%E0%A6%AC%E0%A7%8B%E0%A6%A7%E0%A6%A8%E0%A7%87%E0%A6%B0_%E0%A6%86%E0%A6%97%E0%A7%87%E0%A6%B0_%E0%A6%A6%E0%A6%BF%E0%A6%A8%E0%A7%87_%E0%A6%AA%E0%A6%A6%E0%A7%8D%E0%A6%AE%E0%A6%BE_%E0%A6%B8%E0%A7%87%E0%A6%A4%E0%A7%81.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:%E0%A6%89%E0%A6%A6%E0%A7%8D%E0%A6%AC%E0%A7%8B%E0%A6%A7%E0%A6%A8%E0%A7%87%E0%A6%B0_%E0%A6%86%E0%A6%97%E0%A7%87%E0%A6%B0_%E0%A6%A6%E0%A6%BF%E0%A6%A8%E0%A7%87_%E0%A6%AA%E0%A6%A6%E0%A7%8D%E0%A6%AE%E0%A6%BE_%E0%A6%B8%E0%A7%87%E0%A6%A4%E0%A7%81.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Padma_Bridge" title="Padma Bridge">Padma Bridge</a> spans the Bangladeshi branch of the <a href="/wiki/Ganges" title="Ganges">Ganges</a>, which is known as the <a href="/wiki/Padma_River" title="Padma River">Padma River</a>. It is the longest bridge on the Ganges. When it was opened in June 2022, the bridge was expected to boost GDP by 1.23%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-298"><a href="#cite_note-298">[298]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Bangladesh_Product_Exports_(2019).svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="715" data-file-width="1100" decoding="async" height="143" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/14/Bangladesh_Product_Exports_%282019%29.svg/220px-Bangladesh_Product_Exports_%282019%29.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/14/Bangladesh_Product_Exports_%282019%29.svg/330px-Bangladesh_Product_Exports_%282019%29.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/14/Bangladesh_Product_Exports_%282019%29.svg/440px-Bangladesh_Product_Exports_%282019%29.svg.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Bangladesh_Product_Exports_(2019).svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A proportional representation of Bangladesh's exports (2019)</div></div></div>
<p>Bangladesh is the second largest economy in South Asia after India.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-299"><a href="#cite_note-299">[299]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-scroll.in_300-0"><a href="#cite_note-scroll.in-300">[300]</a></sup> The country has outpaced India (of which it was a part until 1947) and Pakistan (of which it was a part until 1971) in terms of per capita income.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-301"><a href="#cite_note-301">[301]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-scroll.in_300-1"><a href="#cite_note-scroll.in-300">[300]</a></sup> According to the <a href="/wiki/World_Bank" title="World Bank">World Bank</a>, "When the newly independent country of Bangladesh was born on December 16, 1971, it was the second poorest country in the world—making the country's transformation over the next 50 years one of the great development stories. Since then, poverty has been cut in half at record speed. Enrollment in primary school is now nearly universal. Hundreds of thousands of women have entered the workforce. Steady progress has been made on maternal and child health. And the country is better buttressed against the destructive forces posed by climate change and natural disasters. Bangladesh’s success comprises many moving parts—from investing in human capital to establishing macroeconomic stability. Building on this success, the country is now setting the stage for further economic growth and job creation by ramping up investments in energy, inland connectivity, urban projects, and transport infrastructure, as well as prioritizing climate change adaptation and disaster preparedness on its path toward sustainable growth".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-302"><a href="#cite_note-302">[302]</a></sup>
</p><p>Since 2009, Bangladesh has embarked on a series of <a href="/wiki/List_of_megaprojects_in_Bangladesh" title="List of megaprojects in Bangladesh">megaprojects</a>. The 6.15 km long Padma Bridge was built at a cost of US$3.86 billion.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-303"><a href="#cite_note-303">[303]</a></sup> The bridge was the first self-financed megaproject in the country's history.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-304"><a href="#cite_note-304">[304]</a></sup> Other megaprojects include the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Dhaka_Metro" title="Dhaka Metro">Dhaka Metro</a>, <a href="/wiki/Karnaphuli_Tunnel" title="Karnaphuli Tunnel">Karnaphuli Tunnel</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dhaka_Elevated_Expressway" title="Dhaka Elevated Expressway">Dhaka Elevated Expressway</a> and <a href="/wiki/Chittagong_Elevated_Expressway" title="Chittagong Elevated Expressway">Chittagong Elevated Expressway</a>; as well as the <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh_Delta_Plan" title="Bangladesh Delta Plan">Bangladesh Delta Plan</a> to mitigate the impact of climate change. Overseas remittances from expat Bangladeshis and export earnings from the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bangladesh_textile_industry" title="Bangladesh textile industry">Bangladesh textile industry</a> have allowed the country to have the second largest <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_foreign_exchange_reserves" title="List of countries by foreign exchange reserves">foreign-exchange reserves</a> in South Asia. The reserves have boosted the government's spending capacity in spite of tax revenues forming only 7.7% of government revenue.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-trade.gov_305-0"><a href="#cite_note-trade.gov-305">[305]</a></sup> A big chunk of investments have gone into the <a href="/wiki/Electric_power" title="Electric power">power</a> sector. In 2009, Bangladesh was experiencing daily blackouts several times a day. In 2022, the country achieved 100% electrification.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-306"><a href="#cite_note-306">[306]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-307"><a href="#cite_note-307">[307]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-308"><a href="#cite_note-308">[308]</a></sup>
</p><p>The private sector accounts for 80% of GDP in comparison to the dwindling role of state-owned companies.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-309"><a href="#cite_note-309">[309]</a></sup> Bangladesh's economy is dominated by family-owned <a href="/wiki/List_of_companies_of_Bangladesh" title="List of companies of Bangladesh">conglomerates</a> and small and medium sized businesses. Capital markets include the <a href="/wiki/Dhaka_Stock_Exchange" title="Dhaka Stock Exchange">Dhaka Stock Exchange</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Chittagong_Stock_Exchange" title="Chittagong Stock Exchange">Chittagong Stock Exchange</a>. Its <a href="/wiki/Telecommunications_in_Bangladesh" title="Telecommunications in Bangladesh">telecommunications industry</a> is one of the world's fastest growing, with 171.854 million cellphone subscribers in January 2021.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-310"><a href="#cite_note-310">[310]</a></sup> Over 80% of the export earnings are from the <a href="/wiki/Textile_industry_in_Bangladesh" title="Textile industry in Bangladesh">textile industry</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bdarea_7-5"><a href="#cite_note-bdarea-7">[7]</a></sup> Other major industries include <a href="/wiki/Shipbuilding_in_Bangladesh" title="Shipbuilding in Bangladesh">shipbuilding</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pharmaceutical_industry_in_Bangladesh" title="Pharmaceutical industry in Bangladesh">pharmaceuticals</a>, <a href="/wiki/Steel_industry_in_Bangladesh" title="Steel industry in Bangladesh">steel</a>, <a href="/wiki/Electronics_industry_in_Bangladesh" title="Electronics industry in Bangladesh">electronics</a> and <a href="/wiki/Leather_industry_in_Bangladesh" title="Leather industry in Bangladesh">leather goods</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-311"><a href="#cite_note-311">[311]</a></sup>
</p><p>The poverty rate has gone down from 80% in 1971,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-312"><a href="#cite_note-312">[312]</a></sup> to 44.2% in 1991,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-313"><a href="#cite_note-313">[313]</a></sup> to 12.9% in 2021.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-314"><a href="#cite_note-314">[314]</a></sup> The literacy rate stood at 74.66% in 2022.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-315"><a href="#cite_note-315">[315]</a></sup> Bangladesh has a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Labor_force" title="Labor force">labor force</a> of roughly 70 million,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-316"><a href="#cite_note-316">[316]</a></sup> which is the world's <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_labour_force" title="List of countries by labour force">seventh-largest</a>; with an unemployment rate of 5.2% as of 2021<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Bangladesh&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-317"><a href="#cite_note-317">[317]</a></sup> The government is setting up 100 special economic zones to attract <a href="/wiki/Foreign_direct_investment" title="Foreign direct investment">foreign direct investment</a> (FDI) and generate 10 million jobs.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-318"><a href="#cite_note-318">[318]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh_Investment_Development_Authority" title="Bangladesh Investment Development Authority">Bangladesh Investment Development Authority</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh_Economic_Zones_Authority" title="Bangladesh Economic Zones Authority">Bangladesh Economic Zones Authority</a> have been established to help investors in setting up factories.
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Bangladeshi_taka" title="Bangladeshi taka">Bangladeshi taka</a> is the national currency. The service sector accounts for about 51.3% of total GDP and employs 39% of the workforce. The industrial sector accounts for 35.1% of GDP and employs 20.4% of the workforce. The <a href="/wiki/Agriculture_in_Bangladesh" title="Agriculture in Bangladesh">agriculture sector</a> makes up 13.6% of the economy but is the biggest employment sector, with 40.6% of the workforce.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-trade.gov_305-1"><a href="#cite_note-trade.gov-305">[305]</a></sup> In agriculture, the country is a major producer of <a href="/wiki/Rice_production_in_Bangladesh" title="Rice production in Bangladesh">rice</a>, <a href="/wiki/List_of_fishes_in_Bangladesh" title="List of fishes in Bangladesh">fish</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tea_production_in_Bangladesh" title="Tea production in Bangladesh">tea</a>, fruits, vegetables, flowers,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-319"><a href="#cite_note-319">[319]</a></sup> and jute. <a href="/wiki/Lobster" title="Lobster">Lobsters</a> and <a href="/wiki/Shrimp" title="Shrimp">shrimps</a> are some of Bangladesh's well known exports.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-320"><a href="#cite_note-320">[320]</a></sup>
</p><p>Bangladesh is gradually transitioning to a <a href="/wiki/Green_economy" title="Green economy">green economy</a>. Currently, it has the largest off-grid solar power program in the world, benefiting 20 million people.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-321"><a href="#cite_note-321">[321]</a></sup> An <a href="/wiki/Electric_car" title="Electric car">electric car</a> called the <i>Palki</i> is being developed for production in the country.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-322"><a href="#cite_note-322">[322]</a></sup> The government has reduced tariffs for the purchase of electric cars.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-323"><a href="#cite_note-323">[323]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Biogas" title="Biogas">Biogas</a> is being used to produce organic fertilizer.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-324"><a href="#cite_note-324">[324]</a></sup>
</p><p>Bangladesh continues to have huge untapped reserves of <a href="/wiki/Natural_gas" title="Natural gas">natural gas</a>, particularly in its maritime territory in the Bay of Bengal.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-325"><a href="#cite_note-325">[325]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-326"><a href="#cite_note-326">[326]</a></sup> The success ratio of finding gas wells in the country stands at 3:5:1, meaning one commercial deposit is found in every three explored zones.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-auto6_327-0"><a href="#cite_note-auto6-327">[327]</a></sup> The success ratio is well above the global average.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-auto6_327-1"><a href="#cite_note-auto6-327">[327]</a></sup> A lack of exploration and decreasing proven reserves have forced Bangladesh to import <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/LNG" title="LNG">LNG</a> from abroad, despite having substantially untapped gas reserves.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-328"><a href="#cite_note-328">[328]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-329"><a href="#cite_note-329">[329]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-330"><a href="#cite_note-330">[330]</a></sup> Gas shortages were further exasperated by the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Russia-Ukraine_War" title="Russia-Ukraine War">Russia-Ukraine War</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-331"><a href="#cite_note-331">[331]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Tourism_in_Bangladesh" title="Tourism in Bangladesh">tourism industry</a> is expanding, contributing some 3.02% of total GDP.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-332"><a href="#cite_note-332">[332]</a></sup> Bangladesh's international tourism receipts in 2019 amounted to $391 million.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-333"><a href="#cite_note-333">[333]</a></sup> The country has <a href="/wiki/List_of_World_Heritage_Sites_in_Bangladesh" title="List of World Heritage Sites in Bangladesh">three UNESCO World Heritage Sites</a> (<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Historic_Mosque_City_of_Bagerhat" title="Historic Mosque City of Bagerhat">the Mosque City</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ruins_of_the_Buddhist_Vihara_at_Paharpur" title="Ruins of the Buddhist Vihara at Paharpur">the Buddhist Vihara</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Sundarbans" title="Sundarbans">Sundarbans</a>) and five <a href="/wiki/World_Heritage_Site#Nominating_process" title="World Heritage Site">tentative-list</a> sites.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-334"><a href="#cite_note-334">[334]</a></sup> Activities for tourists include <a href="/wiki/Angling" title="Angling">angling</a>, <a href="/wiki/Water_skiing" title="Water skiing">water skiing</a>, river cruising, hiking, <a href="/wiki/Rowing_(sport)" title="Rowing (sport)">rowing</a>, <a href="/wiki/Yachting" title="Yachting">yachting</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Sea_bathing" title="Sea bathing">sea bathing</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-lp_335-0"><a href="#cite_note-lp-335">[335]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-lp_web_336-0"><a href="#cite_note-lp_web-336">[336]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/World_Travel_and_Tourism_Council" title="World Travel and Tourism Council">World Travel and Tourism Council</a> (WTTC) reported in 2019 that the travel and tourism industry in Bangladesh directly generated 1,180,500 jobs in 2018 or 1.9% of the country's total employment.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2019_report_337-0"><a href="#cite_note-2019_report-337">[337]</a></sup> According to the same report, Bangladesh experiences around 125,000 international tourist arrivals per year.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2019_report_337-1"><a href="#cite_note-2019_report-337">[337]</a></sup> Domestic spending generated 97.7 percent of direct travel and tourism gross domestic product (GDP) in 2012.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2013_report_338-0"><a href="#cite_note-2013_report-338">[338]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Electricity_sector">Electricity sector</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Electricity_sector_in_Bangladesh" title="Electricity sector in Bangladesh">Electricity sector in Bangladesh</a>, <a href="/wiki/Energy_policy_of_Bangladesh" title="Energy policy of Bangladesh">Energy policy of Bangladesh</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh_Power_Development_Board" title="Bangladesh Power Development Board">Bangladesh Power Development Board</a>, <a href="/wiki/Natural_gas_and_petroleum_in_Bangladesh" title="Natural gas and petroleum in Bangladesh">Natural gas and petroleum in Bangladesh</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Petrobangla" title="Petrobangla">Petrobangla</a></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/List_of_government-owned_companies_of_Bangladesh" title="List of government-owned companies of Bangladesh">Government-owned companies in Bangladesh</a> produce about half of the electricity generated there. The country produced 5 gigawatts in 2009 to around 25.5 gigawatts in 2022 and plan to produce up to 50 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gigawatts" title="Gigawatts">gigawatts</a> by 2041. U.S. companies supply around 55% of Bangladesh’s domestic natural gas production and are among the largest investors in power projects.  80% of Bangladesh’s installed gas-fired power generation capacity comes from turbines manufactured in the United States.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-339"><a href="#cite_note-339">[339]</a></sup>
</p><p>On 4 October 2022 70-80% of the countries 168 million residence were hit with blackouts and only 45% of residences were restored with power by nightfall. There was a shortage of natural gas because of the <a href="/wiki/2021%E2%80%93present_global_energy_crisis" title="2021–present global energy crisis">2021–present global energy crisis</a> where 77 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Natural_gas_power_plant" title="Natural gas power plant">natural gas power plants</a> had insufficient fuel to meet demand. The <a href="/wiki/Electricity_sector_in_Bangladesh" title="Electricity sector in Bangladesh">electricity sector in Bangladesh</a> is heavily reliant on natural gas.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-340"><a href="#cite_note-340">[340]</a></sup>
The government stopped buying <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Spot_price" title="Spot price">spot price</a> <a href="/wiki/Liquefied_natural_gas" title="Liquefied natural gas">Liquefied natural gas</a> in June 2022, they were importing 30% of their LNG on the spot market this year down from 40% last year. They are still importing LNG on <a href="/wiki/Futures_exchange" title="Futures exchange">futures exchange</a> markets.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-341"><a href="#cite_note-341">[341]</a></sup> The Government of Bangladesh <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Subsidized" title="Subsidized">subsidized</a> energy and LNG imports of $4.6 billion last fiscal year and plan to spend $9.4 billion this fiscal year, they are putting tariffs on the imports of LNG to try and help subsidize the expensive cost.  Since October 2021 they have been importing LNG for between US$30-37 per million <a href="/wiki/British_thermal_unit" title="British thermal unit">Btu</a> which is 10 times the price they were paying May 2020.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-342"><a href="#cite_note-342">[342]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Demographics">Demographics</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Demographics_of_Bangladesh" title="Demographics of Bangladesh">Demographics of Bangladesh</a> and <a href="/wiki/Bengalis" title="Bengalis">Bengalis</a></div>
<table class="toccolours" style="width:15em;border-top-width:0;border-spacing: 0;float:right;clear:right;margin:0.5em 0 1em 0.5em;"><caption style="border-top:1px #aaa solid;border-left:1px #aaa solid;border-right:1px #aaa solid;background-color:lavender;padding:0.25em;font-weight:bold">Population (millions)</caption><tbody><tr style="font-size:95%"><th style="border-bottom:1px solid black;padding:1px;width:3em">Year</th><th style="border-bottom:1px solid black;padding:1px 2px;text-align:right"><abbr title="Population">Pop.</abbr></th><th style="border-bottom:1px solid black;padding:1px;text-align:right"><abbr title="Per annum growth rate">±% p.a.</abbr></th></tr><tr><th style="text-align:center;padding:1px">1971 </th><td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">67,800,000</td><td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">—    </td></tr><tr><th style="text-align:center;padding:1px">1980 </th><td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">80,600,000</td><td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">+1.94%</td></tr><tr><th style="text-align:center;padding:1px">1990 </th><td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">105,300,001</td><td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">+2.71%</td></tr><tr><th style="text-align:center;padding:1px">2000 </th><td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">129,600,000</td><td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">+2.10%</td></tr><tr><th style="text-align:center;padding:1px;border-bottom:1px solid #bbbbbb">2010</th><td style="text-align:right;padding:1px;border-bottom:1px solid #bbbbbb">148,700,000</td><td style="text-align:right;padding:1px;border-bottom:1px solid #bbbbbb">+1.38%</td></tr><tr><th style="text-align:center;padding:1px">2012</th><td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">161,100,200</td><td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">+4.09%</td></tr><tr><th style="text-align:center;padding:1px">2022</th><td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">165,160,000</td><td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">+0.25%</td></tr><tr><td colspan="3" style="border-top:1px solid black;font-size:85%;text-align:left">Source: OECD/World Bank<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IEApop2011_343-0"><a href="#cite_note-IEApop2011-343">[343]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-dhakatribune1_6-1"><a href="#cite_note-dhakatribune1-6">[6]</a></sup></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>According to the <a href="/wiki/2022_Census_of_Bangladesh" title="2022 Census of Bangladesh">2022 Census</a>, Bangladesh has a population of 165.1 million,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-populationcensus2022_8-1"><a href="#cite_note-populationcensus2022-8">[8]</a></sup> and is the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_population" title="List of countries by population">eighth-most-populous country</a> in the world, the <a href="/wiki/List_of_Asian_countries_by_population" title="List of Asian countries by population">fifth-most populous country</a> in Asia, and the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_and_dependencies_by_population_density" title="List of countries and dependencies by population density">most densely populated large country</a> in the world, with a headline <a href="/wiki/Population_density" title="Population density">population density</a> of 1,265 people/km<sup>2</sup> as of 2020<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Bangladesh&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-344"><a href="#cite_note-344">[344]</a></sup> Its <a href="/wiki/Total_fertility_rate" title="Total fertility rate">total fertility rate</a> (TFR), once among the highest in the world, has experienced a dramatic decline, from 5.5 in 1985, to 3.7 in 1995, all the way down to 2.0 in 2020,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-345"><a href="#cite_note-345">[345]</a></sup> which is below the <a href="/wiki/Sub-replacement_fertility" title="Sub-replacement fertility">sub-replacement fertility</a> of 2.1; due to the government promoting <a href="/wiki/Birth_control" title="Birth control">birth control</a> since the 1980s and increased education attainment of females.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-346"><a href="#cite_note-346">[346]</a></sup> The vast majority of Bangladeshis live in <a href="/wiki/Rural_area" title="Rural area">rural areas</a>, with only 39% of the population living in <a href="/wiki/Urban_area" title="Urban area">urban areas</a> as of 2021<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Bangladesh&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-347"><a href="#cite_note-347">[347]</a></sup> It has a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Median_age" title="Median age">median age</a> of roughly 28 years, and its population is relatively young, with 26% of the total population aged 14 or younger,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-348"><a href="#cite_note-348">[348]</a></sup> and merely 5% aged 65 and above.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-349"><a href="#cite_note-349">[349]</a></sup>
</p><p>Bangladesh is a <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_ranked_by_ethnic_and_cultural_diversity_level" title="List of countries ranked by ethnic and cultural diversity level">ethnically and culturally homogeneous society</a>, as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bengali_people" title="Bengali people">Bengalis</a> form 99% of the population.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-dhakatribune1_6-2"><a href="#cite_note-dhakatribune1-6">[6]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Adivasi" title="Adivasi">Adivasi</a> population includes the <a href="/wiki/Chakma_people" title="Chakma people">Chakmas</a>, <a href="/wiki/Marma_people" title="Marma people">Marmas</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Santhal_people" title="Santhal people">Santhals</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mru_people_(Mrucha)" title="Mru people (Mrucha)">Mros</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tanchangya_people" title="Tanchangya people">Tanchangyas</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bawm_people" title="Bawm people">Bawms</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tripuri_people" title="Tripuri people">Tripuris</a>, <a href="/wiki/Khasi_people" title="Khasi people">Khasis</a>, <a href="/wiki/Khumi_people" title="Khumi people">Khumis</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kuki_people" title="Kuki people">Kukis</a>, <a href="/wiki/Garo_people" title="Garo people">Garos</a>, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bisnupriya_Manipuri_people" title="Bisnupriya Manipuri people">Bisnupriya Manipuris</a>. The Chittagong Hill Tracts region experienced unrest and an <a href="/wiki/Chittagong_Hill_Tracts_conflict" title="Chittagong Hill Tracts conflict">insurgency</a> from 1975 to 1997 in an autonomy movement by its indigenous people. Although a peace accord was signed in 1997, the region remains militarised.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-rashiduzzaman_350-0"><a href="#cite_note-rashiduzzaman-350">[350]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Urdu" title="Urdu">Urdu</a>-speaking <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Stranded_Pakistanis" title="Stranded Pakistanis">standed Pakistanis</a> were given citizenship by the Supreme Court in 2008.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-351"><a href="#cite_note-351">[351]</a></sup> Bangladesh also hosts over 700,000 Rohingya refugees since 2017, giving it one of the largest refugee populations in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-RohingyaHRW_248-1"><a href="#cite_note-RohingyaHRW-248">[248]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Urban_centres">Urban centres</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/List_of_cities_and_towns_in_Bangladesh" title="List of cities and towns in Bangladesh">List of cities and towns in Bangladesh</a></div>
<p>Dhaka is Bangladesh's capital and largest city and is overseen by two city corporations who manage between them the northern and southern part of the city. There are 12 <a href="/wiki/List_of_City_Corporations_of_Bangladesh" title="List of City Corporations of Bangladesh">city corporations</a> which hold mayoral elections: Dhaka South, Dhaka North, Chittagong, <a href="/wiki/Comilla" title="Comilla">Comilla</a>, <a href="/wiki/Khulna" title="Khulna">Khulna</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mymensingh" title="Mymensingh">Mymensingh</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sylhet" title="Sylhet">Sylhet</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rajshahi" title="Rajshahi">Rajshahi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Barisal" title="Barisal">Barisal</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rangpur,_Bangladesh" title="Rangpur, Bangladesh">Rangpur</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gazipur,_Dhaka_Division" title="Gazipur, Dhaka Division">Gazipur</a> and <a href="/wiki/Narayanganj" title="Narayanganj">Narayanganj</a>. Mayors are elected for five-year terms. Altogether there are 506 urban centres in Bangladesh among which 43 cities have a population of more than 100,000.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-352"><a href="#cite_note-352">[352]</a></sup>
</p>
<div>

<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Language">Language</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Languages_of_Bangladesh" title="Languages of Bangladesh">Languages of Bangladesh</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Chakma_Letter-Biplob_Rahman.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="453" data-file-width="604" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/10/Chakma_Letter-Biplob_Rahman.jpg/220px-Chakma_Letter-Biplob_Rahman.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/10/Chakma_Letter-Biplob_Rahman.jpg/330px-Chakma_Letter-Biplob_Rahman.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/10/Chakma_Letter-Biplob_Rahman.jpg/440px-Chakma_Letter-Biplob_Rahman.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Chakma_Letter-Biplob_Rahman.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Chakma_script" title="Chakma script">Chakma alphabets</a> are indigenous to the Chittagong Hill Tracts</div></div></div>
<p>The official and predominant language of Bangladesh is <a href="/wiki/Bengali_language" title="Bengali language">Bengali</a>, which is spoken by more than 98% of the population as their <a href="/wiki/First_language" title="First language">native language</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-LOG_353-0"><a href="#cite_note-LOG-353">[353]</a></sup> It is among the easternmost branches of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Indo-European_language" title="Indo-European language">Indo-European language</a> family, and is a part of the <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Indo-Aryan_languages" title="Eastern Indo-Aryan languages">Eastern Indo-Aryan languages</a>, which developed between the 10th and 13th centuries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-354"><a href="#cite_note-354">[354]</a></sup> Bengali is described as a <a href="/wiki/Dialect_continuum" title="Dialect continuum">dialect continuum</a> where there are various <a href="/wiki/Bengali_dialects" title="Bengali dialects">dialects</a> spoken throughout the country. There is a <a href="/wiki/Diglossia" title="Diglossia">diglossia</a> in which much of the population are able to understand or speak Standard Colloquial Bengali and in their regional dialect,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-355"><a href="#cite_note-355">[355]</a></sup> such as <a href="/wiki/Chittagonian_language" title="Chittagonian language">Chittagonian</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sylheti_language" title="Sylheti language">Sylheti</a> and <a href="/wiki/Noakhailla_language" title="Noakhailla language">Noakhailla</a>, which some linguists consider as separate languages; noted for their <a href="/wiki/Arabic" title="Arabic">Arab</a>-<a href="/wiki/Persian_language" title="Persian language">Persian</a> influences.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-LOG_353-1"><a href="#cite_note-LOG-353">[353]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/English_language" title="English language">English</a> plays an important role in Bangladesh's judicial and educational affairs, due to the country's history as part of the British Empire. It is widely spoken and commonly understood, and is taught as a compulsory subject in all <a href="/wiki/List_of_schools_in_Bangladesh" title="List of schools in Bangladesh">schools</a>, <a href="/wiki/List_of_colleges_in_Bangladesh" title="List of colleges in Bangladesh">colleges</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_universities_in_Bangladesh" title="List of universities in Bangladesh">universities</a>; while the English-medium educational system is widely attended.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-356"><a href="#cite_note-356">[356]</a></sup> Tribal languages, although increasingly endangered, include the <a href="/wiki/Chakma_language" title="Chakma language">Chakma language</a>, another native Eastern Indo-Aryan language, spoken by the <a href="/wiki/Chakma_people" title="Chakma people">Chakma people</a>. Others include <a href="/wiki/Garo_language" title="Garo language">Garo</a>, <a href="/wiki/Meitei_language" title="Meitei language">Meitei</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kokborok" title="Kokborok">Kokborok</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rakhine_language" title="Rakhine language">Rakhine</a>. Among the <a href="/wiki/Austroasiatic_languages" title="Austroasiatic languages">Austroasiatic languages</a>, the most spoken is the <a href="/wiki/Santali_language" title="Santali language">Santali language</a>, native to the <a href="/wiki/Santal_people" title="Santal people">Santal people</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-357"><a href="#cite_note-357">[357]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Stranded_Pakistanis_in_Bangladesh" title="Stranded Pakistanis in Bangladesh">stranded Pakistanis</a> and some sections of the <a href="/wiki/Dhakaiyas" title="Dhakaiyas">Old Dhakaites</a> often use <a href="/wiki/Urdu" title="Urdu">Urdu</a> as their native tongue, although the usage of the latter remains highly reproached.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-358"><a href="#cite_note-358">[358]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Religion">Religion</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Religion_in_Bangladesh" title="Religion in Bangladesh">Religion in Bangladesh</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Eid_Prayers_at_Barashalghar,_Debidwar,_Comilla.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1944" data-file-width="2592" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Eid_Prayers_at_Barashalghar%2C_Debidwar%2C_Comilla.jpg/220px-Eid_Prayers_at_Barashalghar%2C_Debidwar%2C_Comilla.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Eid_Prayers_at_Barashalghar%2C_Debidwar%2C_Comilla.jpg/330px-Eid_Prayers_at_Barashalghar%2C_Debidwar%2C_Comilla.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Eid_Prayers_at_Barashalghar%2C_Debidwar%2C_Comilla.jpg/440px-Eid_Prayers_at_Barashalghar%2C_Debidwar%2C_Comilla.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Eid_Prayers_at_Barashalghar,_Debidwar,_Comilla.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Eid_prayers" title="Eid prayers">Eid prayers</a> for Muslims at Barashalghar, <a href="/wiki/Debidwar_Upazila" title="Debidwar Upazila">Debidwar</a>, <a href="/wiki/Comilla" title="Comilla">Comilla</a></div></div></div>
