<p>Bangladesh was constitutionally proclaimed as the first <a href="/wiki/Secular_state" title="Secular state">secular state</a> of South Asia in 1972. It grants <a href="/wiki/Freedom_of_religion" title="Freedom of religion">freedom of religion</a> and claims to be "secular in practise", while establishing Islam as the <a href="/wiki/State_religion" title="State religion">state religion</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-359"><a href="#cite_note-359">[359]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Secularism_360-0"><a href="#cite_note-Secularism-360">[360]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-constituteproject_361-0"><a href="#cite_note-constituteproject-361">[361]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-aljazeera:1_362-0"><a href="#cite_note-aljazeera:1-362">[362]</a></sup> The constitution bans religion-based politics and discrimination, and proclaims equal recognition of people adhering to all faiths.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-363"><a href="#cite_note-363">[363]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Islam_in_Bangladesh" title="Islam in Bangladesh">Islam</a> is the largest religion across the country, being followed by about 91% of the population.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-dhakatribune1_6-3"><a href="#cite_note-dhakatribune1-6">[6]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-globalreligiousfutures1_364-0"><a href="#cite_note-globalreligiousfutures1-364">[364]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-kbrs_365-0"><a href="#cite_note-kbrs-365">[365]</a></sup> The vast majority of Bangladeshi citizens are <a href="/wiki/Bengali_Muslims" title="Bengali Muslims">Bengali Muslims</a>, adhering to <a href="/wiki/Sunni_Islam" title="Sunni Islam">Sunni Islam</a>. The country is the third-most populous Muslim-majority state in the world, and has the fourth-largest overall Muslim population.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-366"><a href="#cite_note-366">[366]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Hinduism_in_Bangladesh" title="Hinduism in Bangladesh">Hinduism</a> is followed by 7.95% of the population,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-dhakatribune1_6-4"><a href="#cite_note-dhakatribune1-6">[6]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-globalreligiousfutures1_364-1"><a href="#cite_note-globalreligiousfutures1-364">[364]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-kbrs_365-1"><a href="#cite_note-kbrs-365">[365]</a></sup> mainly by the <a href="/wiki/Bengali_Hindus" title="Bengali Hindus">Bengali Hindus</a>, who form the country's second-largest religious group and the third-largest Hindu community globally; after those in India and Nepal. <a href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_Bangladesh" title="Buddhism in Bangladesh">Buddhism</a> is the third-largest religion, at 0.61% of the population. Bangladeshi Buddhists are concentrated among the tribal ethnic groups in the Chittagong Hill Tracts. At the same time, coastal Chittagong is home to many <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bengali_Buddhist" title="Bengali Buddhist">Bengali Buddhists</a>. Christianity is the fourth-largest religion, at 0.3%, followed mainly by a small <a href="/wiki/Bengali_Christians" title="Bengali Christians">Bengali Christian</a> minority.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-dhakatribune1_6-5"><a href="#cite_note-dhakatribune1-6">[6]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-367"><a href="#cite_note-367">[367]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Education">Education</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Education_in_Bangladesh" title="Education in Bangladesh">Education in Bangladesh</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Literacy_rate_Bangladesh.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="471" data-file-width="464" decoding="async" height="223" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fc/Literacy_rate_Bangladesh.png/220px-Literacy_rate_Bangladesh.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fc/Literacy_rate_Bangladesh.png/330px-Literacy_rate_Bangladesh.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fc/Literacy_rate_Bangladesh.png/440px-Literacy_rate_Bangladesh.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Literacy_rate_Bangladesh.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Literacy rates in Bangladesh districts</div></div></div>
<p>Article (17) of the constitution states that all children shall receive free and compulsory education.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-368"><a href="#cite_note-368">[368]</a></sup> Education in Bangladesh is overseen by the <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Education_(Bangladesh)" title="Ministry of Education (Bangladesh)">Ministry of Education</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Primary_and_Mass_Education" title="Ministry of Primary and Mass Education">Ministry of Primary and Mass Education</a> is responsible for implementing policy for <a href="/wiki/Primary_education" title="Primary education">primary education</a> and state-funded schools at a local level. Primary and secondary education is <a href="/wiki/Compulsory_education" title="Compulsory education">compulsory</a>, and is financed by the state and free of charge in public schools. Bangladesh has a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Literacy_rate" title="Literacy rate">literacy rate</a> of 74.7% percent as of 2019: 77.4% for males and 71.9% for females.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-369"><a href="#cite_note-369">[369]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-370"><a href="#cite_note-370">[370]</a></sup> The country's educational system is three-tiered and heavily subsidised, with the government operating many schools at the primary, secondary and higher secondary levels and subsidising many private schools. In the tertiary education sector, the Bangladeshi government funds over 45 state universities<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ugc-universities.gov.bd_371-0"><a href="#cite_note-ugc-universities.gov.bd-371">[371]</a></sup> through the <a href="/wiki/University_Grants_Commission_(Bangladesh)" title="University Grants Commission (Bangladesh)">University Grants Commission</a> (UGC), created by Presidential Order 10 in 1973.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-372"><a href="#cite_note-372">[372]</a></sup>
</p><p>The education system is divided into five levels: primary (first to fifth grade), junior secondary (sixth to eighth grade), secondary (ninth and tenth grade), higher secondary (11th and 12th grade), and tertiary.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CompEd_373-0"><a href="#cite_note-CompEd-373">[373]</a></sup> Five years of secondary education (including junior secondary) ends with a <a href="/wiki/Secondary_School_Certificate" title="Secondary School Certificate">Secondary School Certificate</a> (SSC) examination. Since 2009, the Primary Education Closing (PEC) examination has also been introduced. Students who pass the PEC examination proceed to secondary or matriculation training, culminating in the SSC examination.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CompEd_373-1"><a href="#cite_note-CompEd-373">[373]</a></sup> Students who pass the PEC examination proceed to three years of junior secondary education, culminating in the <a href="/wiki/Junior_School_Certificate" title="Junior School Certificate">Junior School Certificate</a> (JSC) examination. Students who pass this examination proceed to two years of secondary education, culminating in the SSC examination. Students who pass this examination proceed to two years of higher secondary education, culminating in the <a href="/wiki/Higher_Secondary_School_Certificate" title="Higher Secondary School Certificate">Higher Secondary School Certificate</a> (HSC) examination.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CompEd_373-2"><a href="#cite_note-CompEd-373">[373]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Universities_in_Bangladesh" title="Universities in Bangladesh">Universities in Bangladesh</a> are of three general types: public (government-owned and subsidised), private (privately owned universities) and international (operated and funded by international organisations). The country has 47 public,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ugc-universities.gov.bd_371-1"><a href="#cite_note-ugc-universities.gov.bd-371">[371]</a></sup> 105 private<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-374"><a href="#cite_note-374">[374]</a></sup> and two international <a href="/wiki/List_of_universities_in_Bangladesh" title="List of universities in Bangladesh">universities</a>; <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bangladesh_National_University" title="Bangladesh National University">Bangladesh National University</a> has the largest enrollment, and the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Dhaka" title="University of Dhaka">University of Dhaka</a> (established in 1921) is the oldest. <a href="/wiki/University_of_Chittagong" title="University of Chittagong">University of Chittagong</a>, established in 1966, has the largest campus among all universities in Bangladesh.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-375"><a href="#cite_note-375">[375]</a></sup> Medical education is provided by 29 government and private <a href="/wiki/List_of_medical_colleges_in_Bangladesh" title="List of medical colleges in Bangladesh">medical colleges</a>. All medical colleges are affiliated with the <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Health_and_Family_Welfare_(Bangladesh)" title="Ministry of Health and Family Welfare (Bangladesh)">Ministry of Health and Family Welfare</a>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Health">Health</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Health_in_Bangladesh" title="Health in Bangladesh">Health in Bangladesh</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Life_expectancy_in_Bangladesh.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="850" decoding="async" height="155" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b1/Life_expectancy_in_Bangladesh.svg/220px-Life_expectancy_in_Bangladesh.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b1/Life_expectancy_in_Bangladesh.svg/330px-Life_expectancy_in_Bangladesh.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b1/Life_expectancy_in_Bangladesh.svg/440px-Life_expectancy_in_Bangladesh.svg.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Life_expectancy_in_Bangladesh.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Historical development of <a href="/wiki/Life_expectancy" title="Life expectancy">life expectancy</a> in Bangladesh, displaying significant strides since independence.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-376"><a href="#cite_note-376">[376]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>Bangladesh, by constitution, guarantees healthcare services as a fundamental right to all of its citizens.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-377"><a href="#cite_note-377">[377]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Health_and_Family_Welfare_(Bangladesh)" title="Ministry of Health and Family Welfare (Bangladesh)">Ministry of Health and Family Welfare</a> is the largest institutional healthcare provider in Bangladesh,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-overview_378-0"><a href="#cite_note-overview-378">[378]</a></sup> and contains two divisions: <a href="/wiki/Health_Service_Division" title="Health Service Division">Health Service Division</a> and <a href="/wiki/Medical_Education_And_Family_Welfare_Division" title="Medical Education And Family Welfare Division">Medical Education And Family Welfare Division</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-379"><a href="#cite_note-379">[379]</a></sup> However, healthcare facilities in Bangladesh are considered less than adequate, although they have improved as the economy has grown and poverty levels have decreased significantly.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-overview_378-1"><a href="#cite_note-overview-378">[378]</a></sup> Bangladesh faces a severe health workforce crisis, as formally-trained providers make up a short percentage the total health workforce.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-380"><a href="#cite_note-380">[380]</a></sup> Significant deficiencies in the treatment practices of village doctors persist, with widespread harmful and inappropriate drug prescribing.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-381"><a href="#cite_note-381">[381]</a></sup> Receiving health care from informal providers is encouraged.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-382"><a href="#cite_note-382">[382]</a></sup>
</p><p>Bangladesh's poor healthcare system suffers from severe underfunding from the government.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-overview_378-2"><a href="#cite_note-overview-378">[378]</a></sup> As of 2019<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Bangladesh&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, some 2.48% of total GDP was attributed to healthcare,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-383"><a href="#cite_note-383">[383]</a></sup> and domestic general government spending on healthcare was 18.63% of the total budget,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-384"><a href="#cite_note-384">[384]</a></sup> while out-of-pocket expenditures made up the vast majority of total budget, totalling 72.68%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-385"><a href="#cite_note-385">[385]</a></sup> Domestic private health expenditure was about 75% of the total healthcare expenditure.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-386"><a href="#cite_note-386">[386]</a></sup> As of 2020<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Bangladesh&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, there are only 5.3 doctors per 10,000 people, and about 6 physicians<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-387"><a href="#cite_note-387">[387]</a></sup> and 3 nurses per 10,000 people, while the  number of hospital beds is 8 per 10,000.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-388"><a href="#cite_note-388">[388]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-389"><a href="#cite_note-389">[389]</a></sup> The overall life expectancy in Bangladesh at birth was 73 years (71 years for males and 75 years for females) as of 2020<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Bangladesh&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-390"><a href="#cite_note-390">[390]</a></sup> and it has a comparably high <a href="/wiki/Infant_mortality" title="Infant mortality">infant mortality</a> rate (24 per 1,000 live births) and <a href="/wiki/Child_mortality" title="Child mortality">child mortality</a> rate (29 per 1,000 live births).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-391"><a href="#cite_note-391">[391]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-392"><a href="#cite_note-392">[392]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Maternal_death" title="Maternal death">Maternal mortality</a> remains high, clocking at 173 per 100,000 live births.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-393"><a href="#cite_note-393">[393]</a></sup> Bangladesh is a key source market for <a href="/wiki/Medical_tourism" title="Medical tourism">medical tourism</a> for various countries, mainly <a href="/wiki/Medical_tourism_in_India" title="Medical tourism in India">India</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-394"><a href="#cite_note-394">[394]</a></sup> due to its citizens dissatisfaction and distrust over their own healthcare system.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-395"><a href="#cite_note-395">[395]</a></sup>
</p><p>The main causes of death are <a href="/wiki/Coronary_artery_disease" title="Coronary artery disease">coronary artery disease</a>, <a href="/wiki/Stroke" title="Stroke">stroke</a>, and chronic <a href="/wiki/Respiratory_disease" title="Respiratory disease">respiratory disease</a>; comprising 62% and 60% of all adult male and female deaths, respectively.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-396"><a href="#cite_note-396">[396]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Malnutrition" title="Malnutrition">Malnutrition</a> is a major and persistent problem in Bangladesh, mainly affecting the rural regions, more than half of the population suffers from it. Severe acute malnutrition affects 450,000 children, while close to 2 million children have moderate acute malnutrition. For children under the age of five, 52% are affected by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Anaemia" title="Anaemia">anaemia</a>, 41% are <a href="/wiki/Stunted_growth" title="Stunted growth">stunted</a>, 16% are <a href="/wiki/Wasting" title="Wasting">wasted</a>, and 36% are <a href="/wiki/Underweight" title="Underweight">underweight</a>. A quarter of women are underweight and around 15% have short stature, while over half also suffer from anaemia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-397"><a href="#cite_note-397">[397]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Culture">Culture</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_Bangladesh" title="Culture of Bangladesh">Culture of Bangladesh</a>, <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_Bengal" title="Culture of Bengal">Culture of Bengal</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Bengali_Renaissance" title="Bengali Renaissance">Bengali Renaissance</a></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Visual_arts">Visual arts</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Bangladeshi_art" title="Bangladeshi art">Bangladeshi art</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Victoria_Memorial_Kolkata_-_Muslin.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3776" data-file-width="4832" decoding="async" height="172" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/Victoria_Memorial_Kolkata_-_Muslin.jpg/220px-Victoria_Memorial_Kolkata_-_Muslin.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/Victoria_Memorial_Kolkata_-_Muslin.jpg/330px-Victoria_Memorial_Kolkata_-_Muslin.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/Victoria_Memorial_Kolkata_-_Muslin.jpg/440px-Victoria_Memorial_Kolkata_-_Muslin.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Victoria_Memorial_Kolkata_-_Muslin.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A preserved cloth of historic <a href="/wiki/Muslin_trade_in_Bengal" title="Muslin trade in Bengal">Bengali fine muslin</a>, which is now extinct</div></div></div>
<p>The recorded history of art in Bangladesh can be traced to the 3rd century BCE, when <a href="/wiki/Terracotta" title="Terracotta">terracotta</a> sculptures were made in the region. In classical antiquity, a notable sculptural Hindu, Jain and Buddhist art developed in the Pala Empire and the Sena dynasty. Islamic art has evolved since the 14th century. The architecture of the Bengal Sultanate saw a distinct style of domed mosques with complex niche pillars that had no minarets. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mughal_Bengal" title="Mughal Bengal">Mughal Bengal</a>'s most celebrated artistic tradition was the weaving of <a href="/wiki/Jamdani" title="Jamdani">Jamdani</a> <a href="/wiki/Motif_(textile_arts)" title="Motif (textile arts)">motifs</a> on fine muslin, which is now classified by UNESCO as an <a href="/wiki/Intangible_cultural_heritage" title="Intangible cultural heritage">intangible cultural heritage</a>. Jamdani motifs were similar to Iranian textile art (buta motifs) and Western textile art (<a href="/wiki/Paisley_(design)" title="Paisley (design)">paisley</a>). The Jamdani weavers in Dhaka received imperial patronage.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-star_86-4"><a href="#cite_note-star-86">[86]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-398"><a href="#cite_note-398">[398]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Ivory" title="Ivory">Ivory</a> and <a href="/wiki/Brass" title="Brass">brass</a> were also widely used in Mughal art. <a href="/wiki/Pottery" title="Pottery">Pottery</a> is widely used in Bengali culture.
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Modern_art" title="Modern art">modern art</a> movement in Bangladesh took shape during the 1950s, particularly with the pioneering works of <a href="/wiki/Zainul_Abedin" title="Zainul Abedin">Zainul Abedin</a>. East Bengal developed its own modernist painting and sculpture traditions, which were distinct from the art movements in West Bengal. The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Art_Institute_Dhaka" title="Art Institute Dhaka">Art Institute Dhaka</a> has been an important centre for visual art in the region. Its annual <a href="/wiki/Mangal_Shobhajatra" title="Mangal Shobhajatra">Bengali New Year parade</a> was enlisted as an intangible cultural heritage by UNESCO in 2016.
</p><p>Modern Bangladesh has produced many of South Asia's leading painters, including <a href="/wiki/SM_Sultan" title="SM Sultan">SM Sultan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mohammad_Kibria" title="Mohammad Kibria">Mohammad Kibria</a>, <a href="/wiki/Shahabuddin_Ahmed_(artist)" title="Shahabuddin Ahmed (artist)">Shahabuddin Ahmed</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kanak_Chanpa_Chakma" title="Kanak Chanpa Chakma">Kanak Chanpa Chakma</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kafil_Ahmed" title="Kafil Ahmed">Kafil Ahmed</a>, <a href="/wiki/Saifuddin_Ahmed" title="Saifuddin Ahmed">Saifuddin Ahmed</a>, <a href="/wiki/Qayyum_Chowdhury" title="Qayyum Chowdhury">Qayyum Chowdhury</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rashid_Choudhury" title="Rashid Choudhury">Rashid Choudhury</a>, <a href="/wiki/Quamrul_Hassan" title="Quamrul Hassan">Quamrul Hassan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rafiqun_Nabi" title="Rafiqun Nabi">Rafiqun Nabi</a> and <a href="/wiki/Syed_Jahangir" title="Syed Jahangir">Syed Jahangir</a>, among others. <a href="/wiki/Novera_Ahmed" title="Novera Ahmed">Novera Ahmed</a> and <a href="/wiki/Nitun_Kundu" title="Nitun Kundu">Nitun Kundu</a> were the country's pioneers of modernist sculpture.
</p><p>In recent times, photography as a medium of art has become popular. Biennial <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chobi_Mela" title="Chobi Mela">Chobi Mela</a> is considered the largest photography festival in Asia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-399"><a href="#cite_note-399">[399]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Literature">Literature</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bangladeshi_literature" title="Bangladeshi literature">Bangladeshi literature</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Syed_Mujtaba_Ali.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="263" data-file-width="250" decoding="async" height="231" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/29/Syed_Mujtaba_Ali.jpg/220px-Syed_Mujtaba_Ali.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/2/29/Syed_Mujtaba_Ali.jpg 1.5x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Syed_Mujtaba_Ali.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Syed_Mujtaba_Ali" title="Syed Mujtaba Ali">Syed Mujtaba Ali</a></div></div></div>
<p>The oldest evidence of writing in Bangladesh is the Mahasthan <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Brahmi" title="Brahmi">Brahmi</a> Inscription, which dates back to the 3rd century BCE.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-400"><a href="#cite_note-400">[400]</a></sup> In the Gupta Empire, Sanskrit literature thrived in the region. Bengali developed from <a href="/wiki/Sanskrit" title="Sanskrit">Sanskrit</a> and <a href="/wiki/Magadhi_Prakrit" title="Magadhi Prakrit">Magadhi Prakrit</a> in the 8th to 10th century. Bengali literature is a millennium-old tradition; the <a href="/wiki/Charyapada" title="Charyapada">Charyapadas</a> are the earliest examples of Bengali poetry. Sufi spiritualism inspired many <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bengali_Muslim" title="Bengali Muslim">Bengali Muslim</a> writers. During the Bengal Sultanate, medieval Bengali writers were influenced by <a href="/wiki/Arabic_literature" title="Arabic literature">Arabic</a> and <a href="/wiki/Persian_literature" title="Persian literature">Persian works</a>. Sultans of Bengal patronized Bengali literature. Examples include the writings of <a href="/wiki/Maladhar_Basu" title="Maladhar Basu">Maladhar Basu</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bipradas_Pipilai" title="Bipradas Pipilai">Bipradas Pipilai</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vijay_Gupta_(poet)" title="Vijay Gupta (poet)">Vijay Gupta</a> and Yasoraj Khan. The <a href="/wiki/Chandidas" title="Chandidas">Chandidas</a> are the notable lyric poets from the early Medieval Age. <a href="/wiki/Alaol" title="Alaol">Syed Alaol</a> was the bard of middle Bengali literature. The Bengal Renaissance shaped modern Bengali literature, including novels, short stories and <a href="/wiki/Bengali_science_fiction" title="Bengali science fiction">science fiction</a>. Rabindranath Tagore was the first non-European laureate of the <a href="/wiki/Nobel_Prize_in_Literature" title="Nobel Prize in Literature">Nobel Prize in Literature</a> and is described as the Bengali Shakespeare.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-401"><a href="#cite_note-401">[401]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Kazi_Nazrul_Islam" title="Kazi Nazrul Islam">Kazi Nazrul Islam</a> was a revolutionary poet who espoused political rebellion against colonialism and fascism. <a href="/wiki/Begum_Rokeya" title="Begum Rokeya">Begum Rokeya</a> is regarded as the pioneer feminist writer of Bangladesh.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Rubaiyat_402-0"><a href="#cite_note-Rubaiyat-402">[402]</a></sup> Other renaissance icons included Michael Madhusudan Dutt and <a href="/wiki/Sarat_Chandra_Chattopadhyay" title="Sarat Chandra Chattopadhyay">Sarat Chandra Chattopadhyay</a>.
The writer <a href="/wiki/Syed_Mujtaba_Ali" title="Syed Mujtaba Ali">Syed Mujtaba Ali</a> is noted for his cosmopolitan Bengali worldview.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-403"><a href="#cite_note-403">[403]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Jasimuddin" title="Jasimuddin">Jasimuddin</a> was a renowned pastoral poet. <a href="/wiki/Shamsur_Rahman_(poet)" title="Shamsur Rahman (poet)">Shamsur Rahman</a> and <a href="/wiki/Al_Mahmud" title="Al Mahmud">Al Mahmud</a> are considered two of the greatest Bengali poets to have emerged in the 20th century. <a href="/wiki/Farrukh_Ahmad" title="Farrukh Ahmad">Farrukh Ahmad</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sufia_Kamal" title="Sufia Kamal">Sufia Kamal</a>, <a href="/wiki/Syed_Ali_Ahsan" title="Syed Ali Ahsan">Syed Ali Ahsan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ahsan_Habib" title="Ahsan Habib">Ahsan Habib</a>, <a href="/wiki/Abul_Hussain" title="Abul Hussain">Abul Hussain</a>, <a href="/wiki/Shahid_Qadri" title="Shahid Qadri">Shahid Qadri</a>, <a href="/wiki/Fazal_Shahabuddin" title="Fazal Shahabuddin">Fazal Shahabuddin</a>, <a href="/wiki/Abu_Zafar_Obaidullah" title="Abu Zafar Obaidullah">Abu Zafar Obaidullah</a>, <a href="/wiki/Omar_Ali_(poet)" title="Omar Ali (poet)">Omar Ali</a>, <a href="/wiki/Al_Mujahidi" title="Al Mujahidi">Al Mujahidi</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Syed_Shamsul_Huq" title="Syed Shamsul Huq">Syed Shamsul Huq</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nirmalendu_Goon" title="Nirmalendu Goon">Nirmalendu Goon</a>, <a href="/wiki/Abid_Azad" title="Abid Azad">Abid Azad</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hasan_Hafizur_Rahman" title="Hasan Hafizur Rahman">Hasan Hafizur Rahman</a> and <a href="/wiki/Abdul_Hye_Sikder" title="Abdul Hye Sikder">Abdul Hye Sikder</a> are important figures of modern Bangladeshi poetry. <a href="/wiki/Ahmed_Sofa" title="Ahmed Sofa">Ahmed Sofa</a> is regarded as the most important Bangladeshi intellectual in the post-independence era. <a href="/wiki/Humayun_Ahmed" title="Humayun Ahmed">Humayun Ahmed</a> was a popular writer of modern Bangladeshi <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Magical_realism" title="Magical realism">magical realism</a> and science fiction. Notable writers of Bangladeshi fictions include Mir Mosharraf Hossain, <a href="/wiki/Akhteruzzaman_Elias" title="Akhteruzzaman Elias">Akhteruzzaman Elias</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Alauddin_Al_Azad" title="Alauddin Al Azad">Alauddin Al Azad</a>, <a href="/wiki/Shahidul_Zahir" title="Shahidul Zahir">Shahidul Zahir</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rashid_Karim" title="Rashid Karim">Rashid Karim</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mahmudul_Haque" title="Mahmudul Haque">Mahmudul Haque</a>, <a href="/wiki/Syed_Waliullah" title="Syed Waliullah">Syed Waliullah</a>, <a href="/wiki/Shahidullah_Kaiser" title="Shahidullah Kaiser">Shahidullah Kaiser</a>, <a href="/wiki/Shawkat_Osman" title="Shawkat Osman">Shawkat Osman</a>, <a href="/wiki/Selina_Hossain" title="Selina Hossain">Selina Hossain</a>, <a href="/wiki/Shahed_Ali" title="Shahed Ali">Shahed Ali</a>, <a href="/wiki/Razia_Khan" title="Razia Khan">Razia Khan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Anisul_Hoque" title="Anisul Hoque">Anisul Hoque</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Abdul_Mannan_Syed" title="Abdul Mannan Syed">Abdul Mannan Syed</a>.
</p><p>The annual <a href="/wiki/Ekushey_Book_Fair" title="Ekushey Book Fair">Ekushey Book Fair</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hay_Festival_Dhaka" title="Hay Festival Dhaka">Dhaka Literature Festival</a>, organised by the <a href="/wiki/Bangla_Academy" title="Bangla Academy">Bangla Academy</a>, are among the largest literary festivals in South Asia.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Women_in_Bangladesh">Women in Bangladesh</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Women_in_Bangladesh" title="Women in Bangladesh">Women in Bangladesh</a></div><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Gender_inequality_in_Bangladesh" title="Gender inequality in Bangladesh">Gender inequality in Bangladesh</a></div><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Child_marriage_in_Bangladesh" title="Child marriage in Bangladesh">Child marriage in Bangladesh</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:BegumRokeyaWithHusband.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="512" data-file-width="420" decoding="async" height="268" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/BegumRokeyaWithHusband.jpg/220px-BegumRokeyaWithHusband.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/BegumRokeyaWithHusband.jpg/330px-BegumRokeyaWithHusband.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/b/b0/BegumRokeyaWithHusband.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:BegumRokeyaWithHusband.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Muslim feminist <a href="/wiki/Begum_Rokeya" title="Begum Rokeya">Begum Rokeya</a> and her husband in 1898</div></div></div>
<p>Although as of 2015<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Bangladesh&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, several women occupied major political office in Bangladesh. Its women continue to live under a patriarchal social regime where violence is common.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-whispers_404-0"><a href="#cite_note-whispers-404">[404]</a></sup> Whereas in India and Pakistan women participate less in the workforce as their education increases, the reverse is the case in Bangladesh.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-whispers_404-1"><a href="#cite_note-whispers-404">[404]</a></sup>
</p><p>Bengal has a long history of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Feminist_activism" title="Feminist activism">feminist activism</a> dating back to the 19th century. <a href="/wiki/Begum_Rokeya" title="Begum Rokeya">Begum Rokeya</a> and <a href="/wiki/Nawab_Faizunnesa" title="Nawab Faizunnesa">Faizunnessa Chowdhurani</a> played an important role in emancipating Bengali Muslim women from <a href="/wiki/Purdah" title="Purdah">purdah</a>, before the country's division, as well as promoting girls' education. Several women were elected to the Bengal Legislative Assembly in the British Raj. The first women's magazine, <i><a href="/wiki/Begum_(magazine)" title="Begum (magazine)">Begum</a></i>, was published in 1948.
</p><p>In 2008, Bangladeshi female workforce participation stood at 26%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-405"><a href="#cite_note-405">[405]</a></sup> Women dominate <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Blue_collar" title="Blue collar">blue collar</a> jobs in the Bangladeshi garment industry. Agriculture, social services, healthcare and education are also major occupations for Bangladeshi women, while their employment in <a href="/wiki/White-collar_worker" title="White-collar worker">white collar</a> positions has steadily increased.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Architecture">Architecture</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Architecture_of_Bangladesh" title="Architecture of Bangladesh">Architecture of Bangladesh</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Dinajpur_KantanagarMondir_11Oct12_IMG_3579.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3463" data-file-width="5194" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Dinajpur_KantanagarMondir_11Oct12_IMG_3579.jpg/220px-Dinajpur_KantanagarMondir_11Oct12_IMG_3579.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Dinajpur_KantanagarMondir_11Oct12_IMG_3579.jpg/330px-Dinajpur_KantanagarMondir_11Oct12_IMG_3579.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Dinajpur_KantanagarMondir_11Oct12_IMG_3579.jpg/440px-Dinajpur_KantanagarMondir_11Oct12_IMG_3579.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Dinajpur_KantanagarMondir_11Oct12_IMG_3579.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The 18th century <a href="/wiki/Terracotta" title="Terracotta">terracotta</a> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hindu" title="Hindu">Hindu</a> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kantanagar_Temple" title="Kantanagar Temple">Kantanagar Temple</a> in <a href="/wiki/Dinajpur" title="Dinajpur">Dinajpur</a></div></div></div>
<p>The architectural traditions of Bangladesh have a 2,500-year-old heritage.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-406"><a href="#cite_note-406">[406]</a></sup> Terracotta architecture is a distinct feature of Bengal. Pre-Islamic Bengali architecture reached its pinnacle in the Pala Empire, when the Pala School of Sculptural Art established grand structures such as the Somapura Mahavihara. <a href="/wiki/Islamic_architecture" title="Islamic architecture">Islamic architecture</a> began developing under the Bengal Sultanate, when local terracotta styles influenced medieval mosque construction.
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Sixty_Dome_Mosque" title="Sixty Dome Mosque">Sixty Dome Mosque</a> was the largest medieval mosque built in Bangladesh and is a fine example of Turkic-Bengali architecture. The <a href="/wiki/Mughal_architecture" title="Mughal architecture">Mughal style</a> replaced indigenous architecture when Bengal became a province of the Mughal Empire and influenced urban housing development. The <a href="/wiki/Kantajew_Temple" title="Kantajew Temple">Kantajew Temple</a> and <a href="/wiki/Dhakeshwari_Temple" title="Dhakeshwari Temple">Dhakeshwari Temple</a> are excellent examples of late medieval <a href="/wiki/Hindu_temple_architecture" title="Hindu temple architecture">Hindu temple architecture</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Indo-Saracenic_Revival_architecture" title="Indo-Saracenic Revival architecture">Indo-Saracenic Revival architecture</a>, based on Indo-Islamic styles, flourished during the British period. The zamindar gentry in Bangladesh built numerous Indo-Saracenic palaces and country mansions, such as the <a href="/wiki/Ahsan_Manzil" title="Ahsan Manzil">Ahsan Manzil</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tajhat_Palace" title="Tajhat Palace">Tajhat Palace</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Uttara_Gonobhaban" title="Uttara Gonobhaban">Dighapatia Palace</a>, <a href="/wiki/Puthia_Rajbari" title="Puthia Rajbari">Puthia Rajbari</a> and <a href="/wiki/Natore_Rajbari" title="Natore Rajbari">Natore Rajbari</a>.
</p><p>Bengali <a href="/wiki/Vernacular_architecture" title="Vernacular architecture">vernacular architecture</a> is noted for pioneering the <a href="/wiki/Bungalow" title="Bungalow">bungalow</a>. Bangladeshi villages consist of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Thatch" title="Thatch">thatched</a> roofed houses made of natural materials like <a href="/wiki/Mud" title="Mud">mud</a>, <a href="/wiki/Straw" title="Straw">straw</a>, wood and bamboo. In modern times, village bungalows are increasingly made of <a href="/wiki/Tin" title="Tin">tin</a>.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Muzharul_Islam" title="Muzharul Islam">Muzharul Islam</a> was the pioneer of Bangladeshi modern architecture. His varied works set the course of modern architectural practice in the country. Islam brought leading global architects, including <a href="/wiki/Louis_Kahn" title="Louis Kahn">Louis Kahn</a>, <a href="/wiki/Richard_Neutra" title="Richard Neutra">Richard Neutra</a>, <a href="/wiki/Stanley_Tigerman" title="Stanley Tigerman">Stanley Tigerman</a>, <a href="/wiki/Paul_Rudolph_(architect)" title="Paul Rudolph (architect)">Paul Rudolph</a>, <a href="/wiki/Robert_Boughey" title="Robert Boughey">Robert Boughey</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Konstantinos_Apostolos_Doxiadis" title="Konstantinos Apostolos Doxiadis">Konstantinos Doxiadis</a>, to work in erstwhile East Pakistan. Louis Kahn was chosen to design the National Parliament Complex in <a href="/wiki/Sher-e-Bangla_Nagar" title="Sher-e-Bangla Nagar">Sher-e-Bangla Nagar</a>. Kahn's monumental designs, combining regional red brick aesthetics, his own concrete and marble <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Brutalism" title="Brutalism">brutalism</a> and the use of lakes to represent Bengali geography, are regarded as one of the masterpieces of the 20th century. In more recent times, award-winning architects like <a href="/wiki/Rafiq_Azam" title="Rafiq Azam">Rafiq Azam</a> have set the course of contemporary architecture by adopting influences from the works of Islam and Kahn.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Performing_arts">Performing arts</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:162px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ektara_player.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="750" data-file-width="750" decoding="async" height="160" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/Ektara_player.jpg/160px-Ektara_player.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/Ektara_player.jpg/240px-Ektara_player.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/Ektara_player.jpg/320px-Ektara_player.jpg 2x" width="160"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Ektara_player.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A Baul from <a href="/wiki/Lalon" title="Lalon">Lalon Shah's</a> shrine in <a href="/wiki/Kushtia_District" title="Kushtia District">Kushtia</a></div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Theatre_in_Bangladesh" title="Theatre in Bangladesh">Theatre in Bangladesh</a> includes various forms with a history dating back to the 4th century CE.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ahmed,_Syed_Jamil_2000_p._396_407-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ahmed,_Syed_Jamil_2000_p._396-407">[407]</a></sup> It includes narrative forms, song and dance forms, supra-personae forms, performances with scroll paintings, puppet theatre and processional forms.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ahmed,_Syed_Jamil_2000_p._396_407-1"><a href="#cite_note-Ahmed,_Syed_Jamil_2000_p._396-407">[407]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Jatra_(theatre)" title="Jatra (theatre)">Jatra</a> is the most popular form of Bengali folk theatre.
The dance traditions of Bangladesh include indigenous tribal and Bengali dance forms, as well as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Classical_Indian_dance" title="Classical Indian dance">classical Indian dances</a>, including the <a href="/wiki/Kathak" title="Kathak">Kathak</a>, <a href="/wiki/Odissi" title="Odissi">Odissi</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Manipuri_dance" title="Manipuri dance">Manipuri dances</a>.
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Music_of_Bangladesh" title="Music of Bangladesh">music of Bangladesh</a> features the <a href="/wiki/Baul" title="Baul">Baul</a> <a href="/wiki/Mysticism" title="Mysticism">mystical</a> tradition, listed by UNESCO as a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Masterpiece_of_the_Oral_and_Intangible_Heritage_of_Humanity" title="Masterpiece of the Oral and Intangible Heritage of Humanity">Masterpiece of Intangible Cultural Heritage</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-408"><a href="#cite_note-408">[408]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Lalon" title="Lalon">Fakir Lalon Shah</a> popularised <a href="/wiki/Baul" title="Baul">Baul</a> music in the country in the 18th century and it has since been one of the most popular music genera in the country since then. Most modern <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bauls" title="Bauls">Bauls</a> are devoted to Lalon Shah.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-409"><a href="#cite_note-409">[409]</a></sup> Numerous lyric-based musical traditions, varying from one region to the next, exist, including <a href="/wiki/Gombhira" title="Gombhira">Gombhira</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bhatiali" title="Bhatiali">Bhatiali</a> and <a href="/wiki/Bhawaiya" title="Bhawaiya">Bhawaiya</a>. Folk music is accompanied by a one-stringed instrument known as the <a href="/wiki/Ektara" title="Ektara">ektara</a>. Other instruments include the <a href="/wiki/Dotara" title="Dotara">dotara</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dhol" title="Dhol">dhol</a>, flute, and <a href="/wiki/Tabla" title="Tabla">tabla</a>. Bengali classical music includes <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tagore_songs" title="Tagore songs">Tagore songs</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nazrul_geeti" title="Nazrul geeti">Nazrul Sangeet</a>. Bangladesh has a rich tradition of <a href="/wiki/Indian_classical_music" title="Indian classical music">Indian classical music</a>, which uses instruments like the <a href="/wiki/Sitar" title="Sitar">sitar</a>, tabla, <a href="/wiki/Sarod" title="Sarod">sarod</a> and <a href="/wiki/Santoor" title="Santoor">santoor</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-410"><a href="#cite_note-410">[410]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Sabina_Yasmin" title="Sabina Yasmin">Sabina Yasmin</a> and <a href="/wiki/Runa_Laila" title="Runa Laila">Runa Laila</a> are considered the leading playback singers in the modern time, while musicians such as <a href="/wiki/Ayub_Bachchu" title="Ayub Bachchu">Ayub Bachchu</a> and <a href="/wiki/James_(musician)" title="James (musician)">James</a> are credited with popularising rock music in Bangladesh.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-411"><a href="#cite_note-411">[411]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-412"><a href="#cite_note-412">[412]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Textiles">Textiles</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Textile_arts_of_Bangladesh" title="Textile arts of Bangladesh">Textile arts of Bangladesh</a> and <a href="/wiki/Muslin_trade_in_Bengal" title="Muslin trade in Bengal">Muslin trade in Bengal</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Kantha_(Quilt)_LACMA_AC1994.131.1.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1548" data-file-width="2100" decoding="async" height="162" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2c/Kantha_%28Quilt%29_LACMA_AC1994.131.1.jpg/220px-Kantha_%28Quilt%29_LACMA_AC1994.131.1.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2c/Kantha_%28Quilt%29_LACMA_AC1994.131.1.jpg/330px-Kantha_%28Quilt%29_LACMA_AC1994.131.1.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2c/Kantha_%28Quilt%29_LACMA_AC1994.131.1.jpg/440px-Kantha_%28Quilt%29_LACMA_AC1994.131.1.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Kantha_(Quilt)_LACMA_AC1994.131.1.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Embroidery on <a href="/wiki/Nakshi_kantha" title="Nakshi kantha">Nakshi kantha</a> (embroidered <a href="/wiki/Quilt" title="Quilt">quilt</a>), centuries-old Bengali art tradition</div></div></div>
<p>The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nakshi_Kantha" title="Nakshi Kantha">Nakshi Kantha</a> is a centuries-old <a href="/wiki/Embroidery" title="Embroidery">embroidery</a> tradition for <a href="/wiki/Quilt" title="Quilt">quilts</a>, said to be indigenous to eastern Bengal (i.e. Bangladesh). The sari is the national dress for Bangladeshi women. Mughal Dhaka was renowned for producing the finest <a href="/wiki/Muslin" title="Muslin">Muslin</a> saris, as well as the famed <a href="/wiki/Dhakai" title="Dhakai">Dhakai</a> and <a href="/wiki/Jamdani" title="Jamdani">Jamdani</a>, the weaving of which is listed by UNESCO as one of the masterpieces of humanity's intangible cultural heritage.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-413"><a href="#cite_note-413">[413]</a></sup> Bangladesh also produces the <a href="/wiki/Rajshahi_silk" title="Rajshahi silk">Rajshahi silk</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Shalwar_kameez" title="Shalwar kameez">shalwar kameez</a> is also widely worn by Bangladeshi women. In urban areas, some women can be seen in western clothing. The <a href="/wiki/Kurta" title="Kurta">kurta</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sherwani" title="Sherwani">sherwani</a> are the national dress of Bangladeshi men; the <a href="/wiki/Lungi" title="Lungi">lungi</a> and <a href="/wiki/Dhoti" title="Dhoti">dhoti</a> are worn by them in informal settings. Aside from ethnic wear, domestically <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tailored" title="Tailored">tailored</a> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Suit_(clothing)" title="Suit (clothing)">suits</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Neckties" title="Neckties">neckties</a> are customarily worn by the country's men in offices, in schools and at social events.
</p><p>The handloom industry supplies 60–65% of the country's clothing demand.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-414"><a href="#cite_note-414">[414]</a></sup> The Bengali ethnic <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fashion_industry" title="Fashion industry">fashion industry</a> has flourished in the changing environment of the fashion world. The retailer <a href="/wiki/Aarong" title="Aarong">Aarong</a> is one of South Asia's most successful ethnic wear brands. The development of the Bangladesh textile industry, which supplies leading international brands, has promoted the local production and retail of modern Western attire. The country now has a number of expanding local brands like Westecs and Yellow. Bangladesh is the world's second-largest garments exporter. Among Bangladesh's fashion designers, <a href="/wiki/Bibi_Russell" title="Bibi Russell">Bibi Russell</a> has received international acclaim for her "Fashion for Development" shows.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-415"><a href="#cite_note-415">[415]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cuisine">Cuisine</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Bangladeshi_cuisine" title="Bangladeshi cuisine">Bangladeshi cuisine</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Bengali_cuisine" title="Bengali cuisine">Bengali cuisine</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Bangladeshi_cuisine.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1296" data-file-width="1608" decoding="async" height="177" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e8/Bangladeshi_cuisine.png/220px-Bangladeshi_cuisine.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e8/Bangladeshi_cuisine.png/330px-Bangladeshi_cuisine.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e8/Bangladeshi_cuisine.png/440px-Bangladeshi_cuisine.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Bangladeshi_cuisine.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Traditional Bangladeshi meals: <a href="/wiki/Shorshe_ilish" title="Shorshe ilish">shorshe ilish</a>, Dhakaiya <a href="/wiki/Biryani" title="Biryani">biryani</a> and <a href="/wiki/Pitha" title="Pitha">pitha</a></div></div></div>
<p>Bangladeshi cuisine, formed by its geographic location and climate, is rich and varied; sharing its culinary heritage with the neighboring Indian state of <a href="/wiki/West_Bengal" title="West Bengal">West Bengal</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cuisine_416-0"><a href="#cite_note-cuisine-416">[416]</a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page / location: 14">: 14 </span></sup> <a href="/wiki/White_rice" title="White rice">White rice</a> is the staple, and along with <a href="/wiki/Fish" title="Fish">fish</a>, forms the culinary base. Varieties of <a href="/wiki/Leaf_vegetable" title="Leaf vegetable">leaf vegetables</a>, <a href="/wiki/Potato" title="Potato">potatoes</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gourd" title="Gourd">gourds</a> and <a href="/wiki/Lentil" title="Lentil">lentils</a> (<a href="/wiki/Dal" title="Dal">dal</a>) also play an important role. <a href="/wiki/Curry" title="Curry">Curries</a> of <a href="/wiki/Beef" title="Beef">beef</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mutton" title="Mutton">mutton</a>, <a href="/wiki/Chicken" title="Chicken">chicken</a> and <a href="/wiki/Duck" title="Duck">duck</a> are commonly consumed,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-shaheda_417-0"><a href="#cite_note-shaheda-417">[417]</a></sup> along with multiple types of <a href="/wiki/Bhurta" title="Bhurta">bhortas</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-418"><a href="#cite_note-418">[418]</a></sup> <i>bhajis</i> and <i>torkaris</i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cuisine_416-1"><a href="#cite_note-cuisine-416">[416]</a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page / location: 8">: 8 </span></sup> Mughal-influenced dishes include <a href="/wiki/Korma" title="Korma">kormas</a>, kalias, <a href="/wiki/Biryani" title="Biryani">biryanis</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pilaf" title="Pilaf">pulaos</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tahri_(dish)" title="Tahri (dish)">teharis</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Khichuri" title="Khichuri">khichuris</a>. Among the various spices, <a href="/wiki/Turmeric" title="Turmeric">turmeric</a>, <a href="/wiki/Fenugreek" title="Fenugreek">fenugreek</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nigella" title="Nigella">nigella</a>, <a href="/wiki/Coriander" title="Coriander">coriander</a>, <a href="/wiki/Anise" title="Anise">anise</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cardamom" title="Cardamom">cardamom</a> and <a href="/wiki/Chili_powder" title="Chili powder">chili powder</a> are widely used; a famous spice mix is the <a href="/wiki/Panch_phoron" title="Panch phoron">panch phoron</a>. Among the condiments and herbs used, <a href="/wiki/Red_onion" title="Red onion">red onions</a>, <a href="/wiki/Chili_pepper" title="Chili pepper">green chillies</a>, <a href="/wiki/Garlic" title="Garlic">garlic</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ginger" title="Ginger">ginger</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cilantro" title="Cilantro">cilantro</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Mentha" title="Mentha">mint</a> stand out.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cuisine_416-2"><a href="#cite_note-cuisine-416">[416]</a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page / location: 12">: 12 </span></sup> <a href="/wiki/Coconut_milk" title="Coconut milk">Coconut milk</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mustard_(condiment)" title="Mustard (condiment)">mustard paste</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mustard_seeds" title="Mustard seeds">mustard seeds</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mustard_oil" title="Mustard oil">mustard oil</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ghee" title="Ghee">ghee</a>, <a href="/wiki/South_Asian_pickle" title="South Asian pickle">achars</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-shaheda_417-1"><a href="#cite_note-shaheda-417">[417]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Chutney" title="Chutney">chutneys</a> are also widely used in the cuisine.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cuisine_416-3"><a href="#cite_note-cuisine-416">[416]</a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page / location: 13–14">: 13–14 </span></sup>
</p><p>Fish is the main source of protein, often enjoyed with its <a href="/wiki/Roe" title="Roe">roe</a>. The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hilsa" title="Hilsa">hilsa</a> is the national fish and immensely popular, a famous dish is <a href="/wiki/Shorshe_ilish" title="Shorshe ilish">shorshe ilish</a>. <a href="/wiki/Rohu" title="Rohu">Rohu</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pangasius_pangasius" title="Pangasius pangasius">pangas</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Tilapia" title="Tilapia">tilapia</a> are also highly consumed.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-419"><a href="#cite_note-419">[419]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Lobster" title="Lobster">Lobsters</a>, <a href="/wiki/Shrimp" title="Shrimp">shrimps</a> and <a href="/wiki/Dried_fish" title="Dried fish">dried fish</a> (<i>shutki</i>) are also widely consumed, with the <a href="/wiki/Chingri_malai_curry" title="Chingri malai curry">chingri malai curry</a> being a famous shrimp dish.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cuisine_416-4"><a href="#cite_note-cuisine-416">[416]</a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page / location: 8">: 8 </span></sup> In Chittagong, <a href="/wiki/Mezban" title="Mezban">Mezban</a> feasts are a popular tradition, featuring the serving of <i>mezbani gosht</i>, a hot and spicy beef curry.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cuisine_416-5"><a href="#cite_note-cuisine-416">[416]</a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page / location: 10">: 10 </span></sup> Other famous dishes from the region include <a href="/wiki/Kala_bhuna" title="Kala bhuna">kala bhuna</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-shaheda_417-2"><a href="#cite_note-shaheda-417">[417]</a></sup> In Sylhet, the <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Shatkora" title="Shatkora">shatkora</a></i> lemons are used to marinate dishes, a notable one is <a href="/wiki/Beef_Hatkhora" title="Beef Hatkhora">beef hatkora</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-420"><a href="#cite_note-420">[420]</a></sup> Among the tribal communities in the <a href="/wiki/Chittagong_Hill_Tracts" title="Chittagong Hill Tracts">Chittagong Hill Tracts</a>, cooking with <a href="/wiki/Bamboo_shoot" title="Bamboo shoot">bamboo shoots</a> is popular.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-421"><a href="#cite_note-421">[421]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Khulna_Division" title="Khulna Division">Khulna</a> is renowned for using <i>chui jhal</i> (<a href="/wiki/Piper_chaba" title="Piper chaba">piper chaba</a>) in its dishes.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-shaheda_417-3"><a href="#cite_note-shaheda-417">[417]</a></sup>
</p><p>Bangladesh has a vast spread of desserts, including distinctive <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sweets" title="Sweets">sweets</a> such as the <i><a href="/wiki/Rasgulla" title="Rasgulla">rôshogolla</a></i>,  <i><a href="/wiki/Ras_malai" title="Ras malai">roshmalai</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Chomchom" title="Chomchom">chomchom</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Sandesh_(confectionery)" title="Sandesh (confectionery)">sondesh</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Mishti_doi" title="Mishti doi">mishti doi</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Gulab_jamun" title="Gulab jamun">kalojaam</a></i>, and <i><a href="/wiki/Jalebi" title="Jalebi">jilapi</a></i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-422"><a href="#cite_note-422">[422]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Pitha" title="Pitha">Pithas</a> are traditional boiled desserts made with rice or fruits.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-423"><a href="#cite_note-423">[423]</a></sup> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Halwa" title="Halwa">Halwa</a> is served during religious festivities.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-424"><a href="#cite_note-424">[424]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Roti" title="Roti">Ruti</a>, <a href="/wiki/Naan" title="Naan">naan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Paratha" title="Paratha">paratha</a>, <a href="/wiki/Luchi" title="Luchi">luchi</a> and <a href="/wiki/Bakarkhani" title="Bakarkhani">bakarkhani</a> are the main local breads.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-425"><a href="#cite_note-425">[425]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-shaheda_417-4"><a href="#cite_note-shaheda-417">[417]</a></sup> Hot <a href="/wiki/Milk_tea" title="Milk tea">milk tea</a> is the most commonly consumed beverage in the country, being the centre of <a href="/wiki/Adda_(South_Asian)" title="Adda (South Asian)">addas</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-426"><a href="#cite_note-426">[426]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Kebab" title="Kebab">Kebabs</a> are widely popular, particularly <a href="/wiki/Seekh_kebab" title="Seekh kebab">seekh kebab</a>, <a href="/wiki/Chapli_kebab" title="Chapli kebab">chapli kebab</a>, <a href="/wiki/Shami_kebab" title="Shami kebab">shami kebab</a>, <a href="/wiki/Chicken_tikka" title="Chicken tikka">chicken tikka</a> and <a href="/wiki/Shashlik" title="Shashlik">shashlik</a>, along with various types of <i>chaaps</i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-shaheda_417-5"><a href="#cite_note-shaheda-417">[417]</a></sup> Popular street foods include <a href="/wiki/Chotpoti" title="Chotpoti">chotpoti</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jhal_muri" title="Jhal muri">jhal muri</a> and <a href="/wiki/Panipuri" title="Panipuri">fuchka</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-427"><a href="#cite_note-427">[427]</a></sup> The large Bangladeshi diaspora dominate the South Asian restaurant industry in many Western countries, particularly in the United Kingdom.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-428"><a href="#cite_note-428">[428]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Festivals">Festivals</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Public_holidays_in_Bangladesh" title="Public holidays in Bangladesh">Public holidays in Bangladesh</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_festivals_in_Bangladesh" title="List of festivals in Bangladesh">List of festivals in Bangladesh</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:302px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Nouka_Baich_(Boat_Race)_(9903944955).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2000" data-file-width="3008" decoding="async" height="199" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/Nouka_Baich_%28Boat_Race%29_%289903944955%29.jpg/300px-Nouka_Baich_%28Boat_Race%29_%289903944955%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/Nouka_Baich_%28Boat_Race%29_%289903944955%29.jpg/450px-Nouka_Baich_%28Boat_Race%29_%289903944955%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/Nouka_Baich_%28Boat_Race%29_%289903944955%29.jpg/600px-Nouka_Baich_%28Boat_Race%29_%289903944955%29.jpg 2x" width="300"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Nouka_Baich_(Boat_Race)_(9903944955).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A <a href="/wiki/Nouka_Baich" title="Nouka Baich">Nouka Baich</a> boat race</div></div></div>
<p><i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pahela_Baishakh" title="Pahela Baishakh">Pahela Baishakh</a></i>, the Bengali new year, is the major festival of <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_Bengal" title="Culture of Bengal">Bengali culture</a> and sees widespread festivities. Of the major holidays celebrated in Bangladesh, only Pahela Baishakh comes without any pre-existing expectations (specific religious identity, culture of gift-giving, etc.) and has become an occasion for celebrating the simpler, rural roots of the Bengal. Other cultural festivals include <a href="/wiki/Nabanna" title="Nabanna">Nabonno</a> and Poush Parbon, Bengali harvest festivals.
</p><p>The Muslim festivals of Eid al-Fitr, <a href="/wiki/Eid_al-Adha" title="Eid al-Adha">Eid al-Adha</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Milad_un_Nabi" title="Milad un Nabi">Milad un Nabi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Muharram" title="Muharram">Muharram</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chand_Raat" title="Chand Raat">Chand Raat</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Barat_Night" title="Barat Night">Shab-e-Barat</a>; the Hindu festivals of <a href="/wiki/Durga_Puja" title="Durga Puja">Durga Puja</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Janmashtami" title="Janmashtami">Janmashtami</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rath_Yatra" title="Rath Yatra">Rath Yatra</a>; the Buddhist festival of <a href="/wiki/Vesak" title="Vesak">Buddha Purnima</a>, which marks the birth of <a href="/wiki/Gautama_Buddha" title="Gautama Buddha">Gautama Buddha</a>, and the Christian festival of Christmas are <a href="/wiki/Public_holidays_in_Bangladesh" title="Public holidays in Bangladesh">national holidays</a> in Bangladesh and see the most widespread celebrations in the country. The two Eids are celebrated with a long streak of public holidays and give the city-dwellers opportunity to celebrate the festivals with their families outside the city.
</p><p>Alongside are national days like the remembrance of 21 February 1952 <a href="/wiki/Language_Movement_Day" title="Language Movement Day">Language Movement Day</a> (declared as <a href="/wiki/International_Mother_Language_Day" title="International Mother Language Day">International Mother Language Day</a> by <a href="/wiki/UNESCO" title="UNESCO">UNESCO</a> in 1999),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-UNESCO_429-0"><a href="#cite_note-UNESCO-429">[429]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Independence_Day_(Bangladesh)" title="Independence Day (Bangladesh)">Independence Day</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Victory_day_of_Bangladesh" title="Victory day of Bangladesh">Victory Day</a>. On Language Movement Day, people congregate at the <a href="/wiki/Shaheed_Minar,_Dhaka" title="Shaheed Minar, Dhaka">Shaheed Minar</a> in Dhaka to remember the national heroes of the Bengali Language Movement. Similar gatherings are observed at the <a href="/wiki/National_Martyrs%27_Memorial" title="National Martyrs' Memorial">National Martyrs' Memorial</a> on Independence Day and Victory Day to remember the national heroes of the <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh_Liberation_War" title="Bangladesh Liberation War">Bangladesh Liberation War</a>. These occasions are celebrated with public ceremonies, parades, rallies by citizens, political speeches, fairs, concerts, and various other public and private events, celebrating the history and traditions of Bangladesh. TV and radio stations broadcast special programs and patriotic songs. Many schools and colleges organise fairs, festivals, and concerts that draw the participation of citizens from all levels of Bangladeshi society.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-430"><a href="#cite_note-430">[430]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Sports">Sports</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sports_in_Bangladesh" title="Sports in Bangladesh">Sports in Bangladesh</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:252px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Bangladesh_team_on_practice_session_at_Sher-e-Bangla_National_Cricket_Stadium_(4).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="4000" data-file-width="6000" decoding="async" height="167" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9a/Bangladesh_team_on_practice_session_at_Sher-e-Bangla_National_Cricket_Stadium_%284%29.jpg/250px-Bangladesh_team_on_practice_session_at_Sher-e-Bangla_National_Cricket_Stadium_%284%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9a/Bangladesh_team_on_practice_session_at_Sher-e-Bangla_National_Cricket_Stadium_%284%29.jpg/375px-Bangladesh_team_on_practice_session_at_Sher-e-Bangla_National_Cricket_Stadium_%284%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9a/Bangladesh_team_on_practice_session_at_Sher-e-Bangla_National_Cricket_Stadium_%284%29.jpg/500px-Bangladesh_team_on_practice_session_at_Sher-e-Bangla_National_Cricket_Stadium_%284%29.jpg 2x" width="250"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Bangladesh_team_on_practice_session_at_Sher-e-Bangla_National_Cricket_Stadium_(4).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Bangladesh team on practice session at Sher-e-Bangla National Cricket Stadium</div></div></div>
<p>In rural Bangladesh, several traditional indigenous sports such as <a href="/wiki/Kabaddi" title="Kabaddi">Kabaddi</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Boli_Khela" title="Boli Khela">Boli Khela</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Lathi_Khela" title="Lathi Khela">Lathi Khela</a> and <a href="/wiki/Nouka_Baich" title="Nouka Baich">Nouka Baich</a> remain fairly popular. While <a href="/wiki/Kabaddi" title="Kabaddi">Kabaddi</a> is the national sport,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-431"><a href="#cite_note-431">[431]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Cricket" title="Cricket">cricket</a> is the most popular sport in the country. The <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh_national_cricket_team" title="Bangladesh national cricket team">national cricket team</a> participated in their first <a href="/wiki/Cricket_World_Cup" title="Cricket World Cup">Cricket World Cup</a> in 1999 and the following year was granted <a href="/wiki/Test_cricket" title="Test cricket">Test cricket</a> status. Bangladesh reached the quarter-final of the <a href="/wiki/2015_Cricket_World_Cup" title="2015 Cricket World Cup">2015 Cricket World Cup</a>, the semi-final of the <a href="/wiki/2017_ICC_Champions_Trophy" title="2017 ICC Champions Trophy">2017 ICC Champions Trophy</a> and they reached the final of the <a href="/wiki/Asia_Cup" title="Asia Cup">Asia Cup</a> 3 times – in 2012, 2016 and 2018. In February 2020, the Bangladesh youth national cricket team won the men's <a href="/wiki/2020_Under-19_Cricket_World_Cup" title="2020 Under-19 Cricket World Cup">Under-19 Cricket World Cup</a>, held in South Africa. This was Bangladesh's first World Cup victory.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-432"><a href="#cite_note-432">[432]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-433"><a href="#cite_note-433">[433]</a></sup> Women's sports saw significant progress in the 2010s decade in Bangladesh. In 2018, the <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh_women%27s_national_cricket_team" title="Bangladesh women's national cricket team">Bangladesh women's national cricket team</a> won the <a href="/wiki/2018_Women%27s_Twenty20_Asia_Cup" title="2018 Women's Twenty20 Asia Cup">2018 Women's Twenty20 Asia Cup</a> defeating <a href="/wiki/India_women%27s_national_cricket_team" title="India women's national cricket team">India women's national cricket team</a> in the final.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-434"><a href="#cite_note-434">[434]</a></sup>
</p><p>Football is a popular sport in Bangladesh,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-435"><a href="#cite_note-435">[435]</a></sup> and is governed by the <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh_Football_Federation" title="Bangladesh Football Federation">Bangladesh Football Federation</a> (BFF). The first instance of a Bangladesh national football team was the emergence of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Shadhin_Bangla_Football_Team" title="Shadhin Bangla Football Team">Shadhin Bangla Football Team</a> during the 1971 <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh_Liberation_War" title="Bangladesh Liberation War">liberation war</a>. The national team also participated in the <a href="/wiki/1980_AFC_Asian_Cup" title="1980 AFC Asian Cup">1980 AFC Asian Cup</a>, becoming only the second <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/South_Asian" title="South Asian">South Asian</a> team to do so.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-436"><a href="#cite_note-436">[436]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh_women%27s_national_football_team" title="Bangladesh women's national football team">Bangladesh women's national football team</a> has also registered some success at regional level, especially the Under-15 and Under-18 teams.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-437"><a href="#cite_note-437">[437]</a></sup>
</p><p>Bangladesh archers Ety Khatun and Roman Sana won several gold medals winning all the 10 <a href="/wiki/Archery" title="Archery">archery</a> events (both individual, and team events) in the <a href="/wiki/2019_South_Asian_Games" title="2019 South Asian Games">2019 South Asian Games</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-438"><a href="#cite_note-438">[438]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/National_Sports_Council" title="National Sports Council">National Sports Council</a> regulates 42 sporting federations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-439"><a href="#cite_note-439">[439]</a></sup> Athletics, swimming, archery, boxing, volleyball, weight-lifting and wrestling and different forms of martial arts remain popular. <a href="/wiki/Chess" title="Chess">Chess</a> is very popular in Bangladesh. Bangladesh has five grandmasters in chess. Among them, <a href="/wiki/Niaz_Murshed" title="Niaz Murshed">Niaz Murshed</a> was the first grandmaster in South Asia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-440"><a href="#cite_note-440">[440]</a></sup> In 2010, mountain climber <a href="/wiki/Musa_Ibrahim" title="Musa Ibrahim">Musa Ibrahim</a> became the first Bangladeshi climber to conquer <a href="/wiki/Mount_Everest" title="Mount Everest">Mount Everest</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-dailystardetail_441-0"><a href="#cite_note-dailystardetail-441">[441]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Wasfia_Nazreen" title="Wasfia Nazreen">Wasfia Nazreen</a> is the first Bangladeshi climber to climb the <a href="/wiki/Seven_Summits" title="Seven Summits">Seven Summits</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-442"><a href="#cite_note-442">[442]</a></sup>
</p><p>Bangladesh hosts a number of international tournaments. <a href="/wiki/Bangabandhu_Cup" title="Bangabandhu Cup">Bangabandhu Cup</a> is an international football tournament hosted in the country. Bangladesh hosted the South Asian Games several times. In 2011, Bangladesh co-hosted the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ICC_Cricket_World_Cup_2011" title="ICC Cricket World Cup 2011">ICC Cricket World Cup 2011</a> with India and Sri Lanka. Bangladesh solely hosted the <a href="/wiki/2014_ICC_World_Twenty20" title="2014 ICC World Twenty20">2014 ICC World Twenty20</a> championship. Bangladesh hosted the <a href="/wiki/Asia_Cup" title="Asia Cup">Asia Cup</a> Cricket Tournament in 2000, 2012, 2014 and 2016.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Media_and_cinema">Media and cinema</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Media_of_Bangladesh" title="Media of Bangladesh">Media of Bangladesh</a> and <a href="/wiki/Cinema_of_Bangladesh" title="Cinema of Bangladesh">Cinema of Bangladesh</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Anwar_Hossain_in_the_film_%22Nawab_Sirajuddoulah%22_(1967).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="451" data-file-width="660" decoding="async" height="150" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2c/Anwar_Hossain_in_the_film_%22Nawab_Sirajuddoulah%22_%281967%29.jpg/220px-Anwar_Hossain_in_the_film_%22Nawab_Sirajuddoulah%22_%281967%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2c/Anwar_Hossain_in_the_film_%22Nawab_Sirajuddoulah%22_%281967%29.jpg/330px-Anwar_Hossain_in_the_film_%22Nawab_Sirajuddoulah%22_%281967%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2c/Anwar_Hossain_in_the_film_%22Nawab_Sirajuddoulah%22_%281967%29.jpg/440px-Anwar_Hossain_in_the_film_%22Nawab_Sirajuddoulah%22_%281967%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Anwar_Hossain_in_the_film_%22Nawab_Sirajuddoulah%22_(1967).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Anwar_Hossain_(actor)" title="Anwar Hossain (actor)">Anwar Hossain</a> playing <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Siraj-ud-Daulah" title="Siraj-ud-Daulah">Siraj-ud-Daulah</a>, the last independent <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nawab_of_Bengal" title="Nawab of Bengal">Nawab of Bengal</a>, in the 1967 film <i><a href="/wiki/Nawab_Sirajuddaula_(film)" title="Nawab Sirajuddaula (film)">Nawab Sirajuddaulah</a></i></div></div></div>
<p>The Bangladeshi press is diverse, outspoken and privately owned. Over 200 newspapers are published in the country. <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh_Betar" title="Bangladesh Betar">Bangladesh Betar</a> is the state-run radio service.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-443"><a href="#cite_note-443">[443]</a></sup> The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/British_Broadcasting_Corporation" title="British Broadcasting Corporation">British Broadcasting Corporation</a> operates the popular <a href="/wiki/BBC_Bangla" title="BBC Bangla">BBC Bangla</a> news and current affairs service. Bengali broadcasts from <a href="/wiki/Voice_of_America" title="Voice of America">Voice of America</a> are also very popular. <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh_Television" title="Bangladesh Television">Bangladesh Television</a> (BTV) is a state-owned television network. More than 20 privately owned television networks, including several <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/News_channel" title="News channel">news channels</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Freedom_of_the_media" title="Freedom of the media">Freedom of the media</a> remains a major concern due to government attempts at censorship and the harassment of journalists.
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Cinema_of_Bangladesh" title="Cinema of Bangladesh">cinema of Bangladesh</a> dates back to 1898 when films began screening at the Crown Theatre in Dhaka. The first bioscope on the subcontinent was established in Dhaka that year. The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Dhaka_Nawab_Family" title="Dhaka Nawab Family">Dhaka Nawab Family</a> patronised the production of several <a href="/wiki/Silent_film" title="Silent film">silent films</a> in the 1920s and 30s. In 1931, the East Bengal Cinematograph Society released the first full-length feature film in Bangladesh, titled the <i>Last Kiss</i>. The first feature film in East Pakistan, <i><a href="/wiki/Mukh_O_Mukhosh" title="Mukh O Mukhosh">Mukh O Mukhosh</a></i>, was released in 1956. During the 1960s, 25–30 films were produced annually in Dhaka. By the 2000s, Bangladesh produced 80–100 films a year. While the Bangladeshi film industry has achieved limited commercial success, the country has produced notable independent filmmakers. <a href="/wiki/Zahir_Raihan" title="Zahir Raihan">Zahir Raihan</a> was a prominent documentary-maker assassinated in 1971. The late <a href="/wiki/Tareque_Masud" title="Tareque Masud">Tareque Masud</a> is regarded as one of Bangladesh's outstanding directors for his critically acclaimed films on social issues.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-444"><a href="#cite_note-444">[444]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-445"><a href="#cite_note-445">[445]</a></sup> Masud was honoured by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/FIPRESCI" title="FIPRESCI">FIPRESCI</a> at the 2002 <a href="/wiki/Cannes_Film_Festival" title="Cannes Film Festival">Cannes Film Festival</a> for his film <i><a href="/wiki/Matir_Moina" title="Matir Moina">The Clay Bird</a></i>. <a href="/wiki/Tanvir_Mokammel" title="Tanvir Mokammel">Tanvir Mokammel</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mostofa_Sarwar_Farooki" title="Mostofa Sarwar Farooki">Mostofa Sarwar Farooki</a>, <a href="/wiki/Humayun_Ahmed" title="Humayun Ahmed">Humayun Ahmed</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Alamgir_Kabir_(filmmaker)" title="Alamgir Kabir (filmmaker)">Alamgir Kabir</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Chashi_Nazrul_Islam" title="Chashi Nazrul Islam">Chashi Nazrul Islam</a> are some of the prominent directors of Bangladeshi cinema. Bangladesh has a very active film society culture. It started in 1963 in Dhaka. Now around 40 Film Societies are active all over Bangladesh. <a href="/wiki/Federation_of_Film_Societies_of_Bangladesh" title="Federation of Film Societies of Bangladesh">Federation of Film Societies of Bangladesh</a> is the parent organisation of the film society movement of Bangladesh. Active film societies include the Rainbow Film Society, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Children%27s_Film_Society" title="Children's Film Society">Children's Film Society</a>, <a href="/wiki/Moviyana_Film_Society" title="Moviyana Film Society">Moviyana Film Society</a> and <a href="/wiki/Dhaka_University_Film_Society" title="Dhaka University Film Society">Dhaka University Film Society</a>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Museums_and_libraries">Museums and libraries</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Museums_in_Bangladesh" title="Museums in Bangladesh">Museums in Bangladesh</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_libraries_in_Bangladesh" title="List of libraries in Bangladesh">List of libraries in Bangladesh</a></div>
